HEADLINE: Rochester Goes for Green, On and Off Championship Course 

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE YORK

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, Aug. 13 

 BODY:
The homicide rate is up. The main employer, Eastman Kodak, is laying off people -- again. And the candidates for the region's top offices are sniping at one another almost daily in bitter election campaigns.
 So naturally, Rochesterians have a lot on their mind. Like golf. 
 Will the surprise British Open winner, Ben Curtis, have a chance? Or will it be Tiger Woods who burns bright? And don't forget about the favorite son, Jeff Sluman. 
Rochester is playing host to the 85th P.G.A. Championship, one of the Grand Slam contests of the golfing world, which promises to provide an economic boost and mental distraction to this beleaguered city in western New York.
"Do we need it? Ab-so-lute-ly," said Patrick Marcanio, a bartender who was hawking Professional Golfers Association specials -- a $15 parking spot during the tournament, and a $12-off dinner coupon for after -- outside Hawthorne's Restaurant on Tuesday. "Oh my God, do we need it."
PGA officials say they expect the tournament, which runs Thursday through Sunday, to draw up to 35,000 people a day and pump $45 million into the local economy. While it is probably difficult to find a hotel room (nearly all of the region's 6,400 hotel rooms are booked), it is a good bet that parking spots are easy to come by. Many of those who live close to the Oak Hill Country Club, where the tournament will be played, are parceling out their manicured lawns with the eagerness of children selling lemonade. 
"Rochester is really a golf-oriented community," said Ed Hall, president of the Greater Rochester Visitors Association. "For those who love it, this is like a 12" on a scale of 1 to 10.
Oak Hill has been host to major golf tournaments periodically since 1949, when the United States Golf Association held the United States Amateur Championship. In 1968, Lee Trevino won his first professional golf tournament there, the United States Open, and became the first man in history to shoot four rounds of sub-70 golf in an Open, according to Oak Hill history.
The U.S. Amateur Championship in 1998 was its last major tournament.
Before practice sessions began Monday -- attracting 25,000 spectators in spite of water hazards from above, consistently gray and threatening skies -- much of the news here was bleak. 
In the last month, Eastman Kodak, which has been shrinking for the last decade, announced plans to lay off an additional 6,000 to 9,000 workers. The Rochester police vowed to step up efforts after it reported a homicide rate that was the worst in years. Candidates competing for the region's top offices are holding regular news conferences to criticize one another. 
"I don't think this will be any vacation from bad news," said Mayor William A. Johnson Jr., a candidate for Monroe County executive who plans to take his eldest grandson, Blaine Bromfield, 13, to the tournament to glimpse Tiger Woods. 
"These are just bad times, period."
Not so, says the current Monroe County executive, Jack Doyle, who is vacillating between rooting for Mr. Woods and for Mr. Sluman. "The PGA is a good opportunity," Mr. Doyle said. "Travel writers and site selectors are coming in. Golf is one of the selling points of this community."
As top-level business leaders come into town, Mr. Hall plans to show them what Rochester has to offer. "I think it's a great event," he said. "It reinforces the fact we can put on a world-class event and do it with style." He added that he was cheering on Mr. Woods, "everybody's sentimental favorite."
Mr. Marcanio, the bartender, was enthusiastically rooting for Mr. Sluman. "Come on, Jeff," he shouted at passing cars today.
Some have not chosen favorites. Richard Steamer, a Sunoco franchise owner, said he considered golf a "good way to ruin a walk." He was rooting for the spectators he expects will pay $20 for his makeshift valet parking service. 
David Metzger and Herb Ross, volunteer firefighters and PGA volunteers, admit that they do not play much golf. They were cheering mostly for the region itself. 
"This brings a whole level of excitement to the community that we don't really have," Mr. Metzger said. "It adds flair and fun."

HEADLINE: National Briefing Rockies: Colorado: Stress On the Ballot 

BYLINE:  By Mindy Sink (NYT)

 BODY:
 Stress, or efforts to reduce it, will be on the ballot for Denver voters this fall. Jeff Peckman, 49, collected enough signatures to force the city council to either pass his initiative, which would require the city to study ways to alleviate stress, or send it to the voters. Mr. Peckman said he believed that soothing music in public places could help lower crime and improve the economy. Council members say they regard the measure as frivolous, with one calling it lunatic and another saying it was causing her stress.
 Mindy Sink (NYT)

HEADLINE: ARTS BRIEFING 

BYLINE:  By Ben Sisario 

 BODY:
 HIGHLIGHTS

MONTREAL: FESTIVAL TO SHOW SLAIN FRENCH ACTRESS'S NEW FILM -- The Montreal World Film Festival will show the latest film with Marie Trintignant, left, the French actress who was killed earlier this month. "Les Marins Perdus," which had its premiere in Paris last month, will be one of the 439 films from 68 countries shown in the festival. It was directed by Claire Devers and also stars Audrey Tautou and Bernard Giraudeau. The festival, which this year honors Martin Scorsese, the Swedish actor Erland Josephson and the Montreal-based producer Denise Robert, begins Aug. 27 and runs through Sept. 7. Ms. Trintignant, 41, died on Aug. 1 in a Paris hospital from severe head and face injuries suffered several days earlier in Vilnius, Lithuania, where she was shooting a film. Her boyfriend, the French rock singer Bertrand Cantat, has been arrested as a suspect in the murder.

DALAI LAMA TO SPEAK AT CONCERT -- The Dalai Lama is going to be a busy man during his tour of New York in September. In addition to his four days of teachings at the Beacon Theater and his appearance at Central Park, he will speak at Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center on Sept. 21 in a benefit concert for Healing the Divide, a new nonprofit organization that promotes culture, health, economic growth and technology in the Himalayan region. The hosts of the concert are Philip Glass and Richard Gere, and the performers are to include the Kronos Quartet, Jessye Norman, Anoushka Shankar, Hamza El Din, the Buddhist monks of the Gyuto Tantric Choir, Foday Musa Suso, R. Carlos Nakai, Nawang Khechog and Mr. Glass. The Dalai Lama, who will visit New York from Sept. 17 to 21, will speak to the public at the East Meadow in Central Park earlier in the day on Sept. 21. He last visited New York in 1999.

EDINBURGH: FRANKENTHALER PAINTINGS OPEN NEW MUSEUM GALLERIES -- The Royal Scottish Academy in Edinburgh, currently the site of a blockbuster exhibition of Monet paintings, will open a new gallery space tomorrow with an exhibition by the American painter Helen Frankenthaler, "Frankenthaler: Paintings on Paper (1949-2002)." The show, which includes "Eve," above, is organized by the Museum of Contemporary Art, North Miami, in Florida. It will open a large new exhibition space downstairs at the academy, which was founded in 1826 and is part of the National Galleries of Scotland. Ms. Frankenthaler has worked almost exclusively on paper for the last decade, but this show of 42 abstract paintings includes works from her entire career. Ms. Frankenthaler, 74, who was born in New York and now lives in Connecticut, was made a member of the Royal Scottish Academy earlier this year. The exhibition is to remain up through Oct. 26. Upstairs from the Frankenthaler show, "Monet: The Seine and the Sea" opened last week with 80 paintings from the period before Monet painted his famous water lilies. That exhibition is drawing record crowds. The BBC reported that 19,000 people saw the show in its opening week.

THEATER NEWS -- Two Off Broadway companies have announced their seasons for 2003-4. Theater for a New Audience, in its 25th season, will offer three productions: the New York premiere in English of "The Last Letter," an adaptation by Frederick Wiseman of a chapter from the novel "Life and Fate" by the Russian author Vasily Grossman, opening Dec. 18 at the Lucille Lortel Theater on Christopher Street; a production of Shakespeare's "Pericles," to be staged at the Brooklyn Academy of Music's Harvey Theater in February; and "Engaged," an 1877 farce by W. S. Gilbert (of Gilbert and Sullivan fame), in April at the Lucille Lortel. Primary Stages, in its 19th season, also has three productions, opening with the New York premiere of A. R. Gurney's "Strictly Academic," a bill of two one-acts ("The Problem" and "The Guest Lecturer"), on Oct. 21 at the Primary Stages 45th Street Theater. In January the company inaugurates its new performance space, 59E59, at 59 East 59th Street, with two new plays by Terrence McNally, "Full Frontal Nudity" and "Prelude & Liebestod," which are collectively called "The Stendhal Syndrome." The premiere of Julia Jordan's "Boy" is to run at the 45th Street space in April and May.

FOOTNOTES

Three Farms, a pair of free rock concerts in the East River Park on the Lower East Side, has had bad luck with the weather this summer. Two scheduled concerts, on June 7 and 21, were postponed by rain; even the rain date, June 22, was rained out. The festival is trying again on Sunday with a concert called "Who'll Stop the Rain?," with David Johansen and the Harry Smiths, Mary Lee's Corvette, Rachel Loshak, Andrew Vladeck and others. It starts at 1 p.m. at the East River Park Amphitheater, south of Grand Street. . . . David Bowie, above, will be broadcasting a London concert on Sept. 8 to fans in movie theaters around the world. The 90-minute concert is to be seen live by satellite in more than 20 cinemas across Europe and the following day in Asia and Australia. Fans in North and South American will see it on Sept. 15.

HEADLINE: Kentucky Race Is Test For Bush on Economy 

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: LOUISVILLE, Ky., Aug. 13 

 BODY:
Improbable as it sounds, the first major test of President Bush's vulnerability on the weak economy may come this November in a state that he won handily in 2000, where his favorable ratings are still high and where Republicans hold seven of eight Congressional seats. 
 No one said Kentucky politics was predictable. 
 With a tenacity that has surprised his opponent and some supporters, the Democratic candidate for governor, Attorney General Ben Chandler, has attacked Mr. Bush's stewardship of the economy, contending that Republican policies have drained Kentucky of 56,000 jobs, aided the wealthy at the expense of the poor and helped drill a gaping hole in the state budget. 
"It's hard to believe that just three years ago, Kentucky had a surplus, had an economy that was growing," Mr. Chandler, 43, said Monday at a campaign event outside a shuttered I.B.M. plant in Lexington. "What has changed is the team in charge in Washington. And my opponent is in the starting lineup."
He has mocked his Republican opponent, Representative Ernie Fletcher, as "the job terminator." He jokes that Mr. Fletcher's motto is "leave no job behind," a jab at President Bush's vow to "leave no child behind."
The state Democratic Party has even created a Web site featuring a comic-strip depiction of an evil emperor -- President Bush -- conspiring with Mr. Fletcher to wreck the economy.
With his scathing attacks on the White House, Mr. Chandler has turned Kentucky, which has voted with the winner in every presidential election since 1964, into a closely watched bellwether of the 2004 presidential campaign, analysts say. 
If Mr. Chandler, considered the underdog, can ride voters' anxieties about unemployment to victory, it could give the Democrats momentum in their seemingly uphill quest to unseat the president, Democrats and political analysts assert.
"He has a powerful message," said Nicole Harburger, spokeswoman for the Democratic Governors Association. "I would not be surprised if the economy and unemployment become the seminal issues in many campaigns."
Kentucky Republicans seem bemused by the attacks, deriding Mr. Chandler as a "guinea pig" for national Democratic strategists. If anything, they have wrapped themselves tighter around the president, who has a 70 percent favorable rating in Kentucky, according to their polls. 
"If they'd like to run against President Bush," said Senator Mitch McConnell, the state's most powerful Republican and a mentor to Mr. Fletcher, "I question whether they are smart enough to take over the job."
Still, Mr. Chandler's assault seems to have put Mr. Fletcher on the defensive. In campaign events, he acknowledges that Kentucky's economy is struggling and that job creation should be among the new governor's top priorities.
But Mr. Fletcher places the blame on the Democratic governor, Paul E. Patton, who because of term limits must leave office at the end of the year. And Mr. Fletcher has made Democratic longevity in the governor's mansion -- there has not been a Republican governor in 32 years -- his central campaign theme. 
"Ben talks about change," Mr. Fletcher, 50, said in a debate in Louisville on Tuesday. "The biggest change he wants is to move his desk 100 feet."
Mr. Patton casts a broad shadow over the race in another way: his administration has been racked by scandal. 
Last September, the governor admitted having a two-year affair with a Kentucky businesswoman, reversing his earlier denials. The woman, Tina Conner, was indicted in July on federal charges that she used false information to apply for state highway contracts. She has pleaded not guilty and has sued Mr. Patton, contending that he pressured state officials to help her during the affair, then harassed her after she broke it off. He denies both assertions.
More indictments are considered likely, and the trial is set for October, just weeks before the election.
In June, Mr. Patton also pardoned two top aides and two union officials who had been indicted on charges of violating state campaign finance laws in 1995. The charges were brought by Mr. Chandler, who angrily called on the governor to resign when the pardons were announced. 
What is more, the state auditor said this month that more than 200 computers in the state's transportation agency had been used to search for pornographic Web sites. The F.B.I. has joined an investigation into the matter. 
Mr. Chandler has tried to distance himself from Mr. Patton, calling himself a "maverick" who had angered the Democratic establishment by indicting the governor's aides. But Republicans are not letting him off the hook.
"We have the most scandal-ridden, embarrassing administration we've had in years," Mr. Fletcher said in an interview. "To have him sitting in the middle of it as the chief law enforcement officer, it's going to be impossible for him to dissociate himself from it."
Despite Mr. Chandler's attacks on the president's policies, the prescriptions he offers for reviving the economy do not differ markedly from those of Mr. Fletcher. 
Mr. Chandler generally supports tax cuts, though he says he would give more relief to lower income families. Both men have endorsed tax breaks to encourage job creation and programs to retrain displaced workers. Neither has issued a detailed plan for closing a projected $274 million state budget shortfall, beyond trimming the state work force and cutting "waste and fraud." 
They do differ on the issue of gambling. Mr. Chandler has called for allowing slot machines in racetracks to generate revenue for schools. Mr. Fletcher has said he opposes gambling, but would be willing to hold a referendum on the issue.
Mr. Chandler, a former state auditor, learned about politics at the knee of his grandfather, A. B. (Happy) Chandler, a former governor and commissioner of baseball who epitomized a back-slapping Kentucky style of charisma. Mr. Fletcher, a former practicing physician and fighter pilot, is more reserved and formal, though he shows flashes of an acerbic wit.
Their contrasting styles were evident Monday night at a political picnic at Red's Fish House, a popular Owensboro restaurant. Mr. Chandler, sweating and garrulous, pumped hands and grabbed shoulders with the vigor of a masseur. Mr. Fletcher, stiff and cerebral, talked quietly with supporters and at times found himself standing alone.
At Red's, some Democrats expressed concerns that Mr. Chandler's attacks on the president could alienate conservative Democrats. 
But many Democrats at Red's also said they thought Mr. Chandler -- who barely survived a bruising primary and is running several points behind Mr. Fletcher in public polls -- had few alternatives. 
"What else do you have?" asked Wendell H. Ford, a former Democratic senator. "The only record the opponent has is in Congress."
Meanwhile, Republicans seem energized by the opportunity to retake the governor's office. The White House has dispatched the presidential political strategist Karl Rove, Energy Secretary Spencer Abraham and a Bush brother, Gov. Jeb Bush of Florida, to appear at fund-raisers for Mr. Fletcher. 
Asked if he expected the president himself to campaign for him, Mr. Fletcher said, "I sure hope so." Mr. Chandler said he would also welcome a visit by Mr. Bush. 
"We'll ask him if he brought along any jobs," Mr. Chandler said.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 1, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article on Aug. 14 about the campaign for the Kentucky governorship misidentified the location of Red's Fish House, a restaurant where the candidates appeared at a political picnic. It is in Sorgho; Owensboro is seven miles to the east.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
Making Light Of the Season Of Absurdity

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK

 BODY:
IN California, people are annoyed with the governor they just re-elected, so they are threatening to replace him with an actor or a columnist or a former child star. In New York, the senior senator is so popular he could run for re-election with negligible competition, so a political critic tried to stir up opposition by accusing him of religious bias. And in television land, a network that labels itself "fair and balanced" is suing a comedian for using those rare words in a book title.
 The political scientists will no doubt tie themselves into knots parsing the dire implications of the summer of 2003, but we prefer to look on the positive side. It's August, the country is taking a break from pondering wars, orange alerts and unemployment statistics, and having some fun. 
 Consider the California scene -- 135 people are running for the punitive job of replacing the incumbent, Gray Davis, if he is recalled in October. The campaign, barely begun, is already tickling the political imagination. Imagine a 135-way debate. O.K., forget that.
Imagine Bill Clinton as an adviser. He is telling Mr. Davis to act gubernatorial. It is nice of him to help out. But isn't the way Mr. Davis has been governing -- from his handling of the state's energy crisis a few years ago to his management of its staggering budget deficit -- what got him in trouble in the first place?
Back in New York, which would never ignore the silly season, politics has produced a home-grown spectacle. The Conservative Party chairman, Michael R. Long, said in several interviews this week that Senator Charles E. Schumer had "an anti-Catholic bias" because of his opposition to some of President Bush's judicial nominees.
Mr. Schumer and other Senate Democrats have been fighting a handful of the president's nominees, arguing that they are far removed from the ideological mainstream and could impose their own views and philosophy on the law.
That, in Mr. Long's view, is being anti-Catholic: "I think he has a prejudice against anyone who is pro-life, for traditional family values, and who fights the gay agenda." When told that Senate Democrats, including Mr. Schumer, had supported dozens of judicial candidates who are both Catholic and opposed to abortion rights, he dismissed those nominees as "pro forma," compared with more prominent candidates.
Mr. Long's allegations were not made in isolation. The same day that his remarks appeared in The New York Post, Robert Novak wrote about the judicial battle in his column, citing charges of anti-Catholicism from Senate Republicans and the Knights of Columbus. He called Mr. Schumer "aggressive," referred to his "confidence and assertiveness" and cited his "massive war chest." Must be because the senator is from New York.
Mr. Long, who says the timing was a coincidence, was criticized by public figures ranging from Edward I. Koch (a Democrat) to Alfonse M. D'Amato and Guy V. Molinari (Republicans). But he is standing firm, and says he is still hopeful he might get someone to actually run against the senator next year. He declined to name names.
Mr. Schumer reacted to Mr. Long's charges by relating a conversation with Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona. "He said to me, 'Don't be the lead guy on the judicial nominees because the hard right wants this badly, and if you get in their way, they will be brutal with you, the way they were with me in South Carolina,' " Mr. Schumer recalled yesterday from Madrid, where he is vacationing. "I said to him, 'John, you forgot one thing: I'm from Brooklyn.' " He would prefer to be attacked on the merits, he added.
AL FRANKEN doesn't mind being attacked any which way, and why should he? A day after news accounts reported that he had been sued by the Fox News Network for using words they claim as their own in a book title, the new book made it to No. 1 on Amazon.com's best seller list, rising from the 400's a day earlier.
The network argues that it has trademarked "Fair and Balanced" to describe its news coverage and that Mr. Franken is besmirching it. So Fox, which truly is as fair and balanced as it is reputable, went to court to stop the satirist from selling his book -- "Lies, and the Lying Liars Who Tell Them: A Fair and Balanced Look at the Right" (Dutton) -- as is. 
Mr. Franken, on vacation in Italy, issued a statement thanking Fox for the publicity, and joked about a countersuit.
Or was it a joke? We shall ask again -- after August has ended.

HEADLINE: No Work, No Homes 

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT; E-mail: bobherb@nytimes.com

 BODY:
Talk about preaching to the choir. President Bush and his clueless team of economic advisers held a summit at the president's ranch in Crawford, Tex., yesterday. This is the ferociously irresponsible crowd that has turned its back on simple arithmetic and thinks the answer to every economic question is a gigantic tax cut for the rich.
 Their voodoo fantasies were safe in Crawford. There was no one at the ranch to chastise them for bequeathing backbreaking budget deficits to generations yet unborn. And no one was there to confront them with evidence of the intense suffering that so many poor, working-class and middle-class families are experiencing right now because of job losses on Mr. Bush's watch. 
 After the meeting, Mr. Bush said, "This administration is optimistic about job creation."
It's too bad George Akerlof wasn't at the meeting. Mr. Akerlof, a 2001 Nobel laureate in economics, bluntly declared on Tuesday that "the Bush fiscal policy is the worst policy in the last 200 years." Speaking at a press conference arranged by the Economic Policy Institute, Mr. Akerlof, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley, said, "Within 10 years, we're going to pay a serious price for such irresponsibility."
Also participating in the institute's press conference was Robert Solow, an economist and professor emeritus at M.I.T. who is also a Nobel laureate. He assailed the Bush tax cuts as "redistributive in intent and redistributive in effect."
"There has been a dissipation of the huge budget surplus," he said, "and all we have to show for that is the city of Baghdad."
The president and his advisers could have learned something about the real world if, instead of hanging out at the ranch, they had visited a city like Los Angeles (or almost any other hard-hit American venue) and spent time talking to folks who have been thrown out of work and, in some cases, out of their homes in this treacherous Bush economy.
The job market in California worsened in July. More than a million people are out of work statewide, and there are few signs of the optimism that Mr. Bush is feeling.
Officials at homeless shelters in Los Angeles, as in other large American cities, are seeing big increases in the number of families seeking shelter because of extended periods of joblessness. The pattern is as depressing as it is familiar: the savings run out, the rent doesn't get paid, the eviction notice arrives.
Tanya Tull, president of Beyond Shelter in downtown L.A., said the percentage of families in her facility had climbed from about one-third to more than half because of the employment crisis. The breadwinners can't find jobs, she said, "so they're losing their housing."
Ralph Plumb, president of the Union Rescue Mission on L.A.'s skid row, said his agency, traditionally a haven for homeless men with drug and alcohol problems, is providing shelter for more and more "intact" families. Their problems are not the result of drug or alcohol abuse, or mental impairment. They simply have no money. Forty percent of the people at the mission are there "purely due to economic issues," he said.
Ms. Tull and Mr. Plumb both said an important factor in the rise of homeless families had been the "reform" of the welfare system. Destitution is the next stop for people who can't find jobs and can't get welfare.
One of the families at the Union Rescue Mission was featured this week in a front-page article in USA Today. William Kamstra, who earned $40,000 a year before losing his job, looks for work each day while his wife, Sue, and their three children spend the day at a library. They sleep at the mission.
"Homelessness in major cities is escalating," the article said, "as more laid-off workers already living paycheck to paycheck wind up on the streets or in shelters."
That story ran one day after a front-page Wall Street Journal article that spelled out how sweet just one of the Bush tax cuts has been for those in the upper brackets: "The federal tax cut, which slashed the tax rate on dividends and prompted many companies to increase their payouts, is proving to be a boon for some corporate executives who are reaping millions in after-tax gains."
Some people have reason to be optimistic. It's the best of times, or the worst of times. Depending on your perspective.

HEADLINE: Citing Upturn, Bush Rejects More Tax Cuts As Vote Nears 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: CRAWFORD, Tex., Aug. 13 

 BODY:
President Bush said today that the sluggish American economy was on the road to recovery and that he would not push for a new round of tax cuts as he heads into his re-election campaign this fall.
 "We are discussing a lot of things, and we believe that the tax relief plan we have in place is robust enough to encourage job growth," Mr. Bush told reporters at his 1,600-acre Texas ranch here, as he stood flanked by his top economic advisers. "If we change our opinion, we will let you know," he added. 
 Mr. Bush did not rule out tax cuts further down the road, but his advisers said that he wanted to determine first how the economy responds to the most recent tax cuts that went into effect last month.
"The president made it clear he wants to wait and see," N. Gregory Mankiw, the Council of Economic Advisers chairman, said. 
Mr. Bush also said that "America is a safe place for people to fly" and that the arrest of a British arms dealer accused of trying to sell a surface-to-air missile proved his point. The arms dealer was arrested on Tuesday in a hotel near Newark International Airport in an American-Russian sting operation. The missile, when armed, is capable of bringing down a commercial airliner.
"The fact that we were able to sting this guy is a pretty good example of what we're doing in order to protect the American people," Mr. Bush said. 
Mr. Bush made his comments after a two-hour meeting this morning with members of his economic team, including Treasury Secretary John W. Snow and Joshua Bolten, the new White House budget director. The meeting was held to show Mr. Bush as engaged and concerned about the economy at a time when the Democratic presidential candidates have intensified their criticism of Mr. Bush's economic stewardship and of the more than two million jobs lost since he became president.
In a 13-minute question-and-answer session with reporters in the hot morning sun at Prairie Chapel Ranch, Mr. Bush and his advisers offered no new initiatives or ideas to improve the economy. Instead, Mr. Bush repeated calls that Congress rein in spending, and said that the $350 billion in tax cuts enacted this year would soon lead to economic growth. 
"We believe it is more likely in the upcoming year that people are going to be able to find a job, and that's exactly what -- where we focused our policy," Mr. Bush said.
Democrats responded that Mr. Bush was fiscally irresponsible and that future generations would have to pay for the record $455 billion deficit that has built up on his watch.
"The debate has been much too polite," said George A. Akerlof, a Nobel Prize-winning economist who participated in a Democratic conference call with reporters on Tuesday to counter what was anticipated as Mr. Bush's good-news pronouncements today. "There might be some question whether Bush policies are advisable. The proper reference point is that the Bush policy is the worst policy in the last 200 years."
This summer, Mr. Bolten said that Mr. Bush was unlikely to call for any significant new tax-cutting initiatives beyond existing proposals not yet enacted by Congress, like a move to make the repeal of the tax on large estates permanent. But today was the first time that Mr. Bush himself ruled them out. Conservative Republicans are considered certain to revive calls for tax cuts between now and the election.
Those attending the meeting at the ranch today were Stephen Friedman, Mr. Bush's chief economic adviser; Andrew H. Card Jr., White House chief of staff; Harriet Miers, White House deputy chief of staff for policy; Donald L. Evans, Commerce secretary; Elaine L. Chao, Labor secretary; along with Mr. Bolten, Mr. Mankiw and Mr. Snow.
After leaving the ranch, the group fanned out to repeat the president's statements to White House reporters in the Crawford Middle School gym and to television correspondents set up with their cameras in front of bales of hay near the school's outdoor track. Mr. Snow indicated that he considered the event more than a photo opportunity and a determined job of White House salesmanship on the eve of the 2004 election campaign.
"It's important that the president talk to his economic advisers," Mr. Snow said. "He wants to be connected to the economy, he wants to let us know what's on his mind, he wants to spur us on to continue to work hard to do the things we need to do. I'll let you characterize it. I found it very worthwhile."
Mr. Friedman said after the meeting that the mood had been one of "guarded optimism" and that the group continued to believe that there would soon be the kind of economic growth that would lead to new jobs. 
The current rate of growth in the economy is 2.4 percent, and many economists say that in order to spur significant new job growth, the economy must expand at the rate of 4 percent. But Mr. Mankiw said today that he thought a growth rate of 3.1 percent was sufficient to add jobs, and predicted that the economy would be growing by 3.7 percent by the end of the year.
"The economy is like a ship, it doesn't turn on a dime," Mr. Mankiw said.

Snow after a news conference about the nation's economy at the president's ranch in Crawford, Tex. (Photo by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: NOMINEE FOR E.P.A. DEFENDS HIS JOB AS UTAH GOVERNOR 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY, Aug. 13 

 BODY:
Gov. Michael O. Leavitt today defended his environmental record in Utah against critics of his nomination to lead the Environmental Protection Agency, saying that under his stewardship, the quality of air, water and public lands in Utah had indisputably improved. As he described it, the success had been achieved by seeking collaborative solutions involving public as well as private interests.
 "There is no progress to be made at the extremes," Mr. Leavitt said in an interview in his office here, responding to accusations by environmental groups that he had been less than ideal as a steward of Utah's natural resources. "Progress can only be made in the productive center. There will always be those who feel their voice has not been heard, so there is a sense of disappointment. I understand that." 
 "But it's clear to me," he added in his first extended comments since he was chosen by President Bush on Monday, "that in collaboration you can create a mechanism for those voices to be heard even if they are not incorporated." 
Despite such amiable words, Governor Leavitt's record has drawn criticism from conservationists, who voice concerns about his warm ties with industry, especially mining, timber, oil and gas interests. Among the actions they cite are his secret negotiations with the Interior Department to eliminate protections for millions of acres of wilderness and his insistence on building a major highway through wetlands and fragile shore areas around the Great Salt Lake, a project stopped by the courts.
Others, however, have praised Governor Leavitt for keeping nuclear waste out of his state and for working against urban sprawl. 
Mr. Leavitt's remarks offered strong insight to the approach he would take as the nation's chief environmental officer. While he reviewed what he considers to be a long list of environmental successes in Utah, he declined to answer specific questions about his vision of national policy or his personal goals for the agency, citing what he expected to be contentious Senate confirmation hearings next month.
"My past speaks volumes about a willingness and desire to improve the way we conduct environmental discussions in the country," he said. "For now, I shouldn't say more than that."
Even as he mounted a proud defense, environmental groups in Utah and beyond were examining his 10-plus years as governor for examples of how they believe he has betrayed the environment in a state known for spectacular scenery and outdoor attractions. The list of complaints reflects the battles Mr. Leavitt has waged for years over issues from air quality to toxic waste to highway construction.
"I don't know of any environmentalist who thinks Governor Leavitt has done a particularly good job protecting the environment," Heidi McIntosh, conservation director of the Southern Utah Wilderness Alliance, said in a typical observation from leaders of state and national groups who contend that Mr. Leavitt has been too willing to consider the economic needs of developers in matters of environmental quality.
But citing his own list of successful projects that have led to cleaner air and water, Mr. Leavitt argued that the old ways of problem solving, pitting environmentalists against developers in a zero-sum death grip, was too simplistic and no longer feasible in a country where military and security needs have placed new demands on federal resources and nearly every environmental dispute ends up in costly lawsuits.
"The facts are indisputable," Mr. Leavitt said, offering examples of improvements. "The water here is more pure than when I became governor, and the air is cleaner, not just in Utah but throughout the West. And our lands are in better condition."
Mr. Leavitt's approach to environmental challenges is based on a principle of balanced interests that he calls "Enlibra," a word created from Latin meant to convey the need to consult all sides to achieve a collaborative result. It stresses eight basic principles, including national standards but local approaches, collaboration and market incentives rather than mandates.
The Enlibra approach, adopted by Western governors, also urges measuring the costs of environmental decisions against the benefits, which has allowed Mr. Leavitt to cast himself as a moderate in one of the most conservative states in the country. He pointed out -- proudly -- that he was once booed by right-wing members of his party at a Republican state convention for supporting a measure that would ban the carrying of guns in churches and schools.
Yet now, with Democrats promising to make his confirmation hearings a proxy fight against environmental policies of the Bush administration that began under Christie Whitman, Mr. Bush's first E.P.A. chief who resigned under pressure in May, Mr. Leavitt said he was bracing for new rounds of criticism by groups that contend he is far too conservative, and too friendly to business interests, to serve as the nation's top environmental steward.
"I am nothing but satisfied with my environmental record," Mr. Leavitt insisted. "I think the facts bear that out. If one's agenda is to portray otherwise, they will do so without benefit of the truth."
While the concept of Enlibra was devised -- and named -- in the late 1990's by him and a fellow governor, John A. Kitzhaber of Oregon, a Democrat, environmental groups say the approach is little more than a thinly veiled ploy that shifts more responsibilities to states, opening the decision making to polluters and despoilers and undermining hard-won federal protections.
Ms. McIntosh cited several examples, including Mr. Leavitt's support for protections of the San Rafael Swell, a dazzling geologic landscape of 600,000 acres in southeast Utah, that were much weaker than environmentalists had sought. She also criticized Mr. Leavitt for quietly settling a federal lawsuit that preserved the state's control over little-used roads on federal lands, keeping them available for commercial interests.
Other environmentalists took issue with Mr. Leavitt today for not doing enough to ensure cleaner air, allowing too much processing of toxic waste in the state and supporting construction of the highway over wetlands.
Denise Boggs, executive director of the Utah Environmental Congress, cited uranium mine tailings that are polluting American Fork Canyon, which, she said, pregnant women and children have been advised to avoid. "God forbid the state would spend any money to clean it up," she said. "Mike Leavitt has been in office for 11 years and has done nothing to alleviate these terrible environmental impacts."
Hearing a list of complaints, Mr. Leavitt shook his head and said many environmentalists in the state and beyond might be unaware of what he considered rousing successes. Among those he is most proud of, he said, is his work with a task force to clean the air over the Grand Canyon involving 13 states, 13 Indian tribes and three federal agencies during the Clinton administration.
Another that he cited was a recently completed effort to clean up a huge copper mine outside Salt Lake City that became the largest mining water reclamation project ever undertaken in the nation. 
He said the collaboration avoided the need to spend billions of Superfund dollars and completed the task in five years, half the time it might have taken if he had not brought environmentalists, government officials and mining officials to the table.
Mr. Leavitt said he fully expected his opponents to do whatever they could to derail his nomination. "I'm ready," he said. "We'll see what happens."

HEADLINE: Court Blocks City's Plans For Bond Sale 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER

 BODY:
The Pataki administration sued New York City yesterday and won a court order temporarily blocking a bond sale the city had planned for next week, escalating a battle between the governor and the mayor over a deal to save the city $500 million a year.
 With the filing of the lawsuit, the dispute between Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg went from a simmer to the boiling point. City officials angrily complained that state officials had given them no warning that the suit was coming, and that they had filed it in an Albany courtroom to keep the city from presenting its side of the case. The suit charges that part of the city's budget plan -- which was passed by the State Legislature over the governor's veto -- is unconstitutional. 
 Yesterday, Justice Thomas W. Keegan of State Supreme Court in Albany granted the state a temporary restraining order that keeps the city from moving forward with the deal until Aug. 25. The city had planned to sell $556 million worth of bonds next week.
The plan in dispute, which the Legislature offered the city in place of its request for a commuter tax, would allow the city to refinance debt left over from the fiscal crisis of the 1970's. It would free the city of $500 million in annual payments to bondholders by allowing it to stretch out the remaining five years of debt for 30 years. The state agreed to pay back the new long-term loan for the city in annual installments of $170 million. 
Governor Pataki, State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi and budget watchdogs have condemned the deal, arguing that it is expensive and bad fiscal policy, and likening it to taking out a new mortgage to pay for last year's groceries. But city officials said they needed help closing a $3.8 billion deficit once the state rejected the commuter tax.
Yesterday, the Local Government Assistance Corporation, the state authority directed to make the annual payments, which is controlled by a board made up of two Pataki appointees and Mr. Hevesi, filed suit to keep the city from moving ahead.
The lawsuit, which reads in places like the news releases that the state has put out in recent days, calls the plan "a public policy disaster."
"If allowed to stand, it would unjustifiably burden state taxpayers for generations to come with $5.1 billion in obligations," the lawsuit says. "It is also unconstitutional."
Mark Page, the city's budget director, countered in a statement that the plan was legal and constitutional, and he noted that New York State had often resorted to the very kind of long-term borrowing to pay operating costs that it was now objecting to.
"It is nothing less than hypocritical to conveniently object to this structure when it benefits the people of New York City, and we will not stand for it," Mr. Page said.
But Pataki administration officials countered that existing state debt was not analogous to the deal the city was trying to move ahead with, which seeks to stretch out debt issued in the 1970's until the 2030's.
The lawsuit capped a week of steadily escalating tensions between the governor, who is on vacation at his upstate farm on Lake Champlain, and the mayor, who had believed that the city's severe budget crisis this year was behind him and that smoother fiscal times were ahead.
On Aug. 6, the board of the Local Government Assistance Corporation, which gets its money from the state sales tax, voted not to proceed with the plan to pay the city $170 million a year even though a state law directed it to.
Mayor Bloomberg threatened legal action and ordered the city to proceed with the bond sale. The governor made a counterproposal, offering to spread out the debt for 10 years instead of 30. But the mayor rejected the offer, saying it did not provide the city with the same amount of money as the Legislature's plan and required the city to go back to Albany every year and request a reallocation of funds, something city officials deemed too risky.
On Tuesday, in defiance of the governor, city officials announced that they were forging ahead with their plan. They said they would sue the state corporation to try to compel it to comply with the state law in a few days, and sell the bonds next week.
The Pataki administration moved to try to scare buyers away from the bonds. A senior Pataki official, speaking on the condition of anonymity, was quoted as describing a small part of the bond issue as "junk bonds."
Then, before the city could file suit, the state beat it to the punch, getting the court order yesterday.
The state's action appeared to have caught the Bloomberg administration by surprise. 
Today, the city plans to go to court to try to get the court order lifted and have the case transferred to New York City. 
Pataki and Bloomberg administration officials accused each other of negotiating in bad faith. Mr. Page's statement said the state obtained the court order "at the very moment we were continuing good-faith negotiations with the state over possible alternatives" and added, "This action has brought negotiations to a halt."
A senior Pataki official countered: "They're the ones that broke down the negotiations. We're negotiating, and they released a statement announcing that they were going to sell the bonds at a certain time and sue on or around a date."
Throughout the battle, Mayor Bloomberg has carefully avoided criticizing Governor Pataki by name. Even Mr. Page's statement complains that "a nonrepresentative state agency is standing in the way of our recovery." 
He omitted noting that the governor controls the agency, and that the only two plaintiffs mentioned by name are his appointees: Carole E. Stone, his budget director, and Maryanne Gridley, a former first deputy secretary to the governor who is now the executive director of the State Dormitory Authority. 
But Gifford Miller, the City Council speaker, who unlike Mr. Pataki and Mr. Bloomberg is a Democrat, seized on the opportunity to attack the governor as someone "trying to destroy the city's finances."
After Mr. Miller criticized the governor for hiring a "white shoe" law firm at public expense -- the suit was filed by Kornstein Veisz Wexler & Pollard -- a reporter noted that Mr. Miller had hired a white-shoe firm this year to argue his case to change the city's term limits law so he could stay in office longer.
"But that was for justice," Mr. Miller said. "And I never checked their shoes."

HEADLINE: THE CALIFORNIA RECALL: THE BALLOT; 
Race Officially On: 135 Are Candidates In California Recall

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 13 

 BODY:
The actor Arnold Schwarzenegger was officially certified today to run in the Oct. 7 recall election on Gov. Gray Davis of California. But so were 134 other people, creating what will be the most congested ballot in state history and setting the stage for an election night count that could drag on for weeks.
 Even without legal challenges, which many people consider likely, state officials said it could take as long as 39 days after the vote to certify the results. The ballot will be longer than the one in 1914, when 48 ballot measures were put to the vote, state records show. 
 "Our next task is to turn our attention to the mechanics of Oct. 7," Secretary of State Kevin Shelley said in releasing the certified list of candidates, "so that we can work on the details of a smooth Election Day operation."
State officials did not draw a distinction between Mr. Schwarzenegger and the others on the official list, but they were possibly the only ones in California who did not. Mr. Schwarzenegger, who has thoroughly dominated the early hustings, made another splash today when his campaign announced the addition of Warren E. Buffet, the billionaire investor.
"He is the greatest investor ever, my mentor, and my hero," Mr. Schwarzenegger said in a statement.
Even with respected figures like Peter V. Ueberroth, the former baseball commissioner, and an entertaining assortment of porn stars, comedians and general malcontents in the mix, Mr. Schwarzenegger easily finishes at the top of most public opinion surveys.
A CNN/USA Today/Gallup poll conducted over the weekend showed that 48 percent of probable voters said there was a good chance or a very good chance they would vote for Mr. Schwarzenegger, a Republican. 
"I am not necessarily certain that anyone can describe this in a fashion that sounds reasonable," said John M. Feliz, the campaign director for a fellow Republican, State Senator Tom McClintock, who is among the 134 other certified candidates.
"It is not a new star being born," Mr. Feliz said of the Schwarzenegger candidacy, "it is a mass that has its own gravity and its own orbits." 
On a day when he did not make a public appearance, Mr. Schwarzenegger still dominated the recall scene when his campaign announced that Mr. Buffett would be its senior financial and economic adviser.
Strategists for Mr. Schwarzenegger predicted the appointment would blunt criticism from both Democrats and conservative Republicans that the actor was not capable of running a state with a $99-billion budget and an economy bigger than the economies of all but a handful of countries.
The naming of Mr. Buffett, who will be unpaid, came a day after the Schwarzenegger campaign announced that it had hired three top aides to former Gov. Pete Wilson, including Bob White, a political fixture in Sacramento who served as Mr. Wilson's chief of staff. Mr. Wilson, a Republican, is a chairman of the Schwarzenegger campaign. 
"Warren Buffett is hot, don't you think?" said George Gorton, a political strategist to Mr. Schwarzenegger. "It shows the type of people Arnold is going to attract to participate in the recovery of California."
In the statement, Mr. Schwarzenegger called Mr. Buffett "a giant in the world of finance," saying, "he will be a huge help to me as we work to strengthen California's economy."
Other candidates, such as Mr. McClintock, the columnist Arianna Huffington and Peter Camejo, a Green Party candidate backed by Ralph Nader, kept to their campaign schedules today, but they were barely audible over the Arnold rumble.
That is not to say Mr. Davis and the others have given up. 
As the final certified list of 135 was being compiled today, an array of traditionally Democratic groups, calling themselves Stand for California, announced an eight-week campaign to urge a vote against the recall. The coalition will not take a position on the replacement candidates.
The recall ballot has two parts. First voters will be asked whether Mr. Davis should be recalled; second, they will be asked to choose a successor from the list of 135 should he lose the first vote.
"We are together on only one issue," said Art Pulaski, executive secretary-treasurer of the California Labor Federation, "and that is the question of opposing the recall."
The Stand for California coalition includes groups like the California Labor Federation, the California Federation of Teachers, the Sierra Club of California and Planned Parenthood
"We've discovered through our polling that 78 percent of Democratic voters respond favorably to an anti-recall message that comes from community leaders like we have in this coalition," Mr. Pulaski said. 
Officials from the groups estimated their combined membership was about 5.5 million people in California. Though they will not be campaigning for Mr. Davis, their messages will emphasize the peril in removing him from office, they said.
"With ongoing threats to choice at the federal level, now is not the time to reject a pro-choice administration in California," said Steve Smith of Planned Parenthood. 
The labor federation said it alone was prepared to spend as much as $2.5 million on the effort.
State campaign finance records showed several candidates were busy raising money for an election that strategists from both parties predict will involve tens of millions of dollars in expenditures, regardless of the victor.
The cost to the state and 58 counties of holding the election, while still not determined, could run as high as $66 million, according to the secretary of state's office.
Mr. McClintock's campaign reported $33,000 in donations today, bringing his total for August to $267,500. Bill Simon Jr., the Republican who lost to Mr. Davis last November, reported $47,500, bringing his total for the month to $212,504.
Lt. Gov. Cruz M. Bustamante, the choice of Democratic Party officials should Mr. Davis lose, reported $189,250 so far in August. Mr. Ueberroth, a Republican running a nonpartisan campaign, reported $103,000, and Ms. Huffington $105,500.
But Mr. Schwarzenegger even managed to steal the money show.
Most of today, the Schwarzenegger campaign statement showed no contributions in August. But late in the afternoon, that changed when Mr. Schwarzenegger donated $1 million to himself.

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING; 
Powerful Racing Association Gets New Scrutiny in Albany

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. with JOE DRAPE

DATELINE: ALBANY, Aug. 13 

 BODY:
When the New York Racing Association was founded in 1955, the goal was to consolidate the state's dilapidated racetracks under a charitable corporation that would devote its gambling profits to the state and pay for everything from schools to hospitals.
 In recent years, however, the racing association has made very little or no profit, and the benefit to the state, mostly in the form of taxes on bets and unclaimed winnings, has dwindled to $10.8 million last year from a peak of $45.3 million in 1987, state budget officials say. 
 Still, in the last six years, the racing association managed to persuade the Legislature and the governor to extend its unique franchise to operate New York's top tracks (Saratoga Race Course, Belmont Park and Aqueduct), each time without competitive bidding. Lawmakers also cut the tax rate on each bet at the track to 1.6 percent in 2001, from 5 percent in 1994, to provide more money for purses and improving the tracks. 
 The racing association argues that the rate cut, and not mismanagement, is the reason its contribution to the state treasury has dropped. Now the association has found itself the center of a growing political fight in Albany. State Attorney General Eliot Spitzer has said the tracks are rife with corruption, while State Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi has suggested in a draft audit that the association is poorly managed. Federal prosecutors are also investigating allegations that its management allowed systematic tax evasion by employees.
 Yet Gov. George E. Pataki and leaders of the Senate and Assembly have been reluctant to criticize the association, in part because the state is depending on revenue from the installation of video lottery terminals at Aqueduct.
 There is another factor. The members of the association's board of trustees, which includes many of the state's most powerful business executives, along with other thoroughbred owners, are politically powerful individuals who have given hundreds of thousands of dollars to various political campaigns. The governor and the two legislative leaders, Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver and Senate Majority Leader Joseph L. Bruno, have all benefited from their largess.
 Mr. Pataki and Senator Bruno both have fund-raisers planned in Saratoga next week that many in the horse racing set are likely to attend, aides said. Just last week, Mr. Silver's campaign committee held a fund-raising event at the Saratoga home of Barry K. Schwartz, chairman of the racing association.
 "They are a terrifically powerful group because of who they are," said Mario M. Cuomo, who butted heads with the association several times during his time as governor. "There has been a kind of reluctance to take them on over the years."
 But Mr. Spitzer and Mr. Hevesi, the two Democrats holding statewide office, have not been shy about criticizing the racing association. In a draft audit not yet officially released, Mr. Hevesi lambastes the association as having unsound budgeting practices and spending more than it takes in. Mr. Hevesi questioned, for instance, why the racing association had provided costly pension benefits to former top executives when its expenses outpaced its revenue for three out of the five years from 1997 to 2001.
 Mr. Spitzer has accused the track managers of cultivating a "culture of criminality" and of running "an organization that is, at best, indifferent to corruption." In a scathing report in June, he laid out a variety of scams that parimutuel clerks have used to fleece bettors. He has called for the management of the tracks to be replaced.
 Federal prosecutors, meanwhile, are investigating the association to determine if top managers engaged in a conspiracy to commit tax fraud. The inquiry stems from the convictions of 16 betting clerks for cheating on their taxes and centers on whether the racing association could have prevented that.
 Racing officials have said privately that the review of their finances and operations has become highly politicized because their franchise to run the tracks will be automatically extended to 2013 if the video lottery terminals are installed and running at Aqueduct by March 2004, under budget legislation passed this year. Some competing racing and gaming interests would like to see the franchise put out to bid, they say.
 The video-lottery terminals, which are similar to slot machines, are projected to generate about $400 million for education in their first year, the racing association estimates. They are important to horse owners and breeders, too, because a portion of the revenue will go toward purses and the State Breeding and Development Fund.
 As Mr. Spitzer has publicly flogged the tracks' management, the racing association has pushed back with a public relations campaign. Last week, it announced it was suspending the construction of a gaming building at Aqueduct that was to house the new video lottery terminals, saying its partner in the venture, MGM Mirage, said it could not go forward with the deal if the racing association were indicted.
 The trustees also maintain they have taken steps to tighten controls, appointing a committee, headed by Stuart Subotnick, the executive vice president of Metromedia, to look into the allegations of corruption and mismanagement.
 But some fiscal experts say the association lacks an incentive to make a profit, since all its profits, if it makes any, go to the state. 
 "Whether N.Y.R.A. performs well or poorly in different regards, there is no good mechanism for holding it accountable," said Edmund J. McMahon, a fiscal analyst with the Manhattan Institute, a think tank that promotes economic choice and individual responsibility. "This is because the franchise has been treated as virtually permanent, with no regular, systematicreview."
 Racing officials and lawmakers say the argument that they produce too little revenue for the state is both inaccurate and misses a larger point. Beyond the $10.8 million of taxes on bets and unclaimed winnings contributed to the state in 2002, the racing association paid nearly $18 million in real estate taxes and contributed $3.4 million to the state breeding fund.
 "They end up producing 40,000 jobs, people who work and pay taxes and buy goods and services," Senator Bruno said.
 In addition, racing officials say fewer people are attending races and an increasing number of people are betting off track, driving down parimutuel tax collections.
 One unanswered question is whether a for-profit racetrack company could operate under the franchise's current restrictions. The Magna Entertainment Corporation, a publicly traded company that owns, operates and manages 15 racetracks, has said it was interested in bidding on the New York tracks. Yesterday, however, a spokesman declined to comment about how Magna would generate revenue for both the state and its shareholders.
 Michael Shanley, vice president of the New York Thoroughbred Horseman's Association, which represents owners and trainers, says he does not believe it is possible.
 "We believe the only structure that works is a not-for-profit where all the money stays within the system or goes to the State of New York," Mr. Shanley said. "With any public corporation, they exist for the benefit for their shareholders, not the horsemen and not the State of New York."

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE STING; 
F.B.I. Asserts Dealer Was Aware Airliner Would Be Missile Target

BYLINE:  By DAVID JOHNSTON and PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13 

 BODY:
The clandestine meeting between the arms dealer and the prospective buyer of the surface-to-air missile, the government says, took place at a hotel with a commanding view of the runways at Newark International Airport on Sept. 17, 2002, less than a week after the first anniversary of the September 2001 hijackings.
 The two watched aircraft take off and land at the nearby airfield, according to an F.B.I. affidavit unsealed today in federal court in Newark. The arms dealer, Hemant Lakhani, a Briton born in India, told the buyer, who was in reality an F.B.I. informant, that he was aware that the shoulder-fired Russian-made missile would be used in an attack against a commercial airliner in the United States, the affidavit says. 
 Mr. Lakhani also said, according to the affidavit, that he understood the economic harm such an attack would cause the United States. "Make one explosion . . . to shake the economy," he is quoted as telling the buyer, described in the affidavit as "a cooperating witness." 
The conversation was one of more than 150 secretly recorded by investigators during an 18-month inquiry that led on Tuesday to Mr. Lakhani's arrest in Newark on charges of trying to sell such a missile to American agents. The missile, one of dozens that the government says Mr. Lakhani was to provide, had in fact been made inoperable by the agents' Russian counterparts in a sting operation, however, and no terrorists were ever actually involved in the plot.
In an earlier meeting in New Jersey, on Jan. 17, 2002, Mr. Lakhani and the buyer discussed Osama bin Laden. According to the affidavit, Mr. Lakhani said Mr. bin Laden had "straightened them out" and had done "a good thing."
At yet another New Jersey meeting, on April 25, 2002, when the buyer told Mr. Lakhani that the missile was intended for a "plane" and would "hit the American people over here," Mr. Lakhani replied that "the Americans are bastards," the affidavit says.
Today Mr. Lakhani, who is 68 years old and lives in North London, was charged in a federal complaint with trying to provide material support to terrorists and trying to sell arms without a license.
Two other men arrested on Tuesday were also identified today. Prosecutors said one was Yehuda Abraham, a 76-year-old jeweler from New York. The other was Moinuddeen Ahmed Hameed, a 38-year-old citizen of India who, the government said, arrived in the New York area on Tuesday from Malaysia.
Court documents said Mr. Lakhani had enlisted Mr. Abraham and Mr. Hameed to help manage the financial arrangements for the arms deal. Both were charged with conspiring to operate an unlicensed money-transmitting business, but neither with any terrorism-related offenses.
All three men appeared in federal court today, Mr. Lakhani and Mr. Hameed in Newark, Mr. Abraham in Manhattan.
Neither Mr. Lakhani nor Mr. Hameed addressed the court at the Newark hearing. Both men were handcuffed, their hands in front of them and chains around their waists.
Mr. Lakhani wore a blue short-sleeve shirt and dark pants. Shortly before the 15-minute hearing began, he was seen animatedly conferring with his lawyer, Donald J. McCauley, a federal public defender who later declined to comment on the case.
After the hearing, Christopher J. Christie, the United States attorney in Newark, told reporters that Mr. Lakhani was a "significant arms dealer" who had promised to deliver missiles "specifically for the purpose of shooting an American commercial airliner out of the sky."
"There is no question that Mr. Lakhani was someone who was sympathetic to the beliefs of the terrorists who were trying to do damage to this country," Mr. Christie said.
American officials said today that it was Russian investigators who first came across Mr. Lakhani, when, they said, he sought suppliers for illegal arms among Russian crime groups. The case was the first undercover terrorism investigation that the United States and Russia worked together, and Larry Mefford, chief of counterintelligence and counterterrorism at the F.B.I., said, "This was an unprecedented example of joint cooperation, and we look forward to building on this success."
In the affidavit unsealed today, the authorities described how American investigators had tracked Mr. Lakhani's activities through the cooperating witness, who, it said, convinced Mr. Lakhani that he was a shadowy middleman for Somali terrorists affiliated with Al Qaeda. That witness is expected to testify when the case goes to trial, but he was not identified in court documents released today.
In addition, the affidavit details how Russian security officers operating under cover fooled Mr. Lakhani into believing that they were black-market suppliers who had sold him a fully functional weapon, which, already made inoperable, was transported by ship from St. Petersburg to the Port of Baltimore and seized by federal agents on Tuesday.
The price for that first missile was $85,000, to be paid in $100 bills, with a $30,000 down payment, the authorities said. But in all, they said, Mr. Lakhani had agreed to provide the buyer 50 missiles at a total price of $5 million. American officials said today that the case was still being investigated in Russia, apparently because of the possibility that Mr. Lakhani might have been close to tapping into an arms pipeline.
As the case shifted to the courts, the debate about the extent of commercial aircraft's vulnerability to missile attack continued today. President Bush said at his Texas ranch that American airliners and airports were safe. "The fact that we were able to sting this guy is a pretty good example of what we're doing in order to protect the American people," Mr. Bush said.
"Today," he added, "the airports are much more secure than they were prior to Sept. 11. America is a safe place for people to fly, because we are working hard to make sure that our homeland security is strong."
But overseas there was new evidence of a threat posed to passenger planes by terrorists. British Airways announced that it had suspended all flights to Saudi Arabia through Sunday because of what the airline described as "heightened security concerns in the region." 
Law enforcement officials in the United States, Britain and Saudi Arabia said the airline was responding to the recent arrest of several Muslim militants in Saudi Arabia who were reported to have been plotting to attack a British Airways plane as it took off or landed at the international airport in Riyadh, the Saudi capital, or Jeddah.
The arrests in the United States this week and the reports of further terrorist threats in Saudi Arabia appeared to bring new pressure on the Bush administration to respond to the specter of shoulder-fired missiles.
The House's leading Republican on aviation security, Representative John L. Mica of Florida, said in an interview that it was clear that the government would need to pay to install antimissile devices on at least some passenger planes, and that installation should begin with larger jets flying to international destinations where terrorism is a special concern.
"These terrorists are not interested in shooting down a small Cessna," Mr. Mica said. "You want to cover your larger passenger aircraft. They want to make a splash, whether it's in Kenya, where they've tried before, or in Saudi Arabia or someplace else."
Though he praised the Bush administration for its early efforts to study the problem, Mr. Mica suggested that the government might want to speed up the research and the deployment of antimissile equipment, like flares or electronic jamming devices. "I think we can do this on an expedited basis," he said.
While American officials said Mr. Lakhani was an established arms dealer, his neighbors in North London described him today as a quiet businessman and said they had no knowledge that he might have been involved in arms trading.
The affidavit portrays him much differently. In one conversation in October 2002, it says, Mr. Lakhani told the cooperating witness that although it was not an "easy job" to obtain the missiles, he could get "the merchandise" and that it would be "high-class stuff."
The document also suggests that Mr. Lakhani was aware of the dangers of illegal arms trading, which, it said, he described as more risky since the Sept. 11 attacks. Advising the cooperating witness against placing money directly into Mr. Lakhani's bank account, he said, according to the affidavit: "This business is getting so dangerous. No one has the guts to do it."
"I won't do anything," he added, "if it's risky."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hemant Lakhani is accused of offering a shoulder-fired missile to an F.B.I. informant. He was driven by agents yesterday to court in Newark, where he was charged with trying to provide support to terrorists. (Photo by John O'Boyle/The Star-Ledger, via Reuters)(pg. A16)
