 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk; Pg. 30

LENGTH: 4672 words

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by Times critics of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. At many museums children under 12 and museum members are admitted free. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free unless noted. * denotes a highly recommended show. 

Museums

* "THE AMERICAN EFFECT: GLOBAL PERSPECTIVES ON THE UNITED STATES, 1990-2003," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street (212) 570-3676 (through Oct. 12). Exploring ways that artists throughout the world react to the United States as a superpower, this show of documentary films, videos, installations, photographs, paintings and objects by 47 artists and filmmakers and three collaborative groups runs from sunny side up to deep despair. There are reflections on America's military might, its industrial clout, its treatment of minorities, its consumerism, its justice system, its marketing strategies, its religious evangelism, its celebrity worship and its interference with other governments. On the other hand there are more positive expressions of admiration for the freedoms, the opportunities and the material achievements of a country unfettered by ancient traditions. A wacky installation by a French artist, Gilles Barbier, in the form of life-size figures, offers a wry take on the United States through its aging comic book heroes, viewed in the setting of a nursing home and in the last stages of decrepitude. The show has its weak spots but overall is provocative and visually compelling. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $9.50, students and 62+ (Grace Glueck).

"ANSEL ADAMS AT 100," Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through Nov. 3). This exhibition of 113 of Adams's photographs, in celebration of the 100th anniversary of his birth, has been traveling around the world for two years. In these warehouse galleries it has a strangely random and homely feel. The photographs look small and lost. Maybe it's the setting. Maybe it's because the show, organized roughly thematically -- austere peaks, plants, peaks with plants, grand vistas, rocks -- doesn't have a clearly focused concept. Or maybe it's because the curator wanted to tamp down Adams's bombast and replace it with something quieter, smaller and subtler. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays to 7:45 p.m. Admission: $12; $8.50 for students and 65+ (Sarah Boxer).

* MAX BECKMANN, Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through Sept. 29). Like Beckmann, this retrospective of that German genius is dense, frequently revelatory and exhausting: -- all that heavy-handed symbolism and claustrophobia. Beckmann can seem like a truculent master, glaring balefully at us from his self-portraits, disappointed by our moral turpitude. It is easy to get bogged down in the miasma of his obscure allusions. But he also puts brush to canvas with surprising tenderness. Color is luxurious, not garish. The humor is sly and black. Finally, he is unavoidably compelling. Hours and admission: See above. (Michael Kimmelman).

* "BLACK PRESIDENT: THE ART AND LEGACY OF FELA ANIKULAPO-KUTI," New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Houston Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Sept. 28). The Nigerian composer, musician and activist Fela Kuti (1938-1997) invented the musical style called Afrobeat, relentlessly assailed political corruption and repression in Africa and beyond through his records and performances, and led a scandalous private life very publicly. This taut, vivacious exhibition is less about the man himself than about how 30 contemporary artists, most of them African or African-American, respond to his blazing, goading lodestar presence. Their reactions range from celebratory to critical, and few are simple, but his vision of a rejuvenated Africa still shines bright. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m.; Thursdays, to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3, students, artists and 65+ (Holland Cotter).

"ART CHANTRY: GREATEST HITS, VOL. 1," P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-24 Jackson Avenue, Long Island City, (718) 784-2084 (through Aug. 31). The argument against graphic design as an art form receives its latest drubbing in this revelatory survey, organized by Robert Nikas and presenting more than 300 posters and album covers by Mr. Chantry, the Seattle-based designer and art director. Dating from the late 1970's to the present, these works capture much of the vitality of the city's underground music and theater scene while defining a maverick sensibility whose inventive low-tech production values and polymorphous recycling of images adds a chapter of its own to the history of appropriation art. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2 for students and 62+ (Roberta Smith).

"CUBA ON THE VERGE: AN ISLAND IN TRANSITION," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000 (through Aug. 31). Is it possible for anyone to photograph Cuba without some sort of romance creeping in? The concept behind this show of Cuban, Cuban-American and American photographers was to eschew "cliched images of vintage American cars and other remnants of a prerevolutionary era" and instead to "convey Cuba present," as the show's guest curator, Terry McCoy, writes in the catalog. But some of the photographs suggest that even as Cuba sinks deeper into poverty, ruin and prostitution, the romance of faded beauty and glamorous revolution won't go away. The most refreshing shots are those in which subjects confront the camera and the fantasy. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $7, students and 62+ (Boxer).

"SALVADOR DALI: DREAM OF VENUS," Queens Museum of Art, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, (718) 592-9700 (through Sept. 7). While images of the 1939 New York World's Fair in Queens remain ingrained in the American collective memory, one attraction, relegated to the "Amusement Zone," was largely forgotten until now: Dali's "Dream of Venus," a tacky Surrealist fun house with live, semi-nude women. This exhibition consists mainly of photographs that document the project from start to finish. Featuring the handsome, charismatic artist; his enigmatic wife, Gala; and lots of voluptuous, unclothed models, this show and its catalog tell a fascinating tale of idealism, opportunism, provocation and censorship. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 1 to 8 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for students and 55+ (Ken Johnson).

"DRAWN HOME: FRITZ VOGT'S RURAL AMERICA," American Folk Art Museum, 45 West 53rd Street, Manhattan, (212) 265-1040 (through Sept. 21). During the last decade of the 19th-century Vogt, a German immigrant, supported himself by making portraits of homes in upstate New York. A homeless itinerant who preferred to sleep in his patrons' barns, Vogt made wonderfully lucid, formally ingenious drawings of farms with multiple outbuildings and of elaborately decorated Victorian showpieces with manicured grounds. The 26 drawings here tap into an American ethos that elevated domestic prosperity to something like a national religion. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Admission: $9; $7, students and 62+ (Johnson).

* "DREAMING IN PICTURES: THE PHOTOGRAPHY OF LEWIS CARROLL," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 857-0000 (through Aug. 31). A photograph is at least as much a looking glass as it is a window. We see in it our own reflections and obsessions. A post-Freudian world has inevitably come to see C. L. Dodgson's photographs through the looking glass of his alter ego, Lewis Carroll. This provocative show tries to put Dodgson's pictures back in their context, to stress that we have lost touch with Victorian conventions, which Dodgson largely obeyed when he photographed little girls. Childhood to Victorians represented, as the show's curator puts it, an "alternate reality, a metaphysical state of preknowledge." Dodgson, he adds "could pose his charges in adult roles, give them guns, daggers and exotic costumes, even portray them as odalisques and half-dressed waifs, because he and most of his audience believed so emphatically in their total insulation from the implications of such postures." These presentations do not so much underscore the latent sexuality of the child (as we post-Freudians would have it) as they do an obvious lack of it." Hours and admission: See above (Kimmelman).

* "FROM EXPRESSIONISM TO THE BAUHAUS: HIGHLIGHTS FROM THE MUSEUM OF MODERN ART," Neue Galerie, 1048 Fifth Avenue, at 86th Street, (212) 628-6200 (through Sept. 15). Borrowed from the Museum of Modern Art, this economical, powerfully resonant exhibition of German Modernist artworks from the first third of the 20th century includes Expressionist paintings by Ludwig Kirchner, Otto Mueller and Emil Nolde; mordantly satiric New Realist paintings by George Grosz and Otto Dix; and sumptuously elegant utilitarian objects by Marcel Breuer and Marianne Brandt. Hours: Fridays, 11 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, Sundays and Mondays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $10; $7 for students and 65+ (Johnson).

"FROM PICASSO TO POLLOCK: CLASSICS OF MODERN ART," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Sept. 28). This selective anthology of perennial in-house favorites in a major museum has much to be said for it. The bait is irresistible, the promised classics turn up here and there, and both the young and the not-so-young have a fine time on the ramps. In addition to fine examples by Kandinsky, Picasso, Leger, Chagall, Kokoschka and Malevich, there is an enormous piece in ceramic tiles by Joan Miro. Begun in 1965 and finished in 1967, it is largely in black and white, but every touch of color sings out. Hours: Saturdays through Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $9 for students and 65+ (John Russell).

* "HENDRICK GOLTZIUS, DUTCH MASTER (1558-1617): DRAWINGS, PRINTS AND PAINTINGS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sept. 7). Goltzius (1558-1617) was one of the hottest of hotshot Dutch artists. He was particularly celebrated for his engravings, many of them mythological tableaus of pumped-up gods and pinup goddesses, rendered in the Mannerist way with flabbergasting elan. But he was also one of the great draftsmen of his age -- his landscape drawings prefigure Rembrandt and Ruisdael -- and became a virtuosic painter whose primary subject was bare human flesh: its texture, its color, its chemistry. To some eyes he remains strictly a period artist; to others he connects to the present in interesting ways. The Met show offers the raw materials for both reactions. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and 65+ (Cotter).

* "LANDSCAPE OF MEMORY: THE ART OF MU XIN," Asia Society and Museum, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street, (212) 288-6400 (through Sept. 7.) The artist and writer Mu Xin, born into a wealthy aristocratic family in China, received a classical scholar's education and early exposure to Western culture. Targeted as a dissident during the Cultural Revolution, he was held in solitary confinement for 18 months, and he secretly wrote a series of first-person meditations now called "Prison Notes," which he carried out of jail sewn in his clothes. Under house arrest several years later, he executed a remarkable series of small landscape paintings in which traditional Chinese themes meet Leonardo da Vinci. The paintings and some of "Prison Notes" are brought together in this lean, penumbral exhibition, organized by the Yale University Art Gallery and the David and Alfred Smart Museum of Art at the University of Chicago. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays to 9 p.m. Admission: $7; $5, students and 65+ (Cotter).

"LEGENDS OF OUR TIMES: NATIVE RANCHING AND RODEO LIFE ON THE PLAINS AND THE PLATEAU," National Museum of the American Indian, George Gustav Heye Center, 1 Bowling Green, Lower Manhattan, (212) 514-3700 (through March 7). This lively account of man, woman and horse among the native people in Western reaches of the United States and Canada proves that a cowboy can be an Indian, and vice versa. The show depicts native peoples not as objects of exploitation by the white man but as ranchers, cowboys, entertainers and rodeo performers. It displays more than 700 objects -- saddles, bead and quill works, paintings, photographs, blankets, clothing, horse gear, hunting implements, roundup equipment, headdresses and other ceremonial garb -- from the 18th century to now. At least half of this huge show provides an engaging and comprehensive account of rodeo, but nonrodeo fans will probably have more fun with the bedazzlement of objects depicting the more traditional side of American Indian life. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdaysuntil 8 p.m. Free (Glueck).

"USDESIGN 1975-2000," Museum of Arts & Design, 40 West 53rd Street, (212) 956-3535 (through Nov. 2). This survey of objects designed during the 20th century's last quarter is disappointing, partly because few of the products on view are very interesting to look at and partly because it sheds so little light on a field that has expanded in a mind-boggling variety of directions in recent years. Focused mainly on consumer goods like chairs, clocks, lamps, teapots, telephones, sneakers, ski boots, roller blades, sunglasses and computers, it has the feel of an outmoded department store. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Thursdays to 8 p.m. Admission: $8; $5 for students and 65+ (Johnson).

"WILLEM VAN TETRODE: BRONZE SCULPTURES OF THE RENAISSANCE," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through Sept. 7). This exhibition introduces a neglected Dutch artist who flourished amid the cultural ferment of 16th-century Italy, when the rediscoveries of monumental Classical marbles helped fuel a passion for mythological themes, the rise of private collecting and a new sense of physical and emotional drama in sculpture. Prodigiously talented, van Tetrode navigated his own path between Classicism and Mannerism with beautifully detailed bronzes, most notably a splendidly muscled and bearded Hercules dispatching various labors with violent panache. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $12; $5 for students; $8 for 62+ (Smith).

"ANDY WARHOL: SCREEN TESTS," Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through Sept. 1). From 1964 to 1966, Warhol shot 500 short, silent, black-and-white films of artists, musicians, actors, writers, filmmakers, models, curators, celebrities and hangers-on at the Factory. The Modern has restored 277 of these screen tests, representing about 34 hours of watching time, and now 28 of the films are being shown continuously on six screens. The subjects include Baby Jane Holzer, Salvador Dali, James Rosenquist, Dennis Hopper, Cass Elliott and Susan Sontag -- but they are of variable interest. By shooting the films at one speed and playing them more slowly, Warhol exposed the mechanics of discomposure and charisma. Some people are fascinating as they lose charisma; others are not. It has nothing to do with handsomeness, histrionics, coolness, slimness, trying or giving up. The typology of charisma is as elusive as the typology of criminality. Hours and admission: See above (Boxer).

Galleries: Uptown

TED FAIERS, "Paintings From the 1950's," Richard York, 21 East 65th Street, (212) 772-9155 (through Aug. 29). Indian Space painting was a mid-20th-century American movement that mixed Cubist abstraction with Native American-style patterns and pictographs. Faiers's exercises in that now dimly remembered style have, at best, an appealing jazziness and chromatic radiance. There is something ultimately silly, though, about the idea of the sophisticated urbanite getting in touch with his inner shaman (Johnson).

TONY FOSTER, "Watermarks," James Graham & Sons, 1014 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, (212) 535-5767 (through Aug. 23). Mr. Foster is yet another Englishman whose art revolves around travel. Finding his way from South American tropical forests to glaciers in Greenland, he neatly documents what he sees in watercolor; he then adds found objects like bones, shells, vials of water, rocks and feathers. The art in the gallery is not as adventurous as the artist himself seems to be (Johnson).

Galleries: 57th Street

"H2O," Danese, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 223-2227 (through Aug. 22). For obvious reasons a lot of summer group shows take water as a theme, this one more directly and more effectively than most. Works by more than 30 artists include Sally Mann's mysterious photograph of three naked, nubile girls urinating; a piece of magic illusionism by Amy Jenkins that has a bathing woman video-projected into a miniature bathtub; Laura Aguilar's portrait of her own mountainously corpulent self lying naked next to a small rock pool; and a gigantically enlarged sweat gland reproduced in rubber by Jeanne Silverthorne (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

"FROM GASLIGHTS TO TELEVISION," Susan Teller, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 941-7335 (through Aug. 28). Typewriters, stoves, refrigerators, clocks, pumps, sewing machines, telephones, fans, ice cream makers, irons and other labor-saving devices turn up in this surprising show about appliances in 20th-century American domestic life. From John Sloan's sexy etching of a woman turning off the light before joining her lover in bed to Louise Leech's painting of her teenage daughters watching the first Moon landing on television, the show conjures an engagingly humane vision of living with modern technology (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

ANSEL ADAMS, "100 + 1," Robert Mann, 210 11th Avenue, near 24th Street, (212) 989-2947 (through Aug. 22). Great modern artist or purveyor of high-toned kitsch? Coinciding with the retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art, this substantial show affords a fine occasion to weigh the evidence. Looking at Adams's skillfully manipulated, Wild West landscapes, one feels less awakened to the wondrous complexities of photography and nature than bludgeoned by a proto-Spielbergian romanticism (Johnson).

"BOYS OF SUMMER," ClampArt, 531 West 25th Street, (646) 230-0020 (through Sept. 6). If you like to look at men, and you're passing by, stop in. Standing out among the crowd of pictures by more than two dozen photographers are "Bruce in His Car," a 1981 portrait of a skinny bohemian in his big red convertible by Nan Goldin; a beefy, shirtless young football player celebrating with his team, by Brian Finke; men in leather, by Barbara Nitke; and, by Malerie Marder, a large color image of a mixed-sex group of naked people relaxing in a California bathhouse (Johnson).

"FRANKENSTEIN (OR IT'S ALL FUN AND GAMES UNTIL SOMEONE LOSES AN EYE)," Tanya Bonakdar, 521 West 21st Street, (212) 414-4144, (through Aug. 22). Organized by Ethan Sklar, the gallery's director, this exhibition examines the ways artists subvert the physical and decision-making processes of art making by using machines, accident, science, random selection and all-inclusiveness and has a title perfectly suited to its sometimes scary weirdness (Smith).

* "HALF AIR," Marianne Boesky, 535 West 22nd Street, (212) 680-9889 (through Aug. 29). Everything in this fascinating reliquary of a show looks like it was exhumed from some moldy basement. It includes enigmatic, semi-abstract symbolist paintings by Forrest Bess; mesmerizing, diagrammatic linear compositions by Genn Branca; videos of the performance artist Charlemagne Palestine whipping himself into Dionysian frenzies; snapshots documenting the demimonde of the performance artist Jack Smith; and scenes from a Wooster Group film featuring the seaside antics of cross-dressed nuns (Johnson).

* "IN FULL VIEW," Andrea Rosen, 525 West 24th Street, (212) 627-6000 (through Sept. 13). A show that invites visitors on a pluralistic treasure hunt for 18 artworks that tease one's limits of visual perception. Look for Christopher Chiappa's Ford Taurus gas-tank door built into the wall; Maurizio Cattelan's roosting stuffed pigeons; Vincent Shine's tiny, gold Brancusian wasp; Jim Hodges's jewelry-chain spiderweb and Charles Ray's classic "Rotating Disc" (Johnson).

"LIGHT AS AIR," Fischbach, 210 11th Avenue, near 24th Street, (212) 759-2345 (through Aug. 22). Most remarkable of all in this 26-artist show is Victoria Gitman's actual-size picture of a moth-shaped silver brooch, its extremely fine filigree painted with eye-straining exactitude. Kevin King's painting of two white swans flying low at a man on railroad tracks is haunting; George Nick's picture of a Victorian house is juicy; and Meg Shields's small painting of an ordinary neighborhood with water tanks towering in the background is nostalgic but not sentimental (Johnson).

ANDREI MOLODKIN, Kashya Hildebrand, 531-539 West 25th Street, (212) 366-5757 (through Sept. 13). This skillful Russian draftsman has a heavy-handed way with popular and political symbols. He draws giant parodies of "I Love N.Y." or "I Love Sex" bumper stickers, replacing the valentine heart with anatomically accurate skulls. Also on view is a double portrait of Lenin and Stalin. What's most interesting is not the imagery but how these enormous drawings are made: entirely with a blue ballpoint pen (Johnson).

"SPLIT," Sandra Gering, 534 West 22nd Street, (646) 336-7183 (through Sept. 6). The best thing in this six-person show is Xavier Veilhan's bigger-than-life skeleton woven in wicker; it slouches casually in a corner of the gallery, a marvel of exotic faux-folk art. Note, too, a dense mix of cartoon characters and abstract patterning painted collaboratively in gouache by Christian Schumann and Gary Panter (Johnson).

"VACATION," Spike, 547 West 20th Street, (212) 627-4100 (through Sept. 20). Innocence and experience collide in the works of Norm Magnusson, who outlines juvenile, coloring-book-style images over gridded fields of pages from pointedly selected books. Jesus offering guidance to a little boy is drawn over pages from Bulfinch's "Mythology," for example, and paper-doll clothes over "Lolita." Also on view: Buck Henri's engaging photographs of exotic dancers, old cars, mannequins, small-town parades and other subjects; Alan Schmer's illustrative paintings of farm animals; and Melissa Stern's pedestal-size figurative sculptures that blend Surrealism and primitivism (Johnson).

Last Chance

* "ART OF THE FIRST CITIES: THE THIRD MILLENNIUM B.C. FROM THE MEDITERRANEAN TO THE INDUS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue and 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sunday). The most timely exhibition in years, as well as diplomatically dexterous and beautiful. It surveys the culture of the third millennium B.C., mainly centered in Mesopotamia, the crucible of Sumerian civilization, where art, architecture, law and writing developed with the rise of the earliest cities. The beginnings of a cosmopolitan art are in tiny cylinder seals and in figurines. The show is full of small objects that are monumental in concept. Hours and admission: See above (Kimmelman).

"FROM THE NECK UP," Garth Clark, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 246-2205 (through today). The human head is here subjected to a cranium-spinning array of treatments in clay. Highlights include a funky, Strangelovian monument called "Crazy Nuke," by Robert Arneson; a sweet yet rugged oversize boy's head, by Elise Siegel; an extremely craggy bust that resembles a natural geological wonder, by Jean-Pierre Larocque; variously glazed portraits notable for their expressive mobility, by Louise Radochonksi; and a faux-neo-Classical bust of General Douglas MacArthur by the Japanese sculptor Akio Takamori (Johnson).

RACHEL HARRISON, HIRSCH PERLMAN, DIETER ROTH, JACK SMITH, REBECCA WARREN, Matthew Marks, 523 West 24th Street, Chelsea,(212) 243-0200 (through today). This show by European and American artists from different generations pays tribute to the ability to conjure loony, often sexual excess from next to nothing in terms of materials or techniques. A museum-quality effort organized by Jeffrey Peabody, the gallery's director, it sings the body electric in clay, found materials, altered stuffed animals and photography (Smith).

"MANET AND THE AMERICAN CIVIL WAR: THE BATTLE OF U.S.S. KEARSARGE AND C.S.S. ALABAMA," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sunday). Along with many of his countrymen, the thoroughly French painter Edouard Manet was fascinated by a celebrated battle of the American Civil War that took place off Cherbourg in 1864: the fight between the Union sailing ship U.S.S. Kearsarge and the Confederate raider C.S.S. Alabama. Although he missed the battle itself, which ended in victory for the Kearsarge, he was inspired to make an imaginary rendition of it, and several weeks later, visiting the victorious Kearsarge at anchor off Boulogne, he painted the ship itself at first hand. His innovative paintings, with their striking compositional effects and fresher, freer brushwork, had an influence on other artists of the period, notably Monet, Whistler and Courbet. They are on view with other material bearing on the incident: photographs, memorabilia and paintings by others (among them a stunner by Monet). A bold depiction of the sea and ships, very different from the tight, literal renderings of more conventional marine artists, Manet's work helped lead the way to the radical brushwork of Impressionism. Hours and admission: See above (Glueck).

* "THE PHOTOGRAPHY OF CHARLES SHEELER," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sunday). This majestic progression of 90 vintage prints will cause some ripples in the big familiar pond of American Modernism, within which Sheeler is known foremost as one of the chief instigators of Precisionist painting. But his most profound, original response to Cubism came through the camera, in tautly composed photographs of Pennsylvania farmhouses and barns, New York skyscrapers and Ford's River Rouge factory. Their confident fusion of abstraction and fact, reverence and scrutiny, puts them among the most radical art of their time; and they are an important precursor, at least in spirit, to Pop and Minimalism. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

OLAV WESTPHALEN, "The First Long Island City Blimp Derby," Sculpture Center, 44-19 Purves Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 361-1750 (through tomorrow). The Blimp Derby, produced by Mr. Westphalen, took place on June 28. You can still see the track painted on the floor where contestants steered their ungainly, remote-control miniature dirigibles; the lumpy, handmade and clumsily painted silver winner's trophy; and painted on one wall in delicate gray washes, an advertisement for the race sponsor, Budweiser (Johnson).

"DIRT WIZARD," Brooklyn Fire Proof, 101 Richardson Street, at Leonard Street, Williamsburg, (718) 302-4702 (through Monday). Organized by the artist Kathy Grayson, this ambitious show of paintings, drawings and wall paintings uses the work of emerging artists like Keegan McHargue, Matt Leines, Maya Hayuk, Xylor Jane and Justin Samson. It highlights the graffiti-based drawing wizardry emanating from the East and West Coasts, as well as a spiritual and stylistic meeting of East and West in the global sense (Smith).

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
From Small Sculptures to Glimpses of Signs, a Mix of Works in the Bronx

BYLINE:  By KEN JOHNSON 

 BODY:
No one ever said it would be easy to achieve a self-sustaining art career in New York. Even artists who have lived in the city for years remain mystified by the commercial system's apparent impenetrability. Yet there are lots of artists who do manage it. How do they do it?
 One answer is: Make great art and they will come. Summoned by the vibes of your art, the dealers, curators and collectors will magically appear at your studio door. The other answer is: It's a business, so deal with it. Make art good, bad or indifferent and then learn how to sell it -- and yourself. This is the approach favored by Artists in the Marketplace (A.I.M.), an artist-supporting program, now in its 23rd year, that focuses not on helping artists make better art but on helping them learn effective ways of marketing their work. 
 Over the course of two 12-week series of seminars, young and emerging artists are introduced to commercial gallery dealers, and to other successful artists, critics, curators, arts administrators, foundation representatives, publicists and even lawyers, who teach them about grant writing, contract negotiations, curatorial practices, pricing, portfolio presentation and so on. At the end of the year, the 35 participants are given a big group show, and this year's edition is on view now at the Bronx Museum of the Arts.
Although it resembles one, the A.I.M. show is not a student exhibition. The artists are out of school and have embarked on their various professional journeys. But it is not the Whitney Biennial; it is not about fresh new things currently animating the art world. A few of these artists might eventually make themselves known in contemporary art, but if the next Matthew Barney or Lisa Yuskavage is among them, there is no evidence of it yet.
Most of the artists are doing the kinds of work that graduate students all over the nation are producing: slightly oversize, conceptually portentous color photographs laminated to panels; layered pastiches of appropriated cartoon imagery; oblique, politically tendentious videos; neat constructions mixing Minimalism and references to vernacular culture.
Most of the work in the show is well executed, but most of it is also so obviously derivative that it could revive a belief in originality in even the most hidebound neo-Marxist. But there is only one painting in the entire show -- Antonio Vigil's expansive cityscape painted with a sensuously meticulous touch -- which seems odd, considering what an active presence painting has had in New York galleries over the last couple of years. 
At the risk of sounding too harsh, it's hard to escape the feeling that what is most urgently needed here is not career coaching but some constructive critical input. Does this cast doubt on the A.I.M. program? Maybe, maybe not. This is not the place to judge its effectiveness at producing smarter career managers.
In any case, on a positive note, there are some appealing artworks in the show. Jeongtae Chae, for one, produces economical sculptural works out of ordinary found materials that are remarkable for their optical effects. A radiating ring of white plastic forks on the floor, called "Flower," for example, creates a pulsating composition of concentric patterns. And a grid of short cardboard tubes, each holding within it a plastic pipe section in red, black or white is similarly captivating.
Also absorbing to look at are Joe Fig's small sculptures of artists' painting tables, crowded with tubes, cans, bottles and brushes. These doll-house-scale works, which include lots of paint splattering and detritus, are not just feats of miniaturism. They represent the work tables of specific artists, including those of April Gornick and Gary Stephan. So they are, in a sense, indirect portraits, as well as sociological documents of a certain vein of professional art-making. 
The most enjoyable video is Kate Gilmore's, in which she appears to be trying to bring order to extremely messy situations. Dressed sensibly in black like an office temp worker, she stacks papers, envelopes and other clerical detritus into shaky towers that keep falling over. It's mildly funny, but the artist's earnest persistence is oddly moving as well. 
Each artist has provided a brief statement about his or her work. Some are more helpful than others. One of the best is by Hidemi Sato, who writes: "When I was a little girl in Japan, I saw the movie 'American Graffiti' on TV. I was amazed by the color in the film. Everybody was dressed in bright clothes: all of the cars and furniture were extremely colorful. I felt it was very American and it filled me with happy feelings."
This is how Ms. Sato explains her practice of what she calls "Happie Photographie," which consists of expansive, gridded arrangements of fragmentary glimpses of fast food restaurant signs, gas station signs and billboards, all seen against backgrounds of deep blue sky. For all its beautiful superficiality, there's a mysterious, poetic profundity to this work.

"A.I.M. 23" is at the Bronx Museum of the Arts, 1040 Grand Concourse, Morrisania, (718) 681-6000, through Sept. 28.

GRAPHIC: Photo: "Stephan (Gary Stephan 2002)," one of Joe Fig's small sculptures of artists' painting tables, in the "A.I.M." show at the Bronx Museum. (Photo by Bronx Museum of the Arts)

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
Military Revival After the Vietnam Trauma

BYLINE:  By DANIEL BENJAMIN; Daniel Benjamin is a senior fellow at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington and co-author of "The Age of Sacred Terror."

 BODY:
AMERICA'S SPLENDID LITTLE WARS
A Short History of U.S. Military Engagements: 1975-2000
By Peter Huchthausen
Illustrated. 254 pages. Viking. $25.95.
 Barely a generation separates two milestones in the history of the United States military: in March 1973, the last American combat troops departed from Vietnam, demoralized standard-bearers of the nation's most ignominious modern failure at arms. Thirty years later, United States forces this past March began an invasion of Iraq that will likely be remembered as one of the most rapid conquests ever of a large nation. Between these two events lies an extraordinary story of regeneration and adaptation. 
 A full accounting of how the post-Vietnam military, a "hollow army," in the famous phrase of Gen. Edward C. Meyer, became a world-bestriding force has yet to be written. It is a work in need of an author not least because military might has become an outsize aspect of American power. Other Western countries have generous welfare states; the United States alone has a military that can project force anywhere on the globe, fight and win.
America's technological advantage in warfare has become so large that, despite the ritual references to coalition forces, the Pentagon finds it more of a burden than a benefit to have allies in combat. (It demonstrated this by turning down offers of assistance for the fighting in Afghanistan. The Department of Defense's desire for assistance in peacekeeping is another issue entirely.)
Remarkably, the Bush administration shows no sign of resting content with the current enormous superiority to all conceivable rivals. Defense spending has been rising for the last five years, and Congress is currently putting the final touches on a national security budget of $400 billion, or about 10 percent more in real dollars than the United States spent in an average year in the cold war. That does not include the $75 billion cost of operations in Iraq. 
In "America's Splendid Little Wars: A Short History of U.S. Military Engagements: 1975-2000," Peter Huchthausen has written a prelude to this subject, surveying the period that began with the Mayaguez incident, in which Khmer Rouge forces seized an American merchant container ship, and ended with NATO's defeat of Serb forces in Kosovo. The title, adapted from the diplomat John Milton Hay's description of the Spanish-American War, is ironic, as the author acknowledges. With ample chapters devoted to debacles like Desert One, the failed effort to rescue American hostages in Iran in 1980, and the 1992-93 deployment in Somalia, little splendor is on display.
These sections are accompanied by others covering eight more engagements, including interventions in Grenada, Bosnia and Kosovo, the reflagging and escorting of merchant ships in the Persian Gulf, the hunt for Manuel Noriega in Panama and the 1991 Persian Gulf war. In clean and economic prose, Captain Huchthausen, a retired Navy officer, delivers a historical background to each engagement of the United States military and a concise narrative of the action.
The author takes a traditionalist's approach and dwells on those episodes in which shots were fired -- or should have been -- instead of ones that saw American troops involved in peacekeeping or nation-building, as in the substantial deployment to Haiti. Many of his vignettes are thoughtful and thorough, recapitulating, for example, the largely forgotten political struggles on Grenada that helped trigger United States intervention and describing in its full horror the experience of the Marines in their 1982-83 deployment in Lebanon, where they came to serve no function except as a target for hostile militias and terrorists. 
Others are marred by mistakes of fact -- the 78-day campaign over the skies of Kosovo involved not "450 allied sorties" but more than 10,000. Some of Captain Huchthausen's conclusions are also off, as when he argues that as a result of the air strike President Ronald Reagan ordered against Libya in 1986, Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's "overt support of terror attacks ceased." Two years later, Colonel Qaddafi's intelligence agents arranged the bombing of Pan Am 103, the most murderous act of Libyan terror ever, which cost 270 lives.
Perhaps the most frustrating shortcoming of "America's Splendid Little Wars" is the author's tendency to touch on big themes without developing them. Thus, he limns the growing importance of special operations forces but never details how halting progress has been in putting these exceptionally trained and lavishly equipped warriors in the field. Though billions have been devoted to building up the fabled Army Delta Force, Navy Seals and others, commanders have been averse to employing them -- often to the exasperation of their civilian masters.
In the 1991 war against Iraq, Gen. Norman Schwarzkopf wanted little to do with the "operators," and almost a decade later the brass in Washington was reluctant to use special forces to capture wanted war criminals in Bosnia. Secretary of Defense Donald Rumsfeld aims to change that aspect of the American Way of War, which favors great massed forces often to the exclusion of small, highly mobile contingents. Whether his innovations will outlast his tenure remains to be seen.
Similarly, Captain Huchthausen observes that "Each military engagement in this history demonstrates the progression of a blend of battlefield hardware, improved communications and command-and-control technologies." Yet he never addresses head-on how the advent of "stand-off" weapons like cruise missiles, precision-guided munitions or stealth technology have changed the face of battle. 
While he says his greatest obligation is to those who fought, he tells us little about who they are -- those who joined the all-volunteer military and, especially, those who fill the contemporary officer corps, an assemblage of talent and intelligence that may be as impressive as any in our history. The human side of the military transformation of the last three decades is surely the most fascinating part of the story. Too much chronicle and not enough history, "America's Splendid Wars" leaves this subject for another to reconnoiter.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Peter Huchthausen (Photo by Associated Press)

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW; 
Giving Life to the Debris of a Mechanized World

BYLINE:  By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
The exhibition of Richard Stankiewicz's charmingly vigorous welded scrap-metal sculpture at the AXA Gallery is the artist's first retrospective in New York, but it has a comforting, even stuffy air of familiarity.
 Glancing over Stankiewicz's slyly figurative semiabstract personages and creatures, with their steam-valve faces, rusted-nail feathers, links-of-chain coiffures, wheel-spoke headdresses and gas-tank torsos, you may tell yourself that you've seen it all before. Truth is, you probably have, but I'll bet you've never seen it quite this good. 
 Stankiewicz, who died in 1983 at the age of 60, was a poet of the industral sublime with an instinctive sense of the kinetic, figurative potential imprisoned within nearly all of the discarded machines, car parts and dismembered kitchen appliances that came his way.
In the early 1950's he started welding fragments of rusted metal scrap into pieces that lived up to titles like "Kabuki Dancer," "Middle-Aged Couple" and "Marionette" with the spine-tingling accuracy of an art-history-savvy cartoon caricature. In the 1955 "City Bird," for example, we see a feathered dandy whose dozen feet create a speeding Futurist blur. 
Soon Stankiewicz had a hit on his hands: "junk" sculpture, a sub-genre of the multifronted art of assemblage that thrived on the East and West Coasts and then rapidly spread to the hinterlands. Junk sculpture appeared to be an easygoing do-it-yourself art; anyone could do it and far too many did -- artists, would-be artists, nonartists and students alike.
Between 1952 and 1965, Stankiewicz had a dozen one-person shows, six at the Hansa Gallery and then six at the Stable Gallery. His work was included in four Whitney Annuals, two Pittsburgh Internationals, a Venice Biennale and a Sao Paulo Bienal. The critic William Geist greeted his 1953 show as "a miracle in the scrap heap," a phrase used in the title to AXA's show, which was organized for the Addison Gallery of American Art at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass., by Emmie Donadio, a Stankiewicz scholar and associate director of the Middlebury College Museum of Art in Vermont. 
The miracle wasn't exactly new. Precedents included Picasso's bull's head made from a bicycle seat and handlebars, reliefs by Kurt Schwitters and to some extent Duchamp's readymades, which were all acknowledged in the catalog to "The Art of Assemblage" at the Museum of Modern Art in 1961. Nor was Stankiewicz acting alone; his cohorts included Edward Kienholz, Bruce Connor, Marisol, Red Grooms as well as European artists like Eduardo Paolozzi and Jean Tinguely. 
Still, his work seems unusually emblematic of a period when Abstract Expressionism was losing traction and more worldly materials, subjects and ideas were bubbling up all around, shortly to be unduly organized into Happenings, Fluxus, Pop Art and Minimalism. It was also the visual equivalent of concrete poetry and jazz.
Born in Philadelphia in 1922, Stankiewicz was, in hindsight, well prepared for this form of improvisation. After training in mechanical drawing, he served a long stint in the Navy, seeking out museums whenever he was ashore. He was discharged in 1947 and less than two years later ended up in New York, where he studied with Hans Hofmann, whose theory of push-pull composition made an indelible impression on him.
In 1950 he spent a year in Paris on the G.I. Bill, studying briefly with Fernand Leger, whose appreciation of modern industry appealed to him even if his classroom style did not, and longer with the sculptor Ossip Zadkine. He also saw the work of Giacometti and Dubuffet. Back in New York, he was attracted by pieces of rusty metal in the garden of the building he lived in on Bond Street and taught himself to weld. 
For a while Stankiewicz had something like perfect pitch, in an almost photographic sense. In "Kabuki Dancer," he uses a little spiraling arrangement of flat metal bars to convey the stylized, cocked-ankle turn of the dancer's raised foot. In "Family Portrait," which comes closest to Kienholz, we make out the figures of a worrying, hunched-shouldered father, a more approachable mother with door-handle breasts and an open-faced child.
In "River of Styx," the attenuated form at the center of this marvelously billowing composition could be either the fierce boatman or the hysterical passenger trying to fend off the gates of hell. But thankfully most of Stankiewicz's choices do double time. "Bird Lover in the Grass" seems more like a skulking submarine with raised periscope, as two of the blades of rusted-pipe grass brandish motor parts that could be either binoculars or guns. 
Sometimes history rather than the work's title provides the punch line. An untitled work ruled by right angles and refrigerator shelving instantly conjures up the International Style version of Giacometti's "Palace at 4 a.m." And in the best work in the show, "Tribal Diagram," he learns from Cubism and African ironwork to achieve what may be the ultimate "drawing in space." It is a rectilinear family tree, as well as a vertical landscape, punctuated with little fringes, tassels and blossoms of nails and wire, each bursting with suggestions of plant, animal and human life.
By the late 1960's, Stankiewicz was fading from view. Artists like Jasper Johns, John Chamberlain and Donald Judd had jettisoned the compositional subtleties he had so assiduously perfected. Stankiewicz was notably absent from "Painting and Sculpture in New York: 1940 to 1970," Henry Geldzahler's big survey at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, which spanned the generations from Hans Hoffmann to Frank Stella. In the catalog's introduction, Geldzahler called the show's 43 artists "deflectors," arguing that they had "significantly deflected the course of recent art." 
What happened? It could be argued that Stankiewicz is one of those artists whose work fits in at so many junctures, historical tangents and cultural moments that it almost seems to disappear as you think about it. It doesn't seem to be much more than the sum of its sources and references because in some basic way it lacks a personal core. Its passion lies in a delicate, erudite sophistication that keeps its inner necessity carefully under wraps. This needn't be so, as is ably demonstrated by the art of Cy Twombly, who was also omitted from Geldzahler's show. 
Stankiewicz's work also suggests a series of final flowerings: of the Cubist chassis, of Abstract Expressionist sculpture, of postwar figuration. It is all leavened by wit, elegance and an economy that is a rebuke to lugubrious efforts on both sides of the Atlantic, committed by artists from Ibram Lassaw to Reg Butler and Lynn Chadwick. In the end, Stankiewicz's art defines a moment of transition so precisely that it is ultimately more the end of one thing than the beginning of another. As the innovations it helped trigger gained force, it looked more and more familiar and old-fashioned, resonant of the past more than the future. Stankiewicz wrestled with and elaborated upon tradition, but did not break with it. 
But art, unlike an opera, is never over. Compositional complexity is no longer the taboo that it once was, and semiabstract cartoonish, double-playing representation has serious currency. Philip Guston's late work gave it a resilient credibility that has been extended by scores of more recent efforts, from Carroll Dunham's lonely, rageful mavericks to the abject composite waifs of Jonathan Pylypchuk. Maybe Stankiewicz's moment of greatest relevance is just beginning.

"Miracle in the Scrap Heap: The Sculpture of Richard Stankiewicz" is at the AXA Gallery, 787 Seventh Avenue, at 51st Street, Manhattan, (212) 554-4818, through Sept. 25.

HEADLINE: Letting Nature Run Its Course, and Making Money From It 

BYLINE:  By HEATHER TIMMONS

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 14 

 BODY:
Brutal heat in Europe has caused power prices to soar and has robbed the profits of bakeries and chocolate makers. Meanwhile, rain in the northeastern United States has left amusement parks and beach resorts empty.
 Where most people see bigger bills, heat exhaustion or ruined vacations, investment banks and traders are finding a way to make money. The fledgling market for weather derivatives is expanding rapidly, they say, and the nasty weather is only going to help. 
 Weather derivatives allow companies whose earnings are affected by nature's variables -- temperature, precipitation, frost and others -- to hedge against that risk. A construction company that cannot pour concrete when the weather is too cold, for example, can buy a derivative that will pay out if there are more than the average number of freezing days in a winter. Soon, say some proponents, there will be no excuse for letting nature run its course.
"Within five years' time, companies won't be able to say, 'Our profits are down because of the weather,' " said Duncan Wilson, a consultant to WeatherXchange, a venture between the Met Office, a British forecaster, and the Chicago Mercantile Exchange.
Weather derivatives were introduced six years ago and popularized in the energy industry by Enron. But the collapse of Enron and the shrinking of other energy companies has left a vacuum that is quickly being filled by investment banks and insurers eager to sell the product.
In the 12 months ended in March, the number of new weather derivatives contracts tripled, to almost 12,000. At about $4.2 billion, the dollar value was nearly unchanged from the year before, but that is because some the biggest participants, like Enron, left the market. There are about $12 billion in contracts outstanding, up from none in 1996.
Oil and power companies still make up the bulk of derivatives users in the United States. But outside the country, industries from ice cream to breweries have signed on. Last year, even the two-week beer festival, the Munich Oktoberfest, was hedged against rain.
The recent spate of hot, dry weather in Europe is helping to increase demand, said Ross McIntyre, director for weather derivatives at Deutsche Bank in London.
"Companies hurt by these extreme weather events are in communication with us, and are interested in doing multi-year deals," he said. Most are from outside the energy industry.
Comey & Barrow, a London wine bar chain, was the first non-energy company in Britain to take out a weather derivative in 2000. Bars and pubs generally make a disproportionate amount of their income on warm days when patrons linger at outside tables, ordering a second or third drink. This year, buying a weather derivative may have seemed a waste, because it was unseasonably warm. But, "next year, it might rain all summer," said Sarah Heward, managing director of Corney & Barrow, who says she is lining one up now.
Trading in these contracts is still much smaller than in other derivatives. About 2,000 temperature-related derivatives trade daily on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, less than one-twentieth the number of interest rate derivatives traded. 
But expansion seems inevitable. On Tuesday, the Chicago exchange and the Met Office said they were creating temperature-related derivatives for Europe that are expected to trade on the commodities exchange by the end of the year. The Chicago exchange also plans to invest up to $1.8 million over the next three years in the WeatherXchange joint venture. "Weather is a new frontier," said Terry Duffy, the chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, in announcing the deal.
Even before the extreme weather in Europe, a renewed focus on corporate governance was sparking more interest in weather derivatives, said Alex Schippers, global head of weather and insurance derivatives at ABN Amro, the Dutch bank. Three years ago, ABN Amro was not even in the market, but it now has weather trading desks in Sydney, Amsterdam, Singapore and London, and will be selling products in India this year.
"The bottom line is a C.E.O. has to explain any deviation in his results," Mr. Schippers said. "Clearly 10 years ago a brewer could say it had a much colder summer than expected," he said. But now analysts will question executives at the same brewer, and wonder why they did not hedge for the weather, he added.
Last year, ABN Amro created one of the largest weather derivative deals to be syndicated, or parceled out to investors. An unnamed Dutch construction company took out a contract with the bank that would pay 10 million euros ($11.2 million) a day if there were more than 19 freezing days in the five months before March 31. (There weren't.)
After being created by an investment bank, weather derivatives can be held, traded, or sold off to third-party investors -- which is where the risk comes in. If an investor in weather derivatives holds a lot of contracts written to European ice cream retailers, for example, and an unseasonably cold summer follows, the investor will suffer.
Still, the derivatives appeal to institutional investors eager to diversify from traditional financial markets. Conventional economic wisdom has always been, "When America sneezes, the rest of the world catches a cold," meaning that the impact of a weak currency, slow spending or plummeting stock prices in the United States are felt around the globe.
But there are no such clearly identified links with the weather. If it rains, say, more than normal in Iowa one summer, it might rain less in Malaysia. Or it might not. Investors in the weather sector often spread their exposure around, and rely on investing formulas that are highly personalized and secretive. One weather derivatives expert contends, for example, that a hotter-than-normal Europe generally comes at the same time as a wetter-than-average Eastern United States -- a bet that made money this summer.
Coriolis Capital, a fund manager, invests about half of its $350 million in weather-related derivatives tied to 20 different countries. . "We have no correlation to the markets," said the fund's chief executive, Diego Wauters. "Only factors like the temperature in London or the snow in the Alps influence the performance of our funds." Coriolis does not disclose its performance, but Mr. Wauters said returns are expected to top the London Interbank Offered Rate, the base interest rate paid on deposits between banks in Europe, by 2 to 10 percent. 
Despite the growing popularity of weather derivatives, there are some executives who say that they will never participate in the market. Hedging against the weather is just laziness, said Jim Clarke, chief financial officer of J.D. Wetherspoons, a British pub chain.
"We've told our pubs, come hail or shine, they have to keep people coming through the doors," he said.

HEADLINE: Data Show Recessions In Germany And Italy 

BYLINE:  By ERIC PFANNER

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 14 

 BODY:
Germany and Italy slipped into recession in the second quarter, as the economies of the 12 nations that share the euro stagnated, according to government reports published today.
 While tentative signs of a rebound in the United States and the European stimulus programs have lifted business and consumer confidence, that optimism has yet to produce real economic gains, analysts said. 
 "We're still in an environment where the euro zone economy has basically come to a halt," said Audrey Childe-Freeman, an economist at CIBC World Markets in London. 
Germany entered a shallow recession for the second time in as many years, its government said today. The economy contracted by 0.1 percent in the second quarter, after a 0.2 percent drop in the first.
The weakness spread to Italy, heavily dependent on Germany as an export market. Italy's recession is its first in a decade.
The weakest numbers of all, however, came from the Netherlands, which was already in recession. Output declined 0.5 percent from April to June as consumers pulled back on spending. 
It was the third consecutive quarter of economic contraction.
Most countries in the euro zone are suffering from weak overseas demand for their goods, which have been priced out of some markets by a rise in the euro. Growth in the region was unchanged in the second quarter from the first quarter, when there was a 0.1 percent gain.
France, the second-largest economy in the euro zone, does not report its second-quarter performance until next week. But the government has steadily reduced its growth forecasts this year.
Despite the current gloom, analysts see a few reasons for optimism. Some recovery in the American economy, which grew 2.4 percent in the second quarter, improves the outlook for Europe, which usually lags the United States by about half a year.
Analysts are also encouraged by recent signs of recovery in business confidence and consumer spending after worries stemming from the war in Iraq kept shoppers at home. "The strengthening of domestic demand bodes well for a gradual recovery both in Germany and the euro area in the second half of this year," said Lorenzo Codogno, an economist at Bank of America.
Analysts were also optimistic about the commitment of Germany's chancellor, Gerhardt Schroder, to take long-delayed steps to improve the competitiveness of Germany, the euro zone's largest economy. The chancellor won cabinet approval this week for a plan to accelerate proposed tax cuts to next yearin an effort to jump-start sluggish consumer spending. The cabinet also endorsed a package of changes to the welfare system, aimed at reducing costly unemployment benefits and reviving the labor market.

CORRECTION-DATE: August 19, 2003

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in World Business on Friday about government reports that showed recessions in Germany and Italy misspelled the given name of the German chancellor. He is Gerhard Schroder, not Gerhardt.

HEADLINE: DRIVING; 
Give Me Plugs In My S.U.V.

BYLINE:  By PHIL PATTON 

 BODY:
AS they so often do, the Simpsons have gotten to the essence of a change in modern American life. In an episode broadcast not long ago, Homer discovers the joys of appliances made to be used in the car: he plugs in a television set with VCR, a French fryer, a fax machine -- even a lava lamp.
 Homer's appliances only slightly exaggerate the range of equipment that plugs into cars these days. As Americans spend more time driving their cars in slow rush-hour traffic, or partying out of them, manufacturers are making all manner of gadgets that plug into the old 12-volt cigarette-lighter socket. And automakers, in turn, are scrambling to provide more sockets, racing one another in a battle shaping up as the new cup-holder wars. 
 Probably the most intimidatingly powerful vehicle on the road today is the Hummer H2, and it delivers not just horsepower (315 with its V-8 engine), but electrical power, too. It has five 12-volt power outlets scattered through its capacious cabin. Runners-up like the GMC Yukon and Lincoln Navigator have four. 
In the Navigator (which also boasts 10 cup holders), there are two outlets in front, one for the back seat and another in the cargo area. The Volkswagen Passat is one of several family sedans that have added plugs to their trunks.
The world of 12-volt power is as foreign to that of the 110-volt American home power systems as European current. But even the 42-volt standard that engineers have experimented with at DaimlerChrysler, General Motors and Delphi Automotive Systems would be too much of a jolt for the safety of mechanics, professional and amateur. So it has been up to appliance makers to adapt, and they have done so enthusiastically.
Heavy-footed drivers have long plugged their radar detectors, legal or not, into the dash. But camping and tailgate parties created a market for appliances like car-compatible coffee makers and refrigerators. And the cellphone, with its relentless demands for recharging, accustomed many drivers to using car plug-ins, further increasing the demand for outlets.
Drivers want front-seat plugs for food coolers and mug warmers. Back-seat power outlets are in demand to run video games for young passengers. Tailgate-party fans want power in the trunk or rear cargo area for their coffee makers and electric charcoal lighters.
Automotive parts and accessories stores, catalogs and Web sites offer a huge variety of kitchen and family-room devices in a 12-volt format, from game consoles to DVD players with flat-panel screens to blenders powerful enough to crush ice for drinks. But also increasingly popular are plug-ins that give drivers options they neglected to order on their new cars -- or allow them to buy those options at lower cost.
Several CD and DVD players are available, for example. Garmin's StreetPilot III fills in for a navigation system, providing a G.P.S. antenna, a map CD and a screen that gives directions for $999, in contrast to $1,200 to $1,500 for a typical factory-installed navigation system. Heated seats, usually an amenity associated with plush luxury cars, can be installed in plug-in form in the most humble econobox.
Some devices are marketed to truckers (the outlets in their rigs are the same 12 volts as the ones in cars). A recent visit to the shop at a South Carolina truck stop revealed a toaster ($24) that sits on clever little rubber feet to absorb highway bumps, a $20 blow-dryer and even a 12-volt soldering iron.
Splitters are available to let a single plug accept two devices. Some appliances for the car come with pass-through plugs so that a second device can attach to them. But in the 12-volt world, the ultimate accessory may be factory-installed. The Pontiac Vibe and Toyota Matrix, sibling vehicles aimed at young buyers, are the first cars to offer a conventional 110-volt household plug (courtesy of a transformer inside it) built into the dash. Using this, you can simply take your favorite appliance with you, from residence to road.
Cars can usually meet the power demands of several devices at once while underway, though the owner should be careful to observe any warnings about overloading from the manufacturers. And too many add-ons can drain the battery of a parked car more rapidly than headlights left on overnight.
When it comes to microwaving the egg sandwich or fishing through the fridge for the chilled drinks, the best option may be to sit and idle. Juggling his plug-in appliances, Homer Simpson becomes so busy that he runs right off the road.

PLUG-INS
To Take With You on the Road
INVENTING and designing for their own parallel power universe, the sellers of 12-volt gear constantly come up with novel appliances and devices to take on the road. Here is a sampling.

NOT JUST ANY COFFEE -- Bertone, the Italian automotive designer, has also turned out an espresso maker for the road. Available in black, bright blue or yellow, it is as cute as an Italian sports car and dispenses brew at 180 degrees. The list price is $52. It is available at Coffeenuts.webdirectbrands.com and www.800-espresso.com or 888-523-2424.

FOR COIFFURE OR WINDOW -- A hair dryer, also advertised as a defroster for those cold mornings, goes for $19.99 from the Hilltop RV Superstore in Michigan (www.hilltoprv.net).

ILLUMINATE -- The super-bright halogen map light is not just for reading maps. Its 10-foot cord and metal legs make it handy for lighting nighttime jobs such as changing a tire or loading luggage onto the roof. At $22.95, it is available at www.griotsgarage.com.

BACK-SEAT VCR -- The Audiovox VBP2000 Video-in-a-Bag, with a five-inch LCD screen, hangs from a seat back. It is available for $496 at Pep Boys stores.

PORTABLE POSITIONING -- The Cobra GPS1000 hand-held navigation system displays a car's location and plots the owner's trips. It is $249.90 at www.12voltfusion.com.

COMFORT -- Ten motors are ready to soothe in a massaging seat topper with heat that fits over the seat from a strap around the headrest. It is $99 at Brookstone (866-576-7337 or www.brookstone.com).

WARM IT OR COOL IT -- The Vector thermoelectric food cooler/warmer chest cools food to 40 degrees below the outside temperature or warms it up to 130 degrees. It sits on the car's seat or floor and comes with a seven-foot cord. It is $69.99 at www.jcwhitney.com.

WHIR -- Blenders are available at many RV stores or www.rvpartsstore.com. Most do not run directly from the 12-volt plug but from a power-storage device needed to provide the motor with the necessary jolts of juice. The Vector model at J. C. Whitney goes for $59.99.

HARNESS THOSE IONS -- The Ionic Breeze Dashboard Ionizer cleans the atmosphere inside the car by trapping airborne particles on an electrostatically charged ring. It is $39.95 at the Sharper Image (www.sharperimage.com).

MULTIPLICATION -- The Quest Blue Quadrasocket turns one 12-volt plug into four and glows in black light. It is $9.99 at Autozone stores or www.autozone.com.

ADAPTERS -- Radio Shack (www.radioshack.com) is a good source of power inverters that will turn a 12-volt plug into one accommodating many household appliances. Prices begin at around $30.

POWER TO GO -- The 2-in-1 Emergency Car Starter and DC Power Source is an electric-power storage device: a 20-minute charge stows away enough power to start a car with a dead battery. It can also be used away from the vehicle to power laptop computers, disc players or other devices. It is $39.99 at Radio Shack. PHIL PATTON

HEADLINE: Not Much Job Growth, but Mediocre May Look Good in 2004 

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS

 BODY:
IT is a recovery. And it is not a jobless one.
 As the economy has gradually shown strength, unevenly to be sure, one critical mantra has been to call it a jobless recovery. But there are statistics that belie that and indicate that the number of people with jobs has been growing since last fall. 
 That growth, to be sure, has been less than overwhelming. At best, it is barely keeping up with the natural growth of the labor force. But it is better than people think.
The conventional way of looking at job totals is tolook at the government's monthly payroll survey. And by that measure, this recovery is a jobless one. In July, that survey found 129.9 million jobs, 2.7 million fewer than the peak reached in February 2001, the month after President Bush took office, and a million less than in November 2001, when the recession officially ended.
But the payroll survey has limitations, and they may be important ones right now. If a person has two part-time jobs, that person is counted twice. If that person then gets one full-time job, the payroll total would fall. And the survey does not try to count self-employed people, a group that is growing rapidly.
The alternative count is the household survey, which is used to compile the unemployment rate. It is based on a survey of 60,000 households, and a quarter of them are replaced each month. 
To be sure, the household survey can be volatile, and relying on month-to-month changes, particularly for smaller groups like black teenagers, can be treacherous. But there is little volatility to worry about if one looks at year-to-year changes in six-month moving averages.
Calculated that way, the number of working Americans in July was up 0.87 percent from a year earlier. It was the ninth consecutive month showing growth. Measured the same way, the payroll survey has shown annual declines for 22 months. Historically, the two surveys usually show similar trends, and there is a good chance that the payroll survey will start to show growth soon.
In hindsight, the remarkable thing about the final days of the boom was the extent to which it benefited those who most needed help. At the time of the last presidential election, the number of employed people over all was up 2.4 percent year-to-year, but the rate of job growth for adults who never finished high school was twice that. 
Now the limited job growth is concentrated among better-educated people. There are fewer jobs for teenagers, black or white, or for adults who never finished high school. But jobs for people with college degrees are rising at a rate of more than 2 percent a year. There are more jobs for managers and professionals, and fewer for workers involved in making and shipping goods.
Low expectations can make mediocre performance respectable. Just as parents may be thrilled if a student gets a C when failure was feared, voters may be relieved that the economy is growing at all after all the talk about Japan-style deflation and continuing loss of jobs. 
"We've set the bar so low that a pedestrian cyclical rebound associated with excessive fiscal and monetary stimulus, arriving just in time for a presidential election, will look spectacular," said Robert Barbera, the chief economist of ITG/Hoenig.
If that happens, President Bush may owe a debt of gratitude to all the commentators who have focused on the negative jobs numbers, while playing down the other signs that the economy is, if not ready to boom again, at least starting to show respectable growth.

HEADLINE: Twilight Zone Economics 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
For about 20 months the U.S. economy has been operating in a twilight zone: growing too fast to meet the classic definition of a recession, but too slowly to meet the usual criteria for economic recovery. There's nothing particularly mysterious about our situation. But recent news coverage and commentary -- in particular, the enthusiastic headlines that followed a modest increase in growth and a modest decline in jobless claims -- suggest that some people still don't get it. So here's a brief refresher course on twilight zone Economics 101. 
 Since November 2001 -- which the National Bureau of Economic Research, in a controversial decision, has declared the end of the recession -- the U.S. economy has grown at an annual rate of about 2.6 percent. That may not sound so bad, but when it comes to jobs there has been no recovery at all. Nonfarm payrolls have fallen by, on average, 50,000 per month since the "recovery" began, accounting for 1 million of the 2.7 million jobs lost since March 2001. 
 Meanwhile, employment is chasing a moving target because the working-age population continues to grow. Just to keep up with population growth, the U.S. needs to add about 110,000 jobs per month. When it falls short of that, jobs become steadily harder to find. At this point conditions in the labor market are probably the worst they have been for almost 20 years. (The measured unemployment rate isn't all that high, but that's largely because many people have given up looking for work.)
All this leads to a great deal of suffering -- not just lost income, but also the anxiety and humiliation that come with long-term unemployment. Is relief in sight?
Over the last few weeks two numbers have led to a spate of optimistic pronouncements. One is the preliminary estimate of second-quarter growth, which came in at a 2.4 percent annual rate -- about one point higher than expected. The other is the rate of new applications for unemployment insurance, which has fallen slightly below 400,000 per week.
But while the growth and new claims numbers were good news, they didn't tell us that the economy is improving. All they said is that things are getting worse more slowly.
This should be obvious when it comes to growth. I saw headlines saying that in the second quarter growth "soared," even "rocketed." Huh? That 2.4 percent growth rate was a bit less than the average during our job-loss recovery. Just to stabilize the labor market in its present dismal state would probably take growth of at least 3.5 percent; it would take much more than that to return the economy to anything resembling full employment.
Meanwhile, about those unemployment claims: somehow that 400,000-per-week benchmark has acquired a lot more significance in people's minds than it deserves. For example, claims came in at 398,000 yesterday -- and this was treated as good news because it was (barely) below the magic number.
Well, here's some perspective: since November 2001 new claims have averaged 414,000 per week. A number a bit lower than that might mean stable or slightly rising payroll employment -- but as we've just seen, that's not nearly good enough. For comparison, in 2000 -- a year of good but not great employment growth -- weekly claims averaged 305,000. My conclusion is that the state of the unemployed won't improve unless claims fall a lot further than they have.
So is a real, unambiguous recovery just around the corner? Recent economic reports have had a "good news"-"bad news" feel to them. Businesses are starting to buy some equipment; that's good. But they seem to be engaging in replacement investment, not capacity expansion; that's bad. Consumers are spending; that's good. But rising interest rates seem to have ended the refinancing boom that put cash in consumers' pockets; that's bad. And so on.
The best guess is that growth in the second half of the year will be faster than in the first half, possibly high enough to create some jobs, but not high enough to make jobs easier to find. In other words, in terms of what matters most, the economy will continue to deteriorate.
All this is, of course, an indictment of our economic policy -- a policy that has managed the remarkable trick of generating immense budget deficits without giving the economy much stimulus. But that's a subject for another day.

HEADLINE: New York City Slows Its Losses, Holding Jobless Rate Steady 

BYLINE:  By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
The rate of job losses in New York City slowed further during July, according to monthly employment figures released yesterday by the state. Jobs in construction and in leisure and hospitality increased, and the rate of losses declined in financial activities and in professional and business services.
 The unemployment rate for the city, after seasonal adjustment, remained at 8.1 percent for the third month in a row, down from a high of 8.8 in February. 
 The state rate remained at 6.1 percent, which is lower than the national rate, now 6.2 percent, for the second month in a row.
"There's definitely some signs of improvement," said Jim Brown, a labor market analyst for the New York State Department of Labor, which released the data. In addition to job gains in several industries, he said, "the rate of layoffs is slowing, even in some of the weaker sectors."
The shrinking was due in part to the increases in jobs in construction and in leisure and hospitality and to a relative increase in jobs in motion picture production.
But it was also attributable to a decrease in job losses in weak areas, including financial activities.
Comparing July 2003 with July 2002, the data showed that construction jobs increased by 7,400, or 6.4 percent, and leisure and hospitality jobs increased by 7,700, or 3 percent. There was also a year-to-year jump in health and social services of 9,000 jobs.
"You're still seeing a lot of industries struggling," said Stephen Kagann, chief economist to Gov. George E. Pataki. "But the outlook is positive, and it's positive because financial services is getting stronger."
Statewide, the private-sector job count remained essentially flat, decreasing by 3,900 jobs to 6,918,800 in July, the numbers showed.
The year-to-year percentage decline of 0.3 percent was better than that of the country as a whole, which was 0.4.
"Despite the long-term effects of the prolonged national recession, the September 11 attacks and the unique problems facing Wall Street, both New York State's unemployment rate and private-sector job count held steady this month," said David J. Trzaskos, acting director of the Labor Department's Division of Research and Statistics.

HEADLINE: Signs of Recovery Influenced June Rate Decrease, Fed Says 

BYLINE:  Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's policy panel cut interest rates by a smaller amount than expected in June because of signs of an economic rebound and concerns that a larger cut would be misinterpreted, minutes from the meeting released today showed.
 "Views cited in favor of the quarter-percentage-point easing included the emergence of firmer signs of a possible upturn on economic activity, the near-term prospect of substantial added stimulus and an already accommodative stance of monetary policy," said the minutes of the meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee on June 24-25.. 
 The committee cut short-term rates a quarter of a percentage point at that meeting, even though many market watchers had anticipated a half-point cut. Members worried such a move would be viewed as "a signal that the committee had come to the end of its policy easing moves -- a judgment they were not prepared to make at this time." 
The panel also felt a slower rise in prices was more likely to be a significant concern than inflation "for a considerable period of time."
The vote was 11 to 1 in favor of the quarter-point rate cut, but there was sentiment for both more aggressive and more mild action. Robert Parry, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco, dissented in favor of a larger rate cut.
But the minutes also noted that one unidentified member saw merit in keeping rates unchanged, though the member did not oppose the cut that was finally approved.
The minutes also sought to damp speculation that the committee shied away from a larger move for fear of causing dislocations in money markets already pressured by a federal funds rate at a four-decade low. "No member expressed the opinion that a smaller move should be favored because of concerns about dislocations resulting from a very low level of the overnight interest rate," the minutes said.
The committee also talked about the possible avenues of nontraditional methods to use if cutting rates failed to stimulate the economy. But the panel saw no need to reach a consensus on any specific approach.
