HEADLINE: Newark To Nepal And Back 

BYLINE:  By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
When Sherry B. Ortner was a bookish, secretly rebellious student in high school in Newark in the 1950's, she says, "I didn't even know what anthropology was.
 "I thought it was about insects. But I looked at a description in the Bryn Mawr catalog as a senior, and it sounded really interesting." 
 From that unlikely beginning, Ms. Ortner has become, in the words of The Chronicle of Higher Education, "one of the most prominent anthropologists of her generation." For 30 years she has studied gender and social and cultural theory, helping invent the field of feminist anthropology, winning a MacArthur "genius award" and traveling to the Himalayas to produce major works on Nepal's Sherpa culture and Mount Everest. 
And now, after much journeying, Ms. Ortner, 61, has returned professionally to the place she once dreamed of leaving to explore the world: her alma mater, Weequahic High School. In her new book, "New Jersey Dreaming: Capital, Culture and the Class of '58" (Duke University Press),being published next month, Ms. Ortner dissects the familiar contours of her graduating class.
She said she wanted to explore how her classmates were formed by the world of the 50's, with its rigid demarcations of class, gender and race, as well as how they "moved through history and made something else out of it," whether by burning their bras or marching for civil rights.
A short woman with short, blond hair, and a straight-forward manner, Ms. Ortner speaks with an unaffected New Jersey twang. Last month she was named chairwoman of Columbia University's anthropology department, where she has a spare office in a dreary corner of a scruffy building. She is married to a Columbia colleague, Timothy D. Taylor, a music professor, and has a 23-year-old daughter.
The idea for "New Jersey Dreaming" came to her after she was invited to her 30th-anniversary high school reunion. She had long been fascinated by the way class shapes people's lives, but did not know how or where to examine that idea. She decided to use her own high school class. Her classmates had managed largely to shuck their working- and middle-class origins to become part of the "white overclass," as she says in the book: doctors, lawyers, college professors.
That class of 304 students was 83 percent Jewish, with some black and gentile white students. She got information from about 250 of them for the book and conducted interviews with more than 100. Her own family was pretty typical, middle class and Jewish, she says, her father the owner of a small packaging business, her mother a homemaker. Ms. Ortner recalled not being quite a nerd but more smart than popular, the editor of the yearbook, not a cheerleader. Her big rebellion was secretly dating non-Jewish guys.
Weequahic (pronounced wee-QUAY-ic) High was considered top-notch. This neighborhood in the southwest corner of Newark was an American dream for the up-and-coming. Philip Roth graduated from Weequahic High, one of the city's five public schools. Allen Ginsberg grew up in the neighborhood. Now the whole area is predominantly black and economically struggling.
"I thought it was going to be extremely fraught, going back and talking to people," Ms. Ortner said. "I think I was kind of a snob. When I left high school I thought I was perhaps the only woman who made something of herself. When I left, I was really glad to get out."
But after being out of touch for years, the pleasant surprise was that her former classmates (the book uses pseudonyms) had led interesting lives and were intrigued by her project. Many were keenly aware of being shaped by the prefabricated possibilities of the 50's. In long interviews they talked about their families' class backgrounds, the meaning of success and their identity.
The women were propelled by the women's movement, the African-Americans took advantage of civil rights gains and the Jewish men capitalized on waning anti-Semitism and the blurring of boundaries "between Jewishness and Americanness," as Ms. Ortner put it. Everyone rode the winds of robust economic times. Only 27 percent of the parents of the class of '58 were members of the business and professional classes, compared with 58 percent of their children.
The most important point, she said, is how individual careers are not just a matter of personal timing but are shaped by larger historical forces. "I broke the class into groups connected to movements in the United States," Ms. Ortner said. "Class background had an impact but not enough to understand what happened to people."
Ms. Ortner vividly captured those days when girls took home economics and boys took shop, said some of the classmates who were interviewed. They also said that things like race and sex roles did not really impinge on their consciousness at the time.
"In 1963, with the King 'I have a dream' speech, I started looking at things a little differently," said Norm Willis, a lawyer at J. P.Morgan Chase and an African-American from a blue-collar family. In 1968, when he was hired at Chase, he was told that he would be the first black employee in the banking division. "You look at the old photos and you see no blacks, no Asians, no women," he said of Chase. "The opportunities just weren't there."
Ms. Ortner's own life was certainly changed by the women's movement. "I knew the minute I got to Bryn Mawr that I was not going to be a suburban matron," she said. "They had a lot of feminist ideology there: 'You young women can be anything you want.' "
A 1962 Bryn Mawr graduate, she received her doctorate from the University of Chicago (where one adviser told her that she smiled too much). Teaching jobs at Princeton and Sarah Lawrence followed.
She was just out of graduate school, looking at how anthropology can be used to explore women's roles in society, when she shook up the anthropological world with an article about women's social roles titled "Is Female to Male as Nature Is to Culture?" That 1972 essay set off a fierce debate about whether female subordination is universal and linked to women's biology. At the time she was criticized for overstating the universality of male dominance.
Ms. Ortner now insists that the essay was widely misunderstood, although she concedes that there are some cultures without such emphatic gender asymmetry. "I wasn't really saying it was women's plumbing or genes that keeps them down," she said in a recent interview. "I was saying that because women's bodies are more biologically involved with human reproduction, they appear more mired in nature than men, who seem transcendent." That general pattern, she said, still holds.
From 1977 to 1995 she taught anthropology, then women's studies at the University of Michigan, where she also did a three-year turn as chairwoman of the Anthropology Department, hiring more women and shoring up its national standing. During those years she was back and forth to Tibet, producing two of her three books on Sherpa culture.
Besides throwing out challenges to stimulate feminist anthropology, Ms. Ortner is also credited with expanding "practice theory," an approach that synthesized competing views in anthropology and sociology. One school of analysis held that people's behavior is based on their understanding of the world, the other that people are unaware of how their behavior is determined by political and economic systems. In her empirical studies, Ms. Ortner considered how people are shaped by both internal forces and their societies.
The MacArthur award in 1990 gave her $295,000 over five years and "changed my life," she said. It eased the way as she worked half-time for eight years and raised her daughter, Gwendolyn Kelly, now a graduate student in archaeology.
In 1996, after two years at the University of California at Berkeley, Ms. Ortner was lured to Columbia by Nicholas Dirks, an old Michigan colleague who was rebuilding the faltering anthropology department.
"She is a major force in the field," said Mr. Dirks, her immediate predecessor as head of the department. "Her name and work is at the forefront of many fields, from the Sherpas to practice theory to feminist theory and now American culture. To be so approachable, so modest, so unassuming is extraordinary."
"She has always been critical in translating complicated debates in social theory in ways that are sustained and important," he continued. Her use of practice theory "become so influential that generations of graduate students referred to it," he said.
Faye Ginsburg, director of the Center for Media, Culture and History at New York University, recalled that when she began graduate school in 1979, Ms. Ortner was a key figure among feminists. "She was in the camp that we shouldn't just be talking among ourselves," Ms. Ginsburg said, "but about what anthropology can contribute to the world beyond anthropology."
Now Ms. Ortner is thinking about her next project, perhaps on Hollywood and class or the new American power elite.
"Class is the one big social force that keeps dropping out of the national discourse," she said of her continued fascination with the subject. "We talk about race, we talk about gender. Class is inside race, it's inside gender. I am just really trying to put it back on the table in a way without dropping the other things."

An article in Arts & Ideas on Saturday about Sherry B. Ortner, an anthropologist who has written a book about her high school class, the class of 1958 at Weequahic in Newark, omitted a word in describing the school system at the time. There were five public high schools, not five public schools.

HEADLINE: Large Gain in Factory Output; Consumer Prices Rise Slightly 

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News

 BODY:
Companies showed the biggest gain in production in six months in July, paced by demand for cars, electronics and electricity, and American consumers paid more for goods and services, the government reported yesterday.
 Industrial production at factories, mines and utilities rose 0.5 percent last month, more than expected and the most since January, the Federal Reserve said. Higher costs for gasoline and health care helped lift the Consumer Price Index by 0.2 percent in July, matching the rise in June, the Labor Department said. 
 The reports add to evidence that the economy is improving in the second half. The price figures may ease concern among investors and Fed policy makers that inflation may slow so much that it would hurt companies and sap the recovery.
"Stronger activity will help to support firms' ability to raise prices modestly, very modestly," said Jade Zelnik, chief economist at RBS Greenwich Capital in Connecticut. "It could help firms continue to repair profit margins."
The government was able to produce its reports yesterday because Washington escaped the power blackout that swept through the Northeast and Canada. The University of Michigan, however, delayed its August consumer sentiment report until Tuesday.
Companies increased production as retail sales posted the biggest gain in four months in July and inventories were kept near record lows compared with sales. The proportion of the nation's factory capacity in use rose to 74.5 percent from 74.2 percent in June, the Fed said.
Work at factories, which accounts for almost 90 percent of industrial production, rose 0.2 percent last month after rising 0.3 percent in June. Production of consumer durable goods, which includes automobiles, furniture and electronics, jumped 2.3 percent after increasing 1 percent the previous month.
The rise in the Consumer Price Index matched analysts' forecasts, while the core index, which excludes food and energy, rose 0.2 percent, more than the forecast 0.1 percent. Industrial production exceeded forecasts of a 0.2 percent increase.
So far this year, consumer prices have been rising at a 2.2 percent annual rate. For all of last year, prices rose 2.4 percent, the Labor Department said. Compared with 12 months ago, core prices were up 1.5 percent, matching the smallest annual gains since 1966, which were recorded in June and April.
"Consumer inflation remains restrained," said Steven Wood, principal economist at Insight Economics in Walnut Creek, Calif. "Despite the current acceleration in business activity, the substantial slack in the economy will continue to limit pricing power. Even with faster G.D.P. growth over the second half of the year, further deceleration in core consumer prices is likely."

HEADLINE: The Day the Lights Went Out; 
We're All On the Grid Together

BYLINE:  By Albert-Laszlo Barabasi; Albert-Laszlo Barabasi, professor of physics at the University of Notre Dame, is author of "Linked: The New Science of Networks."

DATELINE: SOUTH BEND, Ind. 

 BODY:
Once power is fully restored, it will take little time to find the culprit: most likely, it will be a malfunctioning switch or fuse, a snapped power line or some other local failure. Somebody will be fired, promotions and raises denied, and lawmakers will draw up legislation guaranteeing that this problem will not occur again.
 Something will be inevitably missed, however, during all this finger-pointing: this week's blackout has little to do with faulty equipment, negligence or bad design. President Bush's call to upgrade the power grid will do little to eliminate power failures. The magnitude of the blackout is rooted in an often ignored aspect of our globalized world: vulnerability due to interconnectivity. 
 In the early days of electricity, all power was produced locally. First each neighborhood, later each city, had its own power plant. Local generators had to satisfy the peak demands of hot summer nights, when everything from air-conditioners to televisions run full power. That means that the generators were idle most of the time outside of peak hours.
That extra capacity was shared as utilities learned to decrease costs by connecting their facilities and helping each other out during peak-demand periods. The current power grid linked up formerly isolated systems with enough wire to stretch to the moon and back. It requires only a computer keystroke to redirect power produced in New York to the Midwest.
With thousands of generators and hundreds of thousands of miles of lines, the network became so interconnected that even on a normal day a single perturbance can be detected thousands of miles away. This created a whole new set of problems and vulnerabilities, the effects of which have been felt by millions in the past two days.
Because electricity cannot be stored, when a line goes down, its power must be shifted to other lines. Most of the time the neighboring lines have no difficulty carrying the extra load. If they do, however, they will also tip and redistribute their increased load to their neighbors.
This occasionally leads to a cascading failure -- a series of lines becomes overburdened and malfunctions in a short period of time. This is exactly what happened in August 1996 when, because of unusually warm weather, a 1,300-megawatt power line in Oregon sagged, hit a tree and went dead. Power was redistributed automatically but the other lines also failed, causing a blackout in 11 Western states and two Canadian provinces.
Cascading failures are common in most complex networks. They take place on the Internet, where traffic is rerouted to bypass malfunctioning routers, occasionally creating denial of service attacks on routers that are not equipped to handle extra traffic. We witnessed one in 1997, when the International Monetary Fund pressured the central banks of several Pacific nations to limit their credit. That started a cascading monetary failure that left behind scores of failed banks and corporations around the world.
Cascading failures are occasionally our ally, however. The American effort to dry up the money supply of terrorist organizations is aimed at crippling terrorist networks. And doctors and researchers hope to induce cascading failures to kill cancer cells.
The effect of power blackouts, economic crises and terrorism can easily be limited or even eliminated if we are willing to cut the links. Strictly local energy production would guarantee that each blackout would also be strictly local.
But severing the ties would also cripple the network. Shutting down international trade would surely eliminate the impact of the Japanese central bank on the American economy, but it would also guarantee a global economic meltdown. Closing our borders would reduce the chance of terrorist attacks, but it would also risk the American dream of diversity and openness.
The events of the past few days -- unwanted side effects of our network society -- are just one of the periodic reminders that we live in a globalized world. While celebrating that everybody on earth is only six handshakes from us, we need to accept that so are their problems and vulnerabilities.
Most failures emerge and evaporate locally, largely unnoticed by the rest of the world. A few, however, percolate through our dense technological and social networks, hitting us from the most unexpected directions. Unless we are willing to cut the connections, the only way to change the world is to improve all nodes and links.

HEADLINE: THE BLACKOUT: BUSINESS LOSSES; 
Insurers Say Most Policies Do Not Cover Power Failure

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH B. TREASTER

 BODY:
Insurance experts said yesterday that there probably was no coverage for most of the business losses resulting from Thursday's power failure, which forced tens of thousands of shops, restaurants and factories to close and widely disrupted airlines and other transportation companies.
 Most policies for individual homes provide some protection for damage from loss of electricity, the experts said, especially for damage to refrigerators and other appliances. But the experts said they expected relatively few claims from homeowners because jolting power surges were not a main part of the latest failure. 
 Lawyers specializing in collecting insurance claims said that neither businesses nor homeowners should assume their losses are not covered, but should carefully review policies. "You may well have enhanced coverage," said David Steuber, a partner in Los Angeles in the firm of Howrey Simon Arnold & White. 
Robert P. Hartwig, the chief economist for the Insurance Information Institute, a trade group in New York, said that most commercial insurance policies specifically ruled out payment for losses for power failures. But, he said, perhaps 10 to 15 percent of commercial insurance customers buy supplementary policies that provide the coverage, compared with 20 percent that have bought terrorism coverage.
The coverage is not included in most policies, he said, because, while major power losses are infrequent, they can be extremely widespread -- as the latest one has been -- and can result in gargantuan losses.
"It would be difficult," he said, "for us to provide the type of coverage we would want to provide at a reasonable price." 
All kinds of businesses were harmed, but researchers said the effect was probably greatest on small businesses -- those with fewer than 50 employees -- which are less likely to have the special coverage. 
"They haven't been doing particularly well because of the overall economy," said William J. Dennis, who is in charge of research at the National Federation of Independent Business, adding, "I don't think probably a lot of folks are covered."
Small businesses, often strapped for cash, routinely buy only the most basic insurance. When disaster strikes, they may become eligible for government assistance, which often consists of low-cost loans and usually leaves the small businesses with unreimbursed losses. 
Mr. Hartwig said the most likely customers for the supplementary coverages were restaurants and florists, and companies that manufacture and store perishable foods and medicines and depend on refrigeration or heaters. But even among those kinds of businesses, he said, supplementary coverage is not widely bought. "People tend to say, 'Whatever it is, it's not going to happen to me,' " he said.
The main hope for insurance customers without supplemental coverage is the discovery of some obscure section in a policy that explicitly provides coverage in certain situations. One example, said Gregory V. Serio, the superintendent of insurance in New York, is coverage in some policies for damage occurring during the restoration of electricity. 
Because of many possible exceptions in the coverage, one Wall Street investment research firm, Fox-Pitt, Kelton, estimated that insurance companies could wind up paying out up to $3 billion. By contrast, the insurance industry lost an estimated $40 billion in the World Trade Center disaster, its biggest single loss ever.
The heaviest losses in the World Trade Center attack were about $11 billion in claims for the interruption of normal business and the loss of income. Mr. Hartwig said about 80 percent of the businesses in New York had that coverage at the time of the attack. Afterward, he said, some that had gone without the coverage bought it and others extended their coverage.
But business interruption insurance will not help those who lost sales because of the power failure, Mr. Hartwig said. Because the failure itself is not covered, he said, other ramifications like the loss of sales are not covered either.
On the other hand, in cases where the power failure caused a fire or where high temperatures after the loss of air-conditioning set off water sprinklers and caused water damage, the standard fire and water coverage in every commercial property policy would pay. Any business interruption resulting from the fire or water damage would also be paid even though a loss of sales or extra business expenses would not be reimbursed because of the power failure alone.
Mr. Hartwig said he expected a surge in sales of protection against power failures. "After earthquakes, we sell more earthquake insurance," Mr. Hartwig said.

HEADLINE: THE BLACKOUT: NEW JERSEY; 
Economic Toll 'Devastating,' A Troubled McGreevey Says

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI

DATELINE: TRENTON, Aug. 15 

 BODY:
Electrical service was restored to nearly all New Jersey homes by this afternoon, but the state's roadways, beaches and tourist destinations were still coping with serious disruptions from Thursday's blackout.
 Curtailed rail service led to sporadic traffic jams on the New Jersey Turnpike and the Garden State Parkway, particularly as the weekly pilgrimage of beachgoers headed for the Jersey Shore in the late afternoon. In Atlantic City, casino operators said their business had been slowed because some tour bus companies had been unable to ferry gamblers from New York City. 
 Gov. James E. McGreevey, who interrupted his own vacation at Cape May to respond to the situation, lifted the state of emergency this afternoon and ordered turnpike and parkway officials to resume charging tolls, which were suspended on Thursday. But Mr. McGreevey said he was troubled that the failure of the electrical grid left a million homes without power on Thursday afternoon, especially because the North American Electric Reliability Council, which has established rules for managing the system, had repeatedly assured state officials that it could prevent widespread power failures.
Mr. McGreevey, Gov. John G. Rowland of Connecticut and Gov. George E. Pataki of New York demanded that federal officials investigate the cause of the blackout.
"When there is a crisis, that crisis must not be allowed to trip and cascade to affect the entire Northeast portion of the United States," Mr. McGreevey said this afternoon at a news briefing outside the ferry terminal in Hoboken. "There was a devastating toll. Not only in terms of the business community, but to the State Police, National Guard and Office of Emergency Management."
Mr. McGreevey said he would also request financing from the Federal Emergency Management Agency to help pay for the cost of responding to the blackout.
State officials said there were no known fatalities attributable to the blackout, and the governor said the state's emergency response plan, which was revamped after the 9/11 terrorist attacks, operated smoothly.
But even as lights and air-conditioners resumed working across the state, there were abundant signs of turmoil. Public Service Electric and Gas, the state's largest utility, reported that power had been restored to all but 5,000 homes by 2 p.m. But the company was nonetheless urging customers to use electricity sparingly to avoid overburdening the system.
Newark Liberty International Airport was operating, said Greg Trevor, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, although many flights were delayed.
PATH trains and New York Waterway ferries were operating on normal schedules, but New Jersey Transit and Amtrak trains offered only limited service. After the upheaval of Thursday, when thousands of New Jersey commuters endured epic journeys home, many heeded the advice of Mr. McGreevey and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York City, and took today off.
"I spent eight hours making it back last night," said Brian Frank of Ewing Township, whose trip home from an insurance firm in Manhattan included a four-mile walk, a cab, a bus, a ferry and a three-hour crawl down the turnpike as part of a group that squeezed into the car of a man he had met in a parking lot in Hoboken. "That's enough for one week."

HEADLINE: THE BLACKOUT: COMMUNICATIONS; 
Cellphone Failures Cause Many to Question Systems

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN and MATT RICHTEL

 BODY:
As cellular telephone carriers labored to restore service yesterday, voices of concern were raised in Washington and elsewhere about the continued fragility of the nation's wireless networks even as the public grows more dependent upon them.
 Cellular service remained spotty throughout much of the Northeast and parts of the Midwest yesterday, despite the restoration of electrical power in many of the areas affected by Thursday's blackout, as heavy usage and continued problems at some transmitter stations continued to tax the system. 
 Service in New York City, which had been especially hard hit by power losses and high calling volume, had returned to normal by yesterday afternoon as power was restored across most of the city, according to local cellular carriers.
But the industry has drawn criticism for its networks' performance after the blackout, particularly in comparison to the land-line telephone system, which generally stayed in service. 
An aide to Representative Billy Tauzin, Republican of Louisiana and chairman of the House Commerce Committee, said yesterday that Mr. Tauzin wanted an investigation. "The big question we want answered is why there aren't better backup systems," the aide, Ken Johnson, said. 
After coming under fire for its massive service failures in the hours after the Sept. 11, 2001, terrorist attack, the cellular industry, which is only partly regulated, had promised to upgrade its networks to better handle emergencies. Janee Briesemeister, a senior policy analyst for Consumers Union, said the service disruptions during theblackout proved that cellular companies required more public oversight. 
"It appears they didn't fulfill their promises," she said. "The industry markets cellphones as good for emergencies."
Assessments yesterday indicated that the number of cellular transmitters that failed was greater than industry officials had estimated late Thursday, in part because electrical power remained off longer than many had expected. Cell sites, which are essentially radio receiving and transmitting stations, generally have backup batteries that last only several hours before they need to be recharged. 
"The cellular network is designed for power outages of minimal duration," said Michael Grossi, a principal at Adventis, a Boston-based management consulting firm that works for mobile telephone providers.
"The system isn't fragile," he said. "But it has an Achilles' heel."
The land-line telephone system has a primary advantage over wireless ones because its network of wires can carry a small electrical power current along with conversations. As a result, many fewer, centrally located backup generators can keep the wired network operating. But if the electric utility system fails with the cellular network each cell site needs its own source of backup power. While batteries can work for short blackouts, industry analysts say it may not be economically feasible to have backup generators for every one of the hundreds of cell sites necessary for a city the size of New York.
Mr. Grossi said that the same economic limits meant that cellular networks are not built to sustain the huge spikes in traffic that can occur during emergencies. Verizon Wireless said its network experienced four times ordinary call volume on Thursday in Manhattan, while Sprint PCS in Manhattan had three times the normal call volume. 
During events like the blackout, Mr. Grossi said, the antennas at the various cell sites are unable to accept the sudden traffic surge, which he compared to a highway on-ramp becoming jammed with automobiles. Nor is various other equipment in the network built to sustain such bursts of activity, he said.
"The system isn't designed for that kind of wear and tear, or that radical of an event," Mr. Grossi said. It simply would not be cost effective for wireless carriers to gird the networks against such anomalies.
And yet, Mr. Grossi said, in light of the public's increasing reliance on the wireless networks, the companies need to find more effective power backup for their systems.
"With more and more people moving from wire line to wireless, there is probably a greater need to have more redundant systems," he said. 
Over the past several years, a small but growing number of people have completely given up their land lines in favor of using cellular phones exclusively. That trend is expected to continue, according to the Yankee Group, a telecommunications consulting company in Boston, which estimates that nearly 3 percent of telephone users have made wireless phones their primary telephone.
Andrea Linskey, a spokeswoman for Verizon Wireless, said that a number of cell sites ran out of battery power during the blackout, predominately in Manhattan and Detroit, although she declined to say how many. She said that the company deployed generators in some instances to revive dead sites. 
Sprint PCS said that it, like Verizon, had backup batteries at each cell site, but when those batteries expired, so did the sites. Dan Wilinsky, a Sprint PCS spokesman, said that the company had sent trucks with mobile generators to various cell sites to revive them. But even with a generator on the scene, once a site is dead it can take several hours to recharge the batteries.
Customers of the wireless carriers T-Mobile and Cingular were also affected in the blackout areas -- particularly in New York City and other parts of the Northeast, where Cingular uses T-Mobile's network. 
But users of Cingular's wireless Mobitex network, which transmits data to BlackBerry's and other hand-held devices, were well served during the blackout. Federal Express, which uses the network to track packages in the United States, said it did not experience any problems.
The Mobitex network is based on pager technology and has greater backup capabilities.

HEADLINE: Herb Offers Hope to Africans Ravaged by Malaria 

BYLINE:  By MARC LACEY

DATELINE: BUJUMBURA, Burundi 

 BODY:
Surrounded by scores of ailing children at a makeshift health clinic, a white-coated nurse moved quickly from one to the next, putting his hand on each little forehead.
 "I don't use a thermometer at first," said the nurse, Theodore Bitangi, who has grown used to the huge crowds. "Just by touching I can tell if they're too hot." 
 The rebels who have rampaged through Burundi for the last decade may seem this country's most ominous killers, with their automatic weapons and rocket-propelled grenades. Even more dangerous, it turns out, are malarial mosquitoes, which thrive in Lake Tanganyika and buzz across Burundi with a vengeance exceptional even on a continent where malaria kills about a million people a year. 
An epidemic from late 2000 to the summer of 2001 generated 3 million cases in a country of 6.5 million people. Some 85 percent of people live in areas at risk of the disease, often overshadowed by AIDS, which preys on those who have not yet built up natural defenses, particularly children. 
The rate of resistance to common malarial drugs like chloroquine and sulfadoxine-pyrimethamine has grown so high in Burundi that they are now deemed ineffectual here. 
The severity of the problem has placed Burundi in the vanguard of a new treatment, one that health professionals are saying could be as life-saving as the most far-reaching peace accord. 
Increasingly, health experts are recommending a combination treatment, called artemisinin, that comes from a Chinese herb. Burundi is one of just a handful of African countries to adopt the method officially. 
The approach is costlier than others and requires more pills, leading some critics, especially in the United States, to question whether it is right for the remotest reaches of Africa. 
But as it has become clear that other approaches are failing, artemisinin has emerged as the consensus choice among the World Health Organization, the United Nations Children's Fund and others. Doctors Without Borders began issuing the pills in Burundi several years ago, even before the government finally endorsed them last year. 
Still, the treatment does nothing to stop the spread of the disease. The first line of defense is keeping the mosquito off human skin. That is no easy task. 
Most Africans do not bother with the mosquito repellant creams or prophylactic drugs that foreign visitors insist on. For those living in affected areas for long periods, insecticide-treated nets remain the cheapest and most effective way of containing the spread of malaria, experts say. But only about 15 percent of African children sleep under nets and only 2 percent have their nets doused with insecticide, according to a survey by Unicef. 
So the feverish and crying children continue to show up every morning at clinics like this one in the Kiname neighborhood of Bujumbura.
A hand on the forehead detects the hint of a fever. Then a rapid test allows the medical staff to know within minutes whether the mosquito-borne parasite that causes malaria, Plasmodium falciparum, has infected a patient.
A child's finger is pricked, a drop of blood is put on a plastic card, and much like an at-home pregnancy test, a clear indication of yes or no appears. This can be done even in the most remote places. 
"It's positive," said Esperance Simire, a nurse who tested Brice Ndagizimana at the Kiname clinic. Just 15 months old, the boy had already tested positive for malaria four previous times, said his mother, Lydia Ndayisaba, 21, who cradled the listless baby close to her.
For Brice and other youngsters, the disease is life threatening. But malaria affects Ms. Ndayisaba no more severely than the flu. She has come down with it at least twice a year for as long as she can remember.
Still, the malaria symptoms weaken victims so they are more vulnerable to other ailments. The disease also saps already ailing African economies by keeping workers home in bed.
"There are some who say that without getting rid of malaria you don't have enough healthy workers to sustain an economy," said Dr. David Olson, an American who is the medical coordinator for the French chapter of Doctors Without Borders in Bujumbura. "It costs to treat them again and again, and they're always off work."
The civil war in Burundi and other conflicts across Africa only compound malaria's impact. The tens of thousands of people in Burundi's hillsides displaced by the war are often forced to sleep in the open air, with the mosquitoes. Relief workers are often unable to reach war-torn areas in the interior of the country to distribute bed nets and teach locals the basics about the disease. 
"I think it's malaria," said Victoire Nyandwi, 30, thrusting her shrieking 9-month-old boy at a visitor to the clinic. "He's shaking and he throws up a lot. He's getting pale and he stopped taking milk."
Asked how her son Shadrak had come down with the ailment, Ms. Nyandwi offered the same explanation as many other mothers: drinking dirty water. While that causes many ailments in developing countries, malaria is not one of them. 
But one thing no African mother has to be taught is how quickly malaria can kill. They have seen too many babies who are healthy one day and unable to move the next. When an intense fever hits, mothers strap their infants to their backs and trek to the nearest clinic, only sometimes making it in time. 
Little Brice was badly dehydrated when he arrived the other day, and the nurses decided his condition was so severe that he needed to be treated with a malarial drug intravenously. He yelped when Mr. Bitangi, the nurse, tried to insert a needle in a vein in his tiny arm. He yelped even more when the nurse opted instead for the vein in his temple.
"It's over, it's over," Cecile Richard, the field coordinator for Doctors Without Borders, told Brice gently, stroking his forehead. "You're going to be O.K." 
As the boy starred wide-eyed at those who were treating him, his face covered with sweat, Ms. Richard relished the expected arrival of the new antimalaria drugs. "If we can control malaria," she said, "we can focus on everything else."

GRAPHIC: Photo: A nurse tests children for malaria in Bujumbura. Resistance to common malarial drugs is so high in Burundi that they are now considered ineffectual there, placing the country in the vanguard of a new treatment. (Photo by Guillaume Bonn for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INSIDE 

 BODY:
 THE POWER SYSTEM B2-4
Restarting power after a staggering blackout is a matter of precise choreography among often-distant power generators. A misstep can send the system back into the black. Through the years, improvements that might have prevented the blackout have been largely ignored, engineers and others with expert knowledge of the North American system of transmitting electricity said. When power does stop flowing, some people are certain to remember two things, the second of which is the answer to "Where were you when the lights went on?"

TRANSPORTATION B5
The New York region's transportation system began to stagger back to life, with one formidable exception: the subways. For the most part, commuters tended to stay away from the city, taking advantage of the first day of a windfall three-day weekend. At airports from New York to Los Angeles, travelers seemed to spend more time camping out than boarding planes. Swarms of international travelers were stranded without water for a second day at John F. Kennedy Airport in Queens.

THE ECONOMIC IMPACT B6-7
In terms of the effect on the economy, the blackout is nothing more than a bad snowstorm, economists said. But for some businesses, the impact may be greater: insurance experts said there probably was no coverage for blackout-related losses. Broadway slowly crept back to life ("Gypsy" and "The Producers," were sold out). Cellphone service rebounded, too, but not without concerns about the fragility of the nation's wireless networks. Restaurant owners around New York returned to find unspeakable puddles and odors in their walk-in refrigerators.

THE NEW YORK SCENE B8-11
The lights were out, but hey! Was that the Big Dipper? There were other trade-offs. You could see the moon clearly, but you couldn't get cash from a cash machine. Titanic mountains of pungent trash baked in the summer sun, but an armada of garbage trucks, litter basket collection trucks and street sweepers advanced to make pickups. High-rise dwellers learned to appreciate what electricity can do for water pressure -- provide it -- yet the blackout did not encourage an onslaught of crime, just as in 1977.

MEDICAL CARE B12
At hospitals, backup generators were the difference between disaster and business as usual. The blackout cost one woman the chance for a liver transplant; the donor liver was taken to Pittsburgh instead, for another patient at a hospital with a reliable power supply.

POLITICS B13-14
After a deliberative step into the spotlight, President Bush offered details, promises of aid and a pitch to improve the nation's electricity grid. One supporter said Mr. Bush is sensitive that local officials, like Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg of New York, should be on the air first. Mr. Bloomberg, even if many of his constituents were unable to see or hear him through the normal media channels, has been energetic in trying to project calm in the face of adversity. In Congress, lawmakers said the blackout would give new importance to elements of an energy plan aimed at upgrading the power grid.

THE NATION B15
Lakeside Avenue in Cleveland, right across from the football stadium on the downtown waterfront, was strangely barren. But though the empty streets, deserted parks and darkened offices seemed strange on a weekday afternoon, Cleveland was, in truth, returning to normal. Government offices were closed, as were many shops. But yes, the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame was open.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Blackout's Greatest Cost May Be Just Inconvenience
For all the inconvenience and disruption that the blackout of 2003 inflicted on the Northeast, the damage to the national economy is not likely to be any worse than damage from a bad snowstorm -- a blip in the statistics that soon disappears.
 The potential for denting the nation's economic growth came not from New York, but from Detroit and Cleveland, where power might not be fully restored until Monday, disrupting production at the auto assembly and parts plants in those cities. Page B6. 

Many experts say that it is far too early to calculate the overall economic effects of the blackout. But as always in New York, the blackout produced economic winners and losers; and as always, hustle helped. B1.

Insurance experts said there probably was no coverage for most of the business losses resulting from the power failure across the Northeast that forced tens of thousands of shops and restaurants and factories to shut down and widely disrupted airline operations and other transportation companies. B6.

As cellular telephone carriers tried to restore service, voices of concern were raised in Washington and elsewhere about the continued fragility of the nation's wireless networks even as the public grows more dependent upon them. B7.

Investigation at American Capital
A company that is dependent on repeated access to the capital markets may be more vulnerable than most to any hint of a problem. That may be the problem confronting American Capital Strategies, an investment company that reports profits from loans to companies it controls but does not report the operating results of those companies to its investors. Floyd Norris: Market Place. C2.

Reports Offer Sign of Recovery
Companies showed the biggest gain in production in six months in July, paced by demand for cars, electronics and electricity, and American consumers paid more for goods and services, the government reported. C2.

Questions for a Coca-Cola Supplier
The Lancer Corporation, a major equipment supplier to Coca-Cola, said that federal prosecutors in Atlanta had sought information from the company in connection with a criminal investigation involving Coke. Lancer said that it intended to cooperate with federal investigators. The government is investigating fraud accusations raised by a former Coke employee who is suing the company in state and federal court for wrongful termination. C3.

Schrager Hotel Files Chapter 11
Ian Schrager's Clift Hotel in San Francisco filed a petition to reorganize under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection after it could not obtain agreements from all bondholders about a proposed refinancing plan. C2.

Tax Protester Challenges U.S.
Irwin Schiff, a proponent of the idea that people are not required to pay income taxes, is challenging a Justice Department request that he be put behind bars for civil contempt. It says he is flouting an order to stop promoting his "zero tax return," which he says allows anyone to legally list no income and so stop paying taxes. Mr. Schiff has tried to place the focus of the case on the fact that a $150 "Commemorative Injunction Packet" that is being sold on his Web site is made up of public records. A7.

Dana Sues Hostile Suitor
The Dana Corporation filed a lawsuit against the ArvinMeritor Corporation, contending that it violated a 2001 confidentiality agreement between the companies. The lawsuit, filed in the court of common pleas in Lucas County, Ohio, seeks to prevent ArvinMeritor from proceeding with an offer for Dana. C2.

Centerpulse Bid Endorsed
The Swiss medical technology company Centerpulse closed the bidding war between Smith & Nephew of Britain and Zimmer Holdings of the United States by recommending its shareholders accept Zimmer's $3.2 billion cash and share takeover offer. C3.

HEADLINE: THE BLACKOUT: THE ARTS; 
Broadway Is Back, but Many Museums Stay Dark

BYLINE:  By JESSE McKINLEY; Ben Sisario and Emily Eakin contributed to this article.

 BODY:
Broadway and the city's other cultural institutions slowly crept back to life yesterday after across-the-board cancellations caused by Thursday's blackout. 
 All 23 productions currently running on Broadway performed as scheduled last night, after power was restored to most of the Theater District just past noon. Several sold out, including "Gypsy" and "The Producers." 
 Some economic damage, however, had already been done. Jed Bernstein, the president of the League of American Theaters and Producers, Broadway's major trade group, said yesterday that the industry had probably lost $1 million from Thursday's canceled performances, though producers hoped that some patrons would exchange their tickets rather than ask for refunds. 
Insurance may cover some losses, though many companies require a theater production to miss at least two performances before a policy takes effect. Ticket exchanges may also prove difficult for several productions scheduled to close this month, including the hit revival of "Long Day's Journey Into Night" and "Man of La Mancha," both of which close on Aug. 31. 
Still, Mr. Bernstein seemed positively bullish that theatergoers would return in droves after an evening devoid of song and dance. 
"I think the shows will be sold out tonight," he said late yesterday afternoon. "I think every ticket out there will get bought by someone who is either hunting for a deal or who has had their travel plans delayed."
Other cultural institutions, however, were still struggling to reopen, including the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Whitney Museum, both on the Upper East Side; after being closed yesterday, both were expected to reopen today. The New Museum of Contemporary Art, in SoHo, was also shut yesterday.
Elsewhere, a Thursday night performance of Mozart's opera "Il Re Pastore" at the Mostly Mozart Festival at La Guardia High School near Lincoln Center was canceled, but the Divine Divas of Oriental Bellydance went on as planned at 5:30 P.M. in the main plaza, as part of Lincoln Center Out of Doors festival.
Other performers also seemed to embrace the show-must-go-on ethos. At Central Park's SummerStage, the folk rock group the Indigo Girls played for some 1,300 people who braved the dark stroll through the park, said Alexa Birdsong, the executive producer of the series. Once they arrived, fans were treated to a 45-minute set and -- of all things -- lights, fueled by a diesel generator. (A spokeswoman for SummerStage said that another Indigo Girls concert would be scheduled for a later date, and that anyone with tickets or stubs for the original show would be able to get in free.)
And even as Broadway went completely dark on Thursday night, some smaller theaters thrived. The Upright Citizens Brigade Theater, a improvisational comedy haven on West 26th Street, was part of a patch of lucky buildings in Chelsea that had full power, even while most of the city sat in darkness. As the sun set, members of the troupe took to the streets with megaphones announcing the theater's attractions -- "We have power and air conditioning," was the gist -- while the theater's concession stand did a brisk business in cold beer and soda. 
Still, for others, quirks of geography were proving vexing. Even as some uptown neighborhoods got their lights back in the morning, downtown neighborhoods were still without power late yesterday afternoon, and many Off Broadway theaters in those areas remained closed. 
At the New York International Fringe Festival, which performs in 20 theaters in Manhattan, yesterday's performances were canceled. 
Elena K. Holy, the festival's producing artistic director, said several Fringe productions had just finished on Thursday afternoon when the lights went out. "It was surreal," she said. "The house lights went down. And they just stayed down." Ms. Holy said today's Fringe performances should go on as scheduled.
On Broadway, meanwhile, officials were still in customer-service overdrive. The TKTS discount ticket booth in Duffy Square opened at 10 a.m. yesterday -- five hours earlier than usual -- so customers could return tickets they were unable to use on Thursday. 
Michael Kane, the head treasurer for TKTS, said the ticket booth sold between 2,000 and 3,000 tickets worth between $100,000 and $150,000 on Thursday afternoon before the blackout forced it to close early. At midday yesterday, Mr. Kane said refunds had been given on some 800 of those tickets. 
And true to Mr. Bernstein's prediction, some theatergoers were indeed at the booth looking for bargains, though the selection of Broadway fare there was thinner than usual, with discounted tickets for only six shows.
Some customers weren't taking the disruption in good humor. Kwang Uk Suh, 30, a client representative for I.B.M. from Seoul, had just received a refund for six tickets to "The Phantom of the Opera" but still wasn't happy. 
A first-time visitor to Manhattan, Mr. Suh said he had planned to take five clients to the Broadway musical on Thursday, but instead he and his guests endured two anxious hours stuck in a subway tunnel.
"We came to hate New York City," Mr. Suh said. "For foreigners, it's kind of a dream to visit New York City. But the power was gone, and we spent a dark night in the hotel. It was really awful." 
But for others, the blackout provided unexpected pleasure. James Ludwig, who lives with his wife just off Times Square, said they had planned to see the Broadway revival of "Gypsy" on Thursday. After their show was canceled, the couple decided to go for a stroll instead. 
"We figured it would be the only time in this century that we'd see what Times Square was like without the lights," Mr. Ludwig said. "What we saw last night, we'll probably never see again."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Les Goodson played his tenor sax yesterday evening in Times Square, where lights were back on. Several Broadway shows were sold out last night. (Photo by Willie J. Allen Jr./The new York Times)

HEADLINE: A City in Darkness: Reminders and Lessons; 
Short-Term Gain

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 The blackout is the inevitable outcome of a lack of investment caused by the fact that electric utilities historically pay high dividends rather than invest in new plant. 
 The dividend-tax changes of the Bush administration induce corporate America to adopt the same "short-term dividend gain over long-term productivity-enhancing investment" philosophy. Dollars that go into dividends do not go into the kind of infrastructure modernization that could prevent blackouts.
The dividend-tax break gives investors a choice: the instant gratification of dividends over the productivity-enhancing and job-creating effects of long-term development. 
How will America's economy fare when there are intellectual blackouts at Intel, Microsoft and I.B.M. because their investors think that dividend-tax breaks are more important than ever-faster chips and more productive software?

PAT ROGERS
Allentown, Pa., Aug. 15, 2003

GRAPHIC: Drawing (Drawing by Lauren Redniss) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: THE BLACKOUT: THE GRID; 
Warnings Long Ignored On Aging Electric System

BYLINE:  By DAVID FIRESTONE and ANDREW C. REVKIN

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 

 BODY:
For years, the nation's electrical engineers and planners have warned that the North American system of transmitting electricity was becoming the orphan of the digital era, approaching a serious failure if not significantly upgraded.
 For the most part, however, their pleas to improve the system have been ignored, mired in political and regional disputes, or caught up in debates about regulating private industry. As a result, experts said today, improvements that might have prevented the largest blackout in American history have stalled. 
 "This outage will cost consumers millions of dollars, and it would have been far less expensive if we had just made the system robust enough to meet their needs," said Peggy Welsh, senior vice president of the Consumer Energy Council of America, a research group that represents residential and business consumers of power. "We have a system built 50 years ago for an analog society, and it can't handle the demands of a digital society." 
It was five years ago that a federal task force of prominent experts warned the Department of Energy that the reliability of the electrical system was based on a mishmash of voluntary standards, and that Washington needed to impose mandatory rules on the electric industry.
"Failure to act," the task force wrote, "will leave substantial parts of North America at unacceptable risk." Its report was written at the Energy Department's request by prominent engineers and policy makers.
As recently as last month, however, the Energy Department was saying exactly the same thing. While electricity demand has shot up by 25 percent since 1990, construction of transmission systems has declined by 30 percent, the department said. 
"The nation's aging electromechanical electric grid cannot keep pace with innovations in the digital information and telecommunications network," the department said in a report that called for massive investment by the industry and government in a new system by 2030. "Power outages and power quality disturbances cost the economy billions of dollars annually. America needs an electric superhighway to support our information superhighway."
Standards for a more reliable system were not opposed by the industry, and were included in an energy bill that came before Congress in 2001. The bill never passed because of disputes over matters like drilling in the Alaskan wilderness and efficiency standards for cars. Such disputes are holding up a similar bill that is pending in Congress.
The exact reason why a single failure in the Midwest on Thursday afternoon led to a disastrous cascade of blackouts has still not been determined. Industry officials said that an elaborate set of rules and procedures has been developed to allow one regional system to automatically cut itself off from others when a failure occurs. Those rules are voluntary, however, and are followed to different extents by different regions. 
The 1998 task force on electricity reliability recommended that the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission be given legal authority to impose rules on the industry. It also said that several newly developed technologies were available to prevent single failures from expanding into widespread blackouts, if utilities could be persuaded to invest in them.
The commission, however, was never given the authority to impose rules on the industry by Congress, and few utilities have made significant investments in their transmission systems. Philip Sharp, a former Indiana congressman and Harvard lecturer on energy policy who headed the 1998 task force, said that deregulation had led to a patchwork of rules that gave some companies an incentive to improve their systems but discouraged others. "There's a crazy-quilt system of rules that govern markets in different parts of the country," he said. "It shapes what people invest in, and whether they will make upgrades in their transmission systems and get their power plants online. It's foolish not to have a system in place that could reduce our risk for these kinds of events."
Experts also said that energy deregulation, which has been at the heart of most disputes over the future of power in this country, has produced great strains on the system even at times when demand has not reached its peak by providing incentives to build more generating plants without encouraging the building of transmission systems. In the days of regulation, a company would recoup its investment in a generator through rates set by a state commission. Now, private companies make money on generators by selling power, giving them an incentive to produce more than transmission facilities can handle, some experts say.
"Since deregulation, people have been pushing the system too hard," said Dr. Richard Rosen, a utility planning expert at the Tellus Institute, a research group in Boston. "They tend to overload it to too great an extent. Instead of loading lines to close to 100 percent, there needs to be some extra room allowed for problems."
The strain on transmission capacity is particularly acute in New York State, which is known in the industry for having far too few high-voltage power lines. A report issued this spring by the New York Independent System Operator, which manages the state's power grid, said the state's reliability rules were developed to respond to the blackouts of 1965 and 1977, and have not been changed since then. "New York has stayed just ahead of potential reliability problems for the past three years by utilizing some stopgap measures and by driving the existing electrical infrastructure harder and harder," the report said.
Among other factors, community resistance to new lines has been high and continues to prevent new lines from being built, particularly in high-density areas like the northeast. While the federal government can step in and insist on construction of natural gas pipelines, it has no such power related to electrical transmission lines. "People want more power, but they don't want those lines," said Stephen Floyd, a nuclear engineer and a vice president of the Nuclear Energy Institute, the Washington lobby for the nuclear-power industry. "Something's got to give sometime, because the system is really reaching its capacity in terms of what you'd like to have for a margin of safety."
One top power company executive in New York State said that some of the state's biggest power producers actually prefer an inadequate transmission system, because it gives them a captive market and the ability to charge more. At the same time, he said, state regulatory officials have no interest in taking the political heat from community residents for approving new lines. Other states, like Texas and Virginia, routinely approve new transmission systems to go with generators, he said.
Better conservation is another way to reduce the load on power systems, but when deregulation divided the power industry between generators and purveyors of electricity, it also reduced the incentive for utilities to entice customers to conserve, many energy experts said.
Now, in deregulated states, plant owners tend to focus on supplying the most profitable electricity -- produced during periods of peak demand -- while owners of distribution systems, experts say, have to pare costs and keep cables and other equipment running.
Other energy experts say there are many effective ways to insure stability, mostly involving either distributing the generation of power so that less needs to flow long distances or reducing electricity use, particularly in peak periods. "This event underscores the need to reduce the overload on the system, and there are other ways to do it besides building new transmission capacity," said Ralph Cavanagh, energy program director for the Natural Resources Defense Council, an environmental group. "There are elegant ways of doing it, such as electronic controls that allow the system to carry more power safely, or increasing standards for efficiency of air conditioners, which consume a third of the peak demand. The challenge is picking the best solution."

HEADLINE: THE BLACKOUT: THE ECONOMY; 
The Greatest Cost Over the Long Term May Be Inconvenience

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
For all the inconvenience and disruption inflicted by the great blackout of 2003, the damage to the national economy is not likely to be any worse than that from a bad snowstorm -- a blip in the statistics that soon disappears. 
 The potential for doing more serious damage to economic growth comes not from New York, but from Detroit and Cleveland, where power might not be fully restored until next week. 
 "Blackouts are economically like snowstorms," said Mark M. Zandi, the chief economist at Economy.com, referring to the 1965 and 1977 power failures, as well as this latest one. "They are a nuisance, but not a measurable one in the statistics that record the year's economic activity." 
Airlines, restaurants and retail stores have clearly been hurt. But for the economy as a whole, blackouts and snowstorms mostly delay economic activity and rearrange it, taking from one sector and giving to another, economists say. For every suit not sold at Saks, a generator may be sold at Lowe's to someone newly interested in protection from the next blackout.
The lost power closed retail stores and halted Internet shopping, canceling purchases or delaying them until next week or next month. The same thing happened after the blizzard in the Northeast on Feb. 17, which was the Washington's Birthday holiday, one of the biggest shopping days of the year. The lost business was enough to make national retail sales for February dip by $4.3 billion. But in March they rebounded, rising by $6.3 billion.
Much of the revenue from canceled airline flights is recovered; the disappointed ticketholders eventually travel. Their tickets are mostly "prebooked and nonrefundable," said Robert W. Mann, an aviation industry consultant based in Port Washington, N.Y. What the airlines do not recover, though, are the considerable sums for hotel rooms and meals for passengers whose flights are canceled, Mr. Mann said.
Restaurants and theaters forced to close suffer a similar loss in revenue. It may be partly offset in several ways. Thousands of police officers, for example, will get handsome overtime checks, which they will spend, said Lee Price, director of research at the Economic Policy Institute. Spending is also likely to rise for flashlights and batteries, and for improvements to the nation's power grid.
"It is a wash, and you really cannot see it in the aggregate statistics," Mr. Price said. Or as Chris Varvares, the president of Macroeconomic Advisers, a St. Louis consulting and forecasting firm, put it: "The blackout is going to be lost in the rounding."
The blip in the national economic statistics from the power failure this week is likely to show up not in retail sales, as it did after the February snowstorm, but in the industrial production numbers for August, including the output of utilities. Manufacturers consume 40 percent of the electricity generated in the United States, according to the National Association of Manufacturers, and the blackout almost certainly delayed production at dozens of plants.
Among the manufacturers, the Big Three automakers were forced to shut plants in Michigan. Operating at less than full capacity, they have been producing 11,000 to 13,000 cars a day, according to Rebecca Lindland, senior automotive analyst at Global Insight, a consulting and data-gathering firm. The power failure meant the loss of about 18,000 vehicles from late Thursday through yesterday, a drop likely to show up as a downward murmur in the industrial production report for August.
But that is probably a good thing, Ms. Lindland said. Assuming the blackout does not extend into Monday, the Big Three might actually benefit from the opportunity to reduce excess inventories. The industry has 66 days' worth of sales, with a disproportionate share being vehicles made by General Motors, Ford and DaimlerChrysler. The norm is 55 to 65 days.
"The blackout does potentially fix some excess stockpiling problems that the Big Three might have," Ms. Lindland said.

HEADLINE: Idi Amin, a Brutal Dictator Of Uganda, Is Dead at 80 

BYLINE:  AP

DATELINE: JIDDAH, Saudi Arabia, Saturday, Aug. 16 

 BODY:
Idi Amin called himself "a pure son of Africa," but his bizarre and murderous eight years as president of Uganda typified the worst of the continent's military dictatorships. He was 80.
 Mr. Amin died today at King Faisal Specialist hospital, a hospital official said. He had been hospitalized on life-support systems since July 18. He was in a coma and suffering from high blood pressure when he was admitted to the hospital. Later, hospital staff said he suffered kidney failure. 
 A onetime heavyweight boxing champ and soldier in the British colonial army, Mr. Amin seized power on Jan. 25, 1971, overthrowing President Milton Obote while Mr. Obote was abroad.
What followed was a reign of terror laced with buffoonery and a flirtation with Palestinian terrorism that led to the daring 1976 Israeli raid to rescue hijacked hostages in his country.
Mr. Obote once called Mr. Amin "the greatest brute an African mother has ever brought to life." President Jimmy Carter said events in Uganda during Mr. Amin's rule "disgusted the entire civilized world."
Ugandans initially welcomed Mr. Amin's rise to power, and his frequent taunting of Britain, the former colonial ruler of much of Africa, often played well on the continent. But his penchant for the cruel and extravagant became evident in 1972, when he expelled tens of thousands of Asians who had controlled the country's economy. Deprived of its business class, the East African nation plummeted into economic chaos.
Mr. Amin declared himself president-for-life of his landlocked country of 24 million, awarded himself an array of medals and ran the country with an iron fist, killing real and imagined enemies.
Human rights groups say that from 100,000 to 500,000 people were killed during his eight-year rule.
Idi Amin was born into the small Kakwa tribe in Koboko, a village in northwestern Uganda. His mother was a self-proclaimed sorceress of the Lugbara tribe and he was in his 30's before he had regular contact with his peasant father.
A semiliterate school dropout, Mr. Amin boasted that he knew "more than doctors of philosophy because as a military man I know how to act."
He was a well-regarded officer at the time of Uganda's independence from Britain in 1962, and Obote made him military chief of staff in 1966.
The 250-pound president called himself Dada, or "Big Daddy," and in 1975 was even chosen as for the one-year rotating chairmanship of the Organization of African Unity despite objections from some member states.
But mismanagement and corruption of his entourage drove Uganda into an abyss and its economy tumbled toward subsistence levels. The United States and Britain severed ties during Amin's rule.
His overreaching designs led to his downfall after his troops failed in their attempt to annex parts of Tanzania in Oct. 1978. Tanzanian troops counter-invaded, routed Amin's Soviet- and Arab-equipped army and reached the Ugandan capital, Kampala, in April 1979.
Mr. Amin, a convert to Islam, fled to Libya, then Iraq and finally Saudi Arabia, where he was allowed to settle provided he stayed out of politics.

PERSON: Kiran Mazumdar-Shaw 

HEADLINE: THE SATURDAY PROFILE; 
How India's Mother of Invention Built an Industry

BYLINE:  By AMY WALDMAN

DATELINE: BANGALORE, India 

 BODY:
LIKE father, like daughter, Kiran Mazumdar-Shaw thought in the 1970's, when she set out to become a brew master just as her father had been. She left India to train in Australia, then returned home to find that daughters were not welcome in India's breweries. 
 That door closing for her opened another one for India. Unemployed, she followed a love of biology and a chance referral to an Irish biotechnology company. At 25, she started their Indian operation from her garage, successfully extracting from papaya an enzyme used to tenderize meat, among other things, and from the swim bladders of tropical fish a collagen that helps clear beer. 
 It was the beginning of India's biotechnology industry. 
Twenty-five years later, Ms. Mazumdar-Shaw, 50, has become a symbol of sorts for that industry. Her now independent company, Biocon India Ltd., of which she is chairwoman and managing director, employs almost 900 people, making it among India's largest biotechnology companies.
From this capital of the southern state of Karnataka, which is now home to 85 biotechnology companies, Ms. Mazumdar-Shaw is among those trying to shape a nation's approach to uncharted scientific and commercial terrain. It is both promising and risky. 
Across India, states are racing to set up biotech parks, hoping to mimic the success of the information technology industry that defined India as a global knowledge powerhouse. 
But biotechnology touches human lives in a way that information technology does not, and that is at the heart of the debate over its benefits and risks for developing countries.
That debate heated up with President Bush's charge that Europe's resistance to genetically modified foods has made African countries reluctant to accept bio-engineered foods despite widespread hunger there. Similar concerns have arisen in India, which rejected a donation of a soy-corn blend this year because the United States could not certify that it had not been genetically modified. 
The worry in the developing world, said Ms. Mazumdar-Shaw, who does not share the concern, is this: "Why has Europe banned it? It must be for a reason. Why are we being fools and embracing it?"
She passionately believes that India must embrace biotechnology, with the proper precautions. She believes it can change the way this country of more than one billion people, at least one-fourth of them deep in poverty, eats and farms, researches and cures disease. 
"Today anything can be done -- we have the techniques," she said.
Biotechnologists are working to develop high-protein potatoes and high-nutrient rice that could help address the country's malnutrition problem. They have developed a vaccine for leprosy, which was not being researched in the West, and are working on biofuels from local crops like sugar cane. 
But such ventures, if done badly, could also cause damage, sending new genetic strains into the country's basmati rice crop, for example, threatening a staple food. It is a new frontier characterized by excitement, but also uncertainty. 
MS. MAZUMDAR-SHAW seems well-suited to both. She is possessed of what she calls a "spirit of adventure," along with a deep determination to succeed. Her family was unconventional, not least in her father's choice of profession as a master brewer. They were Brahmins originally from the state of Gujarat, which even today prohibits alcohol. 
"My parents were today's people," she said. 
Unable to get into medical college, she focused on zoology and other biosciences at Bangalore University, and she became fascinated by fermentation science. She earned a scholarship to Australia, only to meet disappointment at home in her quest to become India's first female master brewer. 
But the setback was only temporary. Today she has capitalized well on the abundance and affordability of Indian biologists and chemists, building a loyal team. She is simultaneously warm and controlled, a gracefully aggressive entrepreneur who favors scarves and pearls. 
Her company resembles a large family -- her husband, John Shaw, an exuberant Scotsman, is on the management team. She eats lunch in the cafeteria with everyone else, and has decorated the company's walls with her personal art collection. 
Ms. Mazumdar-Shaw has taken a lead in trying to shape policy and perception toward biotechnology. Over a recent breakfast, she explained to the former American ambassador, Robert D. Blackwill, why Western companies' fear that their intellectual property would not be protected in India was misplaced, and asked him to spread the word. 
She has few illusions that the industry is anything but nascent -- it will take another 10 to 15 years before there is a thriving biotech industry in India, she predicts. "I've taken 25 years to get to where I am," she said. 
From extracting enzymes, she moved into fermenting them, developing and patenting a novel technology to do so. Biocon extracted and manufactured enzymes used in everything from Lipton Ice Tea to tomato puree. 
Now Biocon has moved onto even more complex challenges. By year's end, it will begin using an innovative technology to manufacture recombinant human insulin. The product will pit Biocon against multinationals like Eli Lilly, which have already started lowering their prices, apparently in anticipation. It is only one piece of Biocon's focus on diabetes, which also includes efforts to produce oral insulin and clinical trials on diabetics. 
SUCH clinical trials, she believes, are another potential gold mine for India. The country has one of the world's largest populations of "naive" patients on whom no medicine has ever been tried, making them ideal for study. In addition, it has a large population of intermarried relatives, allowing for the study of genetic defects, as well as innumerable ethnic and tribal communities whose genomics can be studied. 
"The kind of patient populations, the diversity of patient populations -- we could have so much data exclusivity to lease out to the rest of the world," Ms. Mazumdar-Shaw said. 
Not surprisingly, such notions have many opponents, who argue they amount to exploitation of India's people and resources, and could threaten the very biodiversity they seek to capitalize on. 
Ms. Mazumdar-Shaw recognizes the concerns, and believes companies must demonstrate their intentions. But, she asks: "What's wrong with Indian guinea pigs? There have been American and European guinea pigs. It's a very important cause: alleviating diseases." 
She is eager to win over the critics. "You can't do every experiment to show genetically modified products are safe," she said, "but are you going to abandon it because of the fear it could be bad?"

HEADLINE: Washington Talk; 
Closing V.A. Hospitals Has Congress Squirming

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 

 BODY:
The Department of Veterans Affairs is relearning a truism about Congress the hard way: Nothing gets a lawmaker riled up faster than a plan to shut something down.
 Always available for a ribbon cutting, members of Congress have a pathological fear of seeing the doors shut to any federal facility back home, whether it be a military base, Social Security office, or in the relevant example, a veterans hospital. 
 So it is no surprise that the department's new proposal to close seven hospitals and change the services available at dozens of others landed with a thud on Capitol Hill this month, even though the plan called for spending billions of dollars to build new centers and open scores of outpatient clinics in areas where veterans have migrated. 
Senators and representatives fired off angry letters, vowing to fight any closings. Emergency community meetings were convened. Advocacy groups were mobilized. 
"There is a lot of unhappiness," said Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, who noted that a potential cutback at three sites in his state ranked right up there with the economy as he held town meetings in the past week. "You are talking about a huge veterans population, and they basically have no place to turn."
In New York, the Congressional delegation is fuming about the department's plan to close or eliminate inpatient care at three hospitals -- Canandaigua, Montrose and Manhattan. Lawmakers are also upset in California, Kentucky, Mississippi, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Texas and other states with hospitals on the block. 
Peter Gaytan, a deputy director at the American Legion headquarters, said, "We don't see how closing a hospital can solve any problem when we have 100,000 veterans standing in line waiting for appointments." 
Given the hopeful acronym of Cares (Capital Asset Realignment for Enhanced Services), the plan is the department's most ambitious effort to date in its struggle to put its services where the veterans are and catch up to the shift of medicine to outpatient care.
It is also an effort to get a grip on what has been an embarrassing problem -- vacant and underutilized veterans centers built in the Northeast and Midwest decades ago when veterans were clustered there before they retired to the Sunbelt. The object of the plan is to save $45 million a year over the next 20 years by reducing the department's vacant and little used space by more than 40 percent -- to 4.9 million by 2022 from 8.5 million square feet in 2001. 
"Bottom line -- the draft plan will allow us to avoid imbalances between the size and location of health care facilities and veterans' demand for care tomorrow," said Dr. Robert H. Roswell, the department's undersecretary for health.
The agency's report concedes that closing hospitals is touchy in the extreme. "Disposition of capital assets traditionally has been a difficult process in the federal sector in general, and in the V.A. in particular," it says with bureaucratic understatement.
Many lawmakers would acknowledge that some veterans facilities should have been mothballed long ago or transformed into something other than 1950's-style hospitals. But they also know their communities expect them to put up a fight. More is at stake than providing care. In some towns, the veterans center is the major employer. Losing jobs is as painful as losing health care.
In a letter to the department secretary, Anthony J. Principi, Mr. Wyden the economic consequences of closing a rehabilitation center in White City, Ore. "In all of White City, there are 2,152 residents with jobs," he wrote. "The domiciliary alone employs 400 people."
Congress has conceded in the past that it is almost incapable of closing down anything. To cut the number of military bases, lawmakers establisheda special commission to recommend the targets. Then -- in their best "stop us before we spend again" mode -- they limited themselves to a straight up or down vote, knowing that was the only way they would get anywhere.
But some lawmakers are now summoning the nerve to shut down one thing -- there is a move afoot to eliminate the next round of base closings in 2005.
