HEADLINE: The Day the Lights Went Out; 
An Industry Trapped by a Theory

BYLINE:  By Robert Kuttner; Robert Kuttner is co-editor of The American Prospect and author of "Everything for Sale: The Virtues and Limits of Markets."

 BODY:
In the search for the source of Thursday's blackout, the underlying cause has been all but ignored: deregulation. In principle, deregulation of the power industry was supposed to use the discipline of free markets to generate just the right amount of electricity at the right price. But electric power, it turns out, is not like ordinary commodities. 
 Electricity can't be stored in large quantities, and the system needs a lot of spare generating and transmission capacity for periods of peak demand like hot days in August. The power system also requires a great deal of planning and coordination, and it needs incentives for somebody to maintain and upgrade transmission lines. 
 Deregulation has failed on all these grounds. Yet it has few critics. Evidently, even calamities like the Enron scandal and now the most serious blackout in American history are not enough to shake faith in the theory.
Ten years ago, most public utilities were regulated monopolies. They were guaranteed a fair rate of return, based on their capital investment and costs. So the government compensated them for building spare generating capacity and maintaining transmission lines. Regulators, of course, sometimes made mistakes and the industry oversold technologies like nuclear power. Even so, in the half-century before deregulation, productivity in the electric power industry increased at about triple the rate of the economy as a whole. 
However, the wave of deregulation that culminated in the late 1990's broke up the integrated utilities like Con Ed that once generated power in its own plants, transmitted it and sold it retail. It ushered in a new breed of entrepreneurial generating and trading companies. However, the prices the local utility companies could charge consumers remained partly regulated. The theory was that local utilities, no longer producing their own power, could negotiate among competing suppliers for the best price and pass the savings along to the consumer. 
But deregulation hasn't worked, for three basic reasons. First, there is a fairly fixed demand for electricity and generating capacity is tight, so companies that produce it enjoy a good deal of power to manipulate prices. The Enron scandal, which soaked Californians for tens of billions of dollars, was only the most extreme example. California authorities calculated that a generating company needed to control just 3 percent of the state's supply to set a monopoly price.
Second, the idea of creating large national markets to buy and sell electricity makes more sense as economic theory than as physics, because it consumes power to transmit power. "It's only efficient to transmit electricity for a few hundred miles at most," says Dr. Richard Rosen, a physicist at the Tellus Institute, a nonprofit research group. 
Third, under deregulation the local utilities no longer have an economic incentive to invest in keeping up transmission lines. Antiquated power lines are operating too close to their capacity. The more power that is shipped long distances in the new deregulated markets, the more power those lines must carry. 
In addition, in the old days of regulation, a utility like Con Ed would be required to regularly submit a resource plan to a state's public service commission. The two organizations would forecast demand and decide how much money should be invested in power plants and transmission lines. Rates would be adjusted to cover costs. Under deregulation, however, nobody plays that crucial planning role. 
Much of the Southeast, by contrast, has retained traditional regulation -- and cheap, reliable electricity. 
When the blackout hit on Thursday, many of us first thought of terrorists. What hit us may be equally dangerous. We are hostage to a delusional view of economics that allowed much of the Northeast to go dark without an enemy lifting a finger.

HEADLINE: Read His Lips 

 BODY:
After presiding over a two-year binge of tax cuts, a rocketing federal deficit and job losses that recall the Herbert Hoover era, President Bush appears ready to step away from the supply-side gaming table, at least for a while. Mr. Bush announced Wednesday that he sensed enough of an economic upturn to reject any immediate plans for yet another tax cut. He estimates that the effects of two years of giddy revenue-slashing -- geared heavily toward the wealthiest Americans -- are looking "robust enough" to hold off on more cuts. 
 We accept the respite as an act of fiscal mercy rather than a cause for economic celebration. The Republicans' chokehold on the nation's revenue flow is doing far more to create debt and deficits than to create jobs, but it is a relief to know that Mr. Bush is not planning to do any more major damage in the immediate future. 
 Certainly things are bad enough as it is. Over nine million Americans are unemployed, and close to three million jobs have disappeared during Mr. Bush's incumbency, leaving him in danger of facing the voters next year as the first president since Hoover to preside over a net job loss. The Democratic candidates in the current scrum are rubbing their hands at this prospect. But most of them have been unwilling to call candidly for the tax cuts' repeal, and so far none have been able to attract much attention above the din of California's recall.
Strutting forth in the Texas heat this week, the president and his chief economic advisers looked like a "Magnificent Seven" tableau of economic optimists marching toward the looming campaign. "Hold the line" was Mr. Bush's surreal spending advice for a Republican-controlled Congress that has been more co-conspirator than deficit hawk in Washington's detax-and-spend mania.
As Mr. Bush's "growth" program rolls out, the richest 1 percent of Americans can expect an estimated 17 percent cut in their taxes by 2010, according to the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy. The other 99 percent get a 5 percent cut -- along with accumulated deficits of $4 billion or more across the next 10 years and the lost chance that the now-vanished surplus might be used to protect their future Social Security benefits. 

CORRECTION-DATE: August 19, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An editorial on Saturday misstated the projected federal deficit over the next decade. It is $4 trillion or more, not $4 billion.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; 
Rumpled and Groggy, Wall Street Resumes Trading

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGEEHAN and JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
Wall Street traders are not known for their sartorial splendor on their best days and yesterday certainly was not one of them. On the morning after a blackout that left the hub of the financial markets without power, hundreds of traders, many unwashed and most of them groggy from lack of sleep or arduous commutes, staggered to their posts at the New York Stock Exchange and brokerage firms around the city.
 The financial markets answered the opening bell about 15 hours after the lights went out and trading proceeded without interruption, but the effort took a physical toll on people like John Conlin. On Thursday afternoon, Mr. Conlin, 40, and his family were just about to celebrate his induction into the exchange -- whose memberships have recently sold for as much as $2 million -- when the power failed. 
 Instead of taking his wife and parents to dinner downtown, he treated them to a sleepover on chairs in the luncheon club upstairs from the exchange's trading floor, where dozens of exchange employees spent the night. Elsewhere in the building, which for a night became a hostel on Broad Street, as many as 300 people bunked in any available space, from the boardroom to the trading floor. Richard A. Grasso, the chairman, and the exchange's co-presidents, Robert Britz and Catherine Kinney, slept on couches in their offices. 
Although she lives in the city and could have gone home, Ms. Kinney said, "I wanted to make sure I was here for the opening." And she was, wearing the pale suit she had worn to work on Thursday, but looking none the worse for wear.
In the morning, Mr. Conlin's family headed home to New Jersey and he, unchanged, went to work buying and selling stocks. "It was an unusual way to start my career as a member," Mr. Conlin said in an interview from the exchange floor.
Odd circumstances abounded yesterday for the people who work on Wall Street, but, operating largely on diesel-fueled generators, the financial markets muddled through the blackout without fail. With the exception of the American Stock Exchange, which could not muster enough steam to open trading until 3:45 p.m., the stock markets operated through a full session of light, directionless trading. The bond market closed early, at 2 p.m., but only to give traders and other workers a headstart on the commute home.
The American Exchange had generators to power its computers but Consolidated Edison could not supply the steam it needed to run its air-conditioning system, exchange officials said. While the New York Exchange, a few blocks away, got its power back at 6 a.m., the American was still waiting on Con Ed as the end of the trading day -- and week -- approached.
Peter Quick, the American exchange's president, may have been more frustrated with Con Ed than any other executive on Wall Street. The utility said it could not provide the steam until it had restored electricity to the exchange's neighbors, Mr. Quick said. "Even now," he said at 3:30 p.m., "we're still the only building in our immediate neighborhood with power."
By late in the afternoon, the exchange had parked a portable steam generator in the street in front of its building and announced that it would start taking orders at 3:45 p.m. and executing trades at 3:55, or five minutes before the usual 4 p.m. closing bell. The super-abbreviated session may have been the shortest in the exchange's nearly century-old history.
A spokesman for the exchange, Robert Rendine, said that trading appeared to go smoothly. He said the exchange expected to open for trading at the normal time on Monday.
At the New York exchange, trading was so orderly that two big brokerages, Goldman Sachs and Bear Stearns, pulled off the sale of 50 million shares of the MBNA Corporation, a large issuer of credit cards, for about $1.1 billion early in the morning. Alan C. Greenberg, the chairman of Bear Stearns, said he got a fright Thursday afternoon just minutes after agreeing to terms of the deal.
Working from Oklahoma City, where he was visiting his 96-year-old mother, Mr. Greenberg heard from a client that the power was off back in New York.
"In my 55 years in this business this was a first for me," Mr. Greenberg said. "At 4:12 p.m. we agreed on the trade. At 4.14 p.m. the power went out. I thought it was divine intervention."
Despite frayed nerves, MBNA and the two firms agreed to proceed with the deal. Some of the traders involved slept at the firm to ensure they could complete the deal by the time the market opened.
Even with that large trade, though, the volume of trading on the New York exchange, at about 636 million shares, was the lightest since 461 million shares changed hands on Christmas Eve and about half the average daily volume this year. The major stock indexes barely changed: The Dow Jones industrial average closed up 11.13 points, or 0.12 percent; the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index edged up 0.16 percent, and the Nasdaq composite index ended up just 1.67 point.
Trading was also light in the bond market, but several traders said there were no problems completing transactions. In trading around 2 p.m., the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note was up to 4.53 percent, from 4.49 percent Thursday, while the price, which moves in the opposite direction, was down 10/32 to 97 24/32 . In the currency market, the dollar was little changed against the euro, with one euro worth $1.1256, unchanged from Thursday.
Some big brokerage firms had trouble connecting through phone lines to the New York exchange and the Nasdaq stock market's electronic trading system. And some smaller firms, without secondary sources of power or enough people to staff their trading desks, could not operate at all yesterday. But the Nasdaq's system, a network of computers that allow brokerage firms around the country to buy and sell stocks from afar, worked smoothly, said its chief executive, Robert Greifeld.
Mr. Greifeld, who spent the first hour of the blackout helping to extract a man trapped in an elevator, said his market switched to backup generators at its primary computer center in Trumbull, Conn., but was running on electricity again by yesterday morning's opening at 9:30 a.m.
"The vast majority of market participants got to us on a fairly seamless and easy basis," Mr. Greifeld said.
The Nasdaq had never had both sources of electricity to its six-year-old data center fail at once, but it was prepared for that double whammy when it hit on Thursday. Every Friday night, the Nasdaq's operations staff practices cutting off power from both of the substations in Connecticut that supply it, said Steve Randich, the chief information officer.
The center's four generators automatically kick on, as they did on Thursday, he said. With 50,000 gallons of fuel on site, the Nasdaq could run for more than a week without electricity, said Mr. Randich, who was heading to Connecticut from lower Manhattan when he got a call in his car notifying him of the blackout.
While Mr. Randich was directing the Nasdaq's recovery as he wended his way north, Mr. Greifeld and David Warren, the Nasdaq's chief financial officer, were searching their offices for tools to pry open an elevator door on the 50th floor of 1 New York Plaza. The two executives were following their staff toward the stairs for the long walk down to the street when they heard a cry for help.
Lacking a toolbox, they wedged the handle of a paper slicer between the outer doors, providing air and a sliver of hope to the stranded passenger. Needing a pole to pass to him, they settled for one designed to lower a screen for PowerPoint presentations in a conference room.
"I was racking my brain, saying what have we got in here," Mr. Warren recounted. "These pagers and laptops don't work. I need a good 10-foot section of 3-inch pipe in my office."
Eventually getting help from the building's security staff, they managed to create enough space for the man, a worker in the building whom they could not identify, to jump free. After escorting him down 50 flights, Mr. Warren spent the rest of the evening walking to the Nasdaq's Marketsite in Times Square. He borrowed a car, drove home to Westchester County by 1 a.m., and was back at his office in lower Manhattan at 8 a.m. to make sure the market was ready to reopen.
Arthur Cashin Jr. was already at the New York exchange by then, having arrived around 7 a.m. after a trip into the city that was smoother than his commute home the night before.
On Thursday evening, Mr. Cashin, director of floor operations for UBS Financial Services, arrived at Pier 11 to catch a ferry to Jersey City and found, he said, about 1,000 people lined up. He boarded a ferry to Liberty Harbor instead and walked a few miles to his car, not getting home until 9 p.m.
Still, Mr. Cashin slept in his own bed. Stephen Kurlowicz, an insurance broker who works at 40 Broad St., across from the exchange, had it harder.
Unable to take the Long Island Rail Road home to Suffolk County, Mr. Kurlowicz, 63, decided to spend the night in the J. P. Morgan building nearby.
"I was in J. P. Morgan laying on a slab of granite," Mr. Kurlowicz, 63, said. "They had air. They had security guards, and they had water, so what else did you need?"
But when he went back to his office, he and his co-workers were not allowed to enter the building because there was no electricity. They were sent home.
"This is why commuters are tough," he said. "They put up with a lot. This is nobody's fault unless you want to blame God."

HEADLINE: THE CALIFORNIA RECALL: GOVERNORS; 
Colleagues Shiver From Chill of Bid to Recall Davis

BYLINE:  By MONICA DAVEY

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Aug. 15 

 BODY:
Gov. Mike Johanns of Nebraska seems torn when it comes to the recall election that is taking place in California, half a country away.
 Surely, Gov. Gray Davis could not deserve all the blame for California's budget woes, Governor Johanns said, since, after all, almost every state has had financial strain in recent months. "When the economy went south as badly as it did, we're all going to have a bad time," Mr. Johanns said the other day. 
 "It strikes me a little bit as shooting the messenger," he said, adding, "I have to tell you, you're not going to find this governor standing up and cheering for recalls."
Such empathy might not sound odd, except that Mr. Johanns is a Republican, who acknowledges that he usually fits, philosophically, on the opposite end of the political spectrum from Mr. Davis, the beleaguered Democrat. 
What is happening to Mr. Davis could not happen to Mr. Johanns because Nebraska has no provision for the recall of a governor, but it is possible in 17 states besides California. And though there is no rush to recall governors elsewhere, it is clear that as the nation's governors gather in Indianapolis on Saturday for their annual meeting, there is an awkward question lurking, if rarely mentioned: Might recall elections, like so many things from California, turn into a trend and spread to other states?
"This whole thing certainly makes people nervous around the country," said Thomas E. Cronin, the president of Whitman College in Walla Walla, Wash., who wrote "Direct Democracy: The Politics of Initiative, Referendum and Recall" (Harvard University Press, 1989). "This is not something that governors are going to be enthralled with."
Even some Republican governors who want to see a fellow party member take the helm in Sacramento seem slightly queasy about what has occurred in California.
Gov. Mike Huckabee of Arkansas is already an outspoken supporter of Arnold Schwarzenegger, one of the major contenders to replace Mr. Davis, and has little sympathy for the California governor. "You always grieve when one of your colleagues is going through something, but at the same time, we all make our own beds," Mr. Huckabee said. 
Still, he said, he did have a slight concern about the number of signatures needed in California to force a recall election -- just 12 percent of the votes cast in the previous election. "If they were going after me," Mr. Huckabee said, "I'd like it to be higher than that. In my state, you could get enough hardcore Democrats together to get 12 percent."
In the 17 other states that do allow recalls of governors, most have tougher requirements to force a recall than California's. Many of those states, including Alaska, Colorado, Kansas, Louisiana, Nevada, New Jersey, Washington and Wisconsin, require signatures from 25 percent or more of voters in recent elections, according to the National Conference of State Legislatures.
And seven of the states also require that a governor be found to have met some specific grounds for recall, like committing crimes, corruption, or other malfeasance in office.
While recalls for local offices -- school boards and town mayors -- are common, only one effort to recall a state's governor has ever been successful. In 1921, voters in North Dakota got rid of Gov. Lynn J. Frazier and other state leaders. The recall hardly ended Governor Frazier's political career; he was later elected to the United States Senate.
In the late 1980's, Arizona voters gathered enough signatures to force a recall election of Gov. Evan Mecham, a Republican, but he was impeached before the election took place.
Some experts said the tight requirements for recall elections in most states would probably keep such movements as rare as they have been -- especially because of the high costs. "I don't think we're going to now see a lot of statewide recall elections, but I wouldn't be surprised to see more threats of recalls," said Jennie Drage Bowser, a policy analyst at the National Conference of State Legislatures. By threatening a recall and gathering signatures, she said, voters often make their point to politicians.
Gov. Judy Martz of Montana, a Republican, said last week she had heard of someone "taking out papers" to consider a recall move against her at one point. The move went nowhere, she said.
And despite it, Governor Martz said she strongly favors the notion of recalls, generally. "People should have that right," she said. "If people are given the correct information, I think it's a good process."
Governor Martz said she would support a "good, conservative, Republican candidate" to replace Governor Davis in California. This week, meanwhile, she announced that she herself would not run for re-election, saying that she wanted to spend more time with her family. 
Some political scholars even think the California recall election might have the opposite effect on other states: People elsewhere would not want to follow the example of such a quirky, Hollywood-style affair. 
"I just don't think anybody's saying, 'Hey, we want to look like California,' " said Elisabeth R. Gerber, a professor of public policy at the University of Michigan. "I don't think the circus nature of California's experience does a lot to make recall look like a credible choice, but still, you never know. This could be seen as an unsavory, but effective, way of changing political power in other states."
John Mark Hansen, dean of the social sciences division at the University of Chicago, suggested that the danger of recall fever might not be to other states, but to California, over and over.
"Once the genie is out of the bottle, the bigger question is: will it happen again in California?" he said. "If the situation again turns against a sitting governor, someone facing a difficult political situation, what will happen then? It also makes it harder to do brave things as governor."

HEADLINE: THE BLACKOUT: LEGISLATION; 
After 2 Years, Energy Bill Is Getting New Urgency in Congress

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 15 

 BODY:
The blackout will give new urgency to an energy plan that has languished in Congress for more than two years, lawmakers said today, and they asserted that elements of the plan aimed at upgrading the power grid will gain in importance.
 "We simply cannot afford to wait any longer," said Representative Billy Tauzin, the Louisiana Republican who is chairman of the House Energy and Commerce Committee. "Our economy and our way of life are at stake." 
 Mr. Tauzin said his panel would open an investigation into the cause of the blackout, convening a hearing on the massive power failures within days of Congress's return after Labor Day. Senator Charles E. Schumer, the New York Democrat on the Senate energy committee, called for similar hearings in the Senate. 
When they return the week of Sept. 2, House and Senate negotiators are to begin already scheduled negotiations to merge broad energy bills that have been stalled since 2001 over a range of environmental, partisan and regional disputes.
The Senate measure became so bogged down this month that Republican leaders, eager to pass something just to start talks with the House, agreed to pass the bill from last year, even though it was written when the Democrats were in charge.
The House and Senate plans contain provisions intended to increase the capacity for power transmission and to protect against widespread failures. But a serious disagreement remains over a plan by a federal energy panel to require utilities to participate in regional power organizations able to share electricity nationwide. Many southern and western lawmakers oppose that approach.
In addition to the disputes over transmission, passage of the overall measure, which grew out of the 2001 energy report by the Bush administration, depends on the ability of its authors to work out resolutions to unrelated fights over oil and gas exploration, subsidies for nuclear power, global warming and other contentious issues.
The House minority leader, Nancy Pelosi, Democrat of California, said that the insistence of President Bush and his Congressional allies on approval for oil drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge had helped stall measures that could have led to improvements to the power grid. 
"President Bush and Tom DeLay put the interests of the energy companies before the interests of the American people by insisting we drill in A.N.W.R. and other environmentally sensitive areas rather than modernize our energy system," said Ms. Pelosi.
Mr. DeLay, the House majority leader from Texas, is a strong advocate of increased energy production.
Republicans said improvements in the power delivery system had been held up by environmental and other resistance. 
A spokesman for the House energy panel, Ken Johnson, said: "If the accepted public policy in America becomes 'not in my backyard,' there are going to be a lot of people walking home from closed businesses to dark homes in the future." 
There was wide agreement that the blackout would give new momentum to the energy bill, which has been a secondary priority of Congressional leaders who for much of the year focused on other issues.
"This outage clearly demonstrates how close the nation is to its energy production and distribution limit," said Senator Pete V. Domenici, the New Mexico Republican who is chairman of the Energy and Natural Resources Committee. "I hope that when Congress returns in September the House-Senate conference on an energy policy bill will make rapid progress."
But the prospect of agreement on an energy bill was worrisome to environmental groups, which have opposed both the House and Senate bills and contend that they are backward looking on energy issues.
"Everyone is going to jump on this, and the problem is that neither the House or Senate's energy bill nor the president's energy plan is going to do what it takes to give us a cleaner energy future," said Anna Aurilio, legislative director of the U.S. Public Interest Research Group.
The electrical provisions of the bill had taken a back seat to issues like oil drilling and gas mileage. But they were followed closely by the industry, state regulators and lawmakers. 
To move the Senate energy measure, the leadership agreed to requests from lawmakers, including Senator Richard C. Shelby, Republican of Alabama, to seek a lengthy delay in the new transmission market that the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission has proposed. Mr. Shelby and others say the plan, the Standard Market Design, would usurp state authority and penalize local utilities that have made their own investments in upgrades. The critics prefer new enforceable standards of reliability for the grid. 
"It appears," a spokesman for Mr. Shelby said, "that the cascading power outages throughout the Northeast only reinforce our need to focus on reliability and transmission infrastructure development rather than creation of a new national market system." 
But Senator Jeff Bingaman of New Mexico, senior Democrat on the energy panel, said the blackouts should push lawmakers to consider changes in a grid that has been largely built and regulated state by state.
"Times have changed, and our policies need to change with them," Mr. Bingaman said.
Mr. Schumer urged Congressional negotiators to drop all the electricity provisions from the bill until a cause of the blackout is pinpointed, to make certain that the legislation does not worsen the problems.

HEADLINE: THE CALIFORNIA RECALL: VOTERS; 
Poll Finds Governor's Support Still Eroding and Likens Him to Nixon in '74 Resignation Crisis

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 15 

 BODY:
A new statewide opinion poll shows that Gov. Gray Davis of California continues to lose support in his effort to keep his job, while Lt. Gov. Cruz M. Bustamante and Arnold Schwarzenegger, the actor, are at the top of the list of possible successors. 
 Mr. Davis, who faces a recall election on Oct. 7, has become so unpopular among registered voters that the pollsters, Field Research, likened his standing to that of President Richard M. Nixon before he resigned in August 1974. 
 "We've been doing polling for 56 years, and the current rating of the governor, 70 percent disapproval, is equivalent to the lowest job rating we have ever measured for an elected official," said Mark DiCamillo, director of the Field (California) Poll.
In the first half of the poll of 1,036 Califorinians, which was released today, 58 percent of likely voters said they favored removing Mr. Davis from office, up from 51 percent last month. 
Asked whether they thought he would be recalled, 68 percent said yes.
In the second half of the poll, to be released on Saturday, Mr. Bustamante, a Democrat, and Mr. Schwarzenegger, a Republican, placed well ahead of the 133 other candidates on the ballot. The recall ballot will pose two questions. First, should Mr. Davis be recalled, and second, who should succeed him if he loses?
The survey showed that 25 percent of likely voters favored Mr. Bustamante, while 22 percent said Mr. Schwarzenegger was their first choice. Three other Republicans followed the front-runners, with State Senator Tom McClintock picking up 9 percent, Bill Simon Jr. 8 percent and Peter V. Ueberroth 5 percent. 
The margin of error in the poll was plus or minus 5 percent.
Mr. DiCamillo said the ranking of the candidates, even with the margin of error, showed that Republicans voters were dividing their votes among the top four Republican candidates and that Democrats had more or less settled on Mr. Bustamante, the lone prominent Democrat on the replacement ballot.
"It is one of the problems that the state Republican Party has had over the years, that they have not been able to come up with consensus candidates," Mr. DiCamillo said.
That said, the poll suggested that many voters had yet to settle firmly on one candidate. Forty-four percent of likely voters indicated that they might change their mind before Oct. 7. 
Peter Ragone, a spokesman for Californians Against the Costly Recall, a group formed by Mr. Davis, said the recall had been so volatile that it would be unwise to place much credence on any poll.
"It is like trying to grab a fistful of water," Mr. Ragone said. "It is so fluid. The polls that have been out there have been all over the map for the past several weeks."
Mr. Davis, in an appearance in Los Angeles, did not talk about the polls. Instead, he criticized remarks by Warren Buffett, a newly named economics adviser to Mr. Schwarzenegger, about property taxes.
In an interview with The Wall Street Journal, Mr. Buffett suggested that the state's property taxes were too low, something that Mr. Schwarzenegger's opponents portrayed today as an assault on Proposition 13, the ballot measure from 1978 that limits on property taxes.
"The people spoke," Mr. Davis said, "and all of us who have held office since then have honored the will of the electorate. Lord knows, we have some things that cost a lot of money in this state. But property taxes are not one of them, and no one is about to change that."

HEADLINE: THE BLACKOUT: POLITICAL STRATEGIES; 
Which Party Gets the Blame? They Agree: It's the Other One

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER and KATHARINE Q. SEELYE

 BODY:
With tens of millions of Americans left powerless, the blackout gave Democrats what they hoped would be a huge new political opportunity -- and they wasted little time in seizing it.
 On the campaign trail, Democratic presidential contenders assailed President Bush for focusing too heavily on drilling for new sources of energy, instead of on a power grid they called too old and overburdened to meet the nation's electrical needs. 
 In Congress, Democrats accused Republicans of blocking modernization of the nation's power-transmission system in 2001.
At the same time, Republican leaders in Congress and conservative talk-show hosts mounted a counteroffensive, charging that Democrats and environmentalists had colluded to prevent the overhaul of the power-transmission grid and blocked legislation on a national energy plan.
"Passage of the energy bill is a vital national interest, and partisan Democrats stalling it should work with the House to get a realistic program to the President's desk," said Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the majority leader. 
Even as the nation waited to learn its exact cause, the blackout promised to heat up a political issue, energy policy, that until now had seemed remote to many Americans outside of California, which suffered an energy crisis and rolling blackouts two years ago. 
Democratic strategists said the crisis could enable their party to question whether President Bush was adequately safeguarding the nation's energy and economic security and to bring back to center stage his administration's ties to the energy industry. 
Mr. Bush himself seemed sensitive to that possibility when two days in a row he said that he favored modernization of the electrical grid. "I view it as a wakeup call," he said yesterday about the blackout.
Regardless of who turns out to be at fault, voters often blame whomever they perceive to be in charge when the lights go out -- a fact of political life with potential ramifications even at the Congressional-district level for incumbents in areas affected by the blackout.
"Millions of Americans are now well acquainted with our old, antiquated, not up to par energy system that they have not been paying attention to," Senator John Kerry, a Massachusetts Democrat and presidential contender, said in a telephone interview. "And this is not a forward-looking administration that tries to eliminate problems before they occur."
Bill Carrick, a Democratic political consultant based in California, said: "Nothing gets people going faster than not having power. Just ask Gray Davis. Before the energy crisis, his approval rating was consistently in the 50's. Then it just plummeted."
Two years ago California suffered a series of temporary blackouts as demand for electricity outpaced older power plants, while a botched experiment with partial price deregulation and environmental opposition created disincentives to build new plants. Wholesale electricity prices spiraled out of control, pushing the state's two private utilities to the brink of bankruptcy as they were left buying power at market rates at costs they could not pass on to the consumer.
Although Mr. Davis, who is fighting a recall effort, is the prime example of how an electrical crisis can harm a public figure, he also seemed likely to benefit somewhat from the blackout in the Northeast. His allies were all but claiming vindication, with Representative Nancy Pelosi of California, the House minority leader, sending out a press release noting, "Gov. Davis Kept the Lights on in California During the Energy Crisis."
David Freeman, chairman of the California Power Authority, said of Mr. Davis, "Everyone's counting him out, but I think he got a break yesterday.
"Now his performance will be appraised in light of some real failure. Seeing a far worse electrical emergency elsewhere does put in perspective what we went through, and that we licked it in a fairly short period of time." He noted that California officials had predicted 200 days of blackouts, "and we haven't had any."
Mr. Freeman said that the latest blackout "puts this whole deregulation phenomenon on trial."
"What's lacking in this deregulated world is someone to take responsibility," he said. "No one is responsible for beefing up the system or building power plants. We're talking about the lifeblood of our economy, and there has to be a sense of legal responsibility for keeping the lights on, and that's what we lost with deregulation."
At the national level, some political consultants cautioned against seeking political advantage from the blackout before its cause was determined. "The Democrats, if they try to turn this into a political issue against President Bush, will just look absolutely desperate, like they're flailing at anything that moves," said Whit Ayres, a Republican pollster. "Let's go out and spout off and take some political shots before we have any idea where the fault lies."
But most of the Democratic presidential candidates were undeterred. Howard Dean, the former governor of Vermont, claimed credit for saving New England from disaster and argued that the administration was going in the wrong direction by trying to expand the national grid.
"I think they should stop trying to link every bit of the grid together," Dr. Dean said in Iowa. "I stopped New York, Vermont and New England from linking up by threatening to sue, and they rethought it. If that had happened, New England would have gone out last night. The idea that bigger is better and that we need a national grid is just foolish."
Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut asked the Department of Homeland Security to assess the vulnerability of key electric infrastructures and devise a plan to protect them from attack. He also asked the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to probe the causes of the blackout.
"It is disconcerting that the president would describe yesterday's events as a 'wakeup call,' " Mr. Lieberman said in a statement. "The reality is that the administration has simply failed to provide the leadership or resources necessary to ensure that our critical infrastructure is adequately protected."
Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri called the blackout "further evidence that the Bush administration is inexorably tied to Persian Gulf oil and old energy, and is incapable of devising a comprehensive, forward-looking energy strategy." 
Senator Bob Graham of Florida tied the overburdened grid to Mr. Bush's tax policy. "His $900 billion in tax giveaways to the richest Americans have left America without the resources to rebuild this nation's infrastructure," Mr. Graham said in a telephone interview.
As Republican leaders in Congress said that environmentalists and Democrats had blocked the improvements to the nation's power grid, conservative talk radio hosts amplified their message.
"We've got to set the record straight," said Sean Hannity on his syndicated program yesterday. "What party is it that is opposing all attempts for us to move toward energy self-sufficiency? What party is it that refuses to allow us to drill in the second-largest oil field in American history, known as ANWR, which is a vast wilderness?"
What seemed clear as the day wore on was that millions of Americans -- and in particular, their leaders -- would become newly sensitized to the politics of energy infrastructure.
"There may have been an elected official who has been arguing for improvements in the grid, or warning of danger ahead," said Howard Wolfson, a Democratic strategist in New York. "Before yesterday no one would have known or cared. Tomorrow, I can guarantee you, they will."

HEADLINE: A City in Darkness: Reminders and Lessons; 
New York Spirit

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 I recently visited New York after a 19-year hiatus to pay my respects at ground zero, spend money in your town to support your economy and attend the David Letterman show, whose host, to me, epitomizes the strong spirit and good humor of New Yorkers. 
 I have been watching New Yorkers' response to another emergency, not nearly as horrifying as 9/11, but certainly frightening, disruptive and potentially dangerous. In watching the news, what I observed was a sense of acceptance on the part of New Yorkers, and I admired the good judgment, calm, dignity and respect with which you worked through this latest crisis.
New York, you have had enough, but your spirit is inspirational to the entire world.

NANCY DEE BRANDES
Wilmette, Ill., Aug. 15, 2003

HEADLINE: THE BLACKOUT: COST; 
While Businesses Suffered, a Few Made Out

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON

 BODY:
Almost all the fancy stores on Fifth Avenue were still shuttered yesterday afternoon, Day 2 of the big blackout. But in front of Fendi, a slightly furtive-looking fellow hissed "Prada!" as he stood over a grimy sheet piled with handbags. He had plenty of customers (as did the nearby Prada store, selling the genuine article, which opened at 2 p.m. and was mobbed, despite the lack of air conditioning).
 Many experts say it is far too early to calculate the overall economic effects of the blackout. But as always in New York, the blackout produced economic winners and losers, and as always, a little hustle did not hurt. 
 Take Ken Ford, who sells jewelry and other trinkets at a table on Roosevelt Avenue in Flushing, Queens. "The blackout helped," he said yesterday. "People swarmed to my table and bought everything." And when his table was bare, he continued, he went to an all-for-a-dollar store, bought flashlights and sold them for $3.
To be sure, many more traditional small businesses suffered from the blackout, especially restaurants, which lost both customers and food when the electricity went out. Such businesses are also less likely than big corporations to have insurance that will help cover their losses.
But even among the biggest companies in the region, there were winners and losers. Among the winners was Verizon, which raked in a sea of quarters from its 20,000 pay phones in the city and suburbs. "I wouldn't be surprised if the traffic was double the normal," said James A. Smith, a Verizon spokesman, adding that solid figures will not be available until Monday.
Among the losers, count Consolidated Edison. The utility has not yet calculated its costs from the blackout, but it is paying overtime to thousands of employees who are working 12-hour shifts to try to restore power, said Chris Olert, a company spokesman.
New York City also faces increased expenses for overtime, among other things, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said, though the exact amount is not yet known. About 10,000 police officers patrolled the dark streets on Thursday night, more than double the usual number.
Those expenses may be bad for taxpayers, but they are not necessarily a bad thing for the regional economy, said Barbara Byrne Denham, an economist for Jones Lang LaSalle, a real estate company. "It comes out of the city coffers," she said, "but it goes back into the economy" as people spend their overtime earnings.
And the city may be able to recoup some of its costs from the federal government. Gov. George E. Pataki has asked President Bush to declare a federal emergency in New York, which would make it eligible for disaster aid, a request seconded by Senators Hillary Rodham Clinton and Charles E. Schumer. 
While the true cost of the blackout will not be known for a few days, Senator Schumer said in a statement, "This is the worst blackout in American history, and I think it's safe to say that by the time we finish tallying the cost of responding to this crisis, its expense is going to make the record books."
Larian Angelo, finance director for the City Council, estimated last night that the blackout would lead to a loss of $30 million to $40 million in sales and income tax revenue for the fiscal year, although she stressed that her calculations were preliminary. Her back-of-the-envelope projection is that city residents' personal income will be down by $500 million to $750 million because of decreased economic activity. On the other hand, total personal income for the year is estimated to be $325 billion, with a B.
"So it's not nothing," she said, "but it's not devastating."
On the other hand, economists are fairly sanguine about the overall economic effects of the blackout, which they note struck in the late afternoon and late in the summer (and not, say, three days before Christmas).
"Aside from some discomforts, like food spoilage, it's probably not all that significant," said Jason Bram, an economist for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Tell that to businessmen like Gerry Hayden, owner of Amuse, a restaurant at 18th Street and the Avenue of the Americas. He said he lost at least $12,000 because he was closed on the busiest night of the week, Thursday, and had still not reopened by last evening. His hourly workers get paid only if the restaurant is open.
Bruce Sterman, who owns two Manhattan Chili Company restaurants near Times Square, was back in business yesterday. He said he hoped that his insurance would cover the costs of the food he had to dump, but was less hopeful about getting a claim paid on his business interruption policy, in part because he would have to have been closed for 24 hours.
On the other hand, when he reopened in the afternoon, a lot of people came in the door, Mr. Sterman said. "We're definitely doing more bar business than we usually do in the midafternoon," he said. 
There were also winners and losers in the financial services industry, sometimes at the same company. The Wall Street side of the business generally functioned smoothly; for example, the Bank of New York's securities processing business, one of the largest in the country, was operating normally, said Jeep Bryant, a spokesman for the bank.
But on the consumer banking side, only about a third of the bank's 375 automated teller machines were working yesterday morning, though the number that were spitting out cash rose through the day to 236. Other banks in the area had problems as well, leaving angry customers shaking the locked doors of branch offices.
Transaction volume for the NYCE Corporation, the largest processor of A.T.M. and debit card transactions in the Northeast, was 30 to 40 percent lower than usual in the New York metropolitan area from 4 p.m. Thursday to 7 yesterday morning, said Dennis F. Lynch, chief executive of the network.
The hardest-hit sections of the economy were probably retail and travel, said Kathryn Wylde, president of the Partnership for New York City, which represents many of the city's largest businesses. 
For thousands of tourists and their all-important dollars, it was a case of plenty of time, nothing to do and nothing to buy. Even tourist attractions that had backup generator power could not open, like Madame Tussaud's wax museum, where most of its 50 employees could not get into Midtown to work. 
"Normally we'd have 4,200 visitors today," said Janine DiGioacchino, general manager of the attraction. 
Kembree Darakshani, an athlete's representative from Memphis, spent $10 for an animal-name painting on Broadway and 42nd Street (you know, painted lobsters, dolphins and butterflies in the shape of letters). "Today was supposed to be my shopping day, but there was nothing to buy," she said, "so this is my consolation prize."

HEADLINE: THE CALIFORNIA RECALL: THE CANDIDATES; 
California Voters Wonder: Is Anyone Not Running?

BYLINE:  By RICK LYMAN

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Aug. 15 

 BODY:
Bill Simon walked in from the broiling afternoon to the cool onion-scented air of an In-n-Out Burger, a couple of aides at his elbows, on Tuesday. Smiling, he surveyed the clusters of people hunched over their thick, dripping sandwiches. "How are you?" Mr. Simon said, holding out his hand to a wary-looking Jesse Young, seated at a table facing the freeway in Stockton, just over 300 miles north of Los Angeles. "My name's Bill Simon, and I'm running for governor."
 Mr. Young replied: "No kidding. I'm running for governor, too." He turned to the man across the table, Jim Eakes. "How about you, Jim -- you running for governor?" 
 Mr. Eakes set down his No. 3 burger (single patty, no cheese) and wiped his hands on a paper napkin. "Sure, I'm running for governor," he said. 
Apparently, it's going to be that kind of election.
Even a studiously serious candidate like Mr. Simon finds himself treated like one of the flakes from fringeville.
With just 53 days until the voters in the nation's largest state decide whether to kick Gov. Gray Davis out of office and, if so, which of the 135 accredited candidates will replace him, the great recall election of 2003 is creaking to life.
Governor Davis, who won re-election a year ago by trouncing Mr. Simon, finds himself fighting an uphill battle against a recall insurgency that has pitted him not only against his former adversary but also a virtual menagerie of potential governors, including the man who hasbeen sucking up most of the media oxygen and leading in all the early polls, Arnold Schwarzenegger. He is the campaign's missing man, who has managed to dominate the discussion while barely appearing in public.
The power blackout of 2003 even wormed its way into the fracas, with Governor Davis insisting that it would force a fresh assessment of how Enron had manipulated the state's power system two years ago and force Mr. Schwarzenegger to explain how he would have handled such a crisis. Another candidate, Arianna Huffington, the political commentator and agitator, demanded that Mr. Schwarzenegger explain just why he had met with Kenneth Lay, the Enron chairman, and other big shots in 2001.
On Thursday, the crisis actually flushed out Mr. Schwarzenegger for the first time since Monday. Meeting briefly with reporters today, he said he did not remember any meeting and did not intend to answer anyone's charges.
Among the other candidates are a stripper, a young woman who is publicizing her campaign by handing out thong underwear with her name on it, a rock star, a comedian, a former television star, a smut publisher and an aging billboard queen. 
There are so many candidates that if as many people vote in the recall as did in last year's gubernatorial election -- about eight million -- and the votes are split evenly among the candidates, the new governor of the nation's most populous state could potentially be chosen with as few as 60,000 votes, less than the number of people who attend the average N.F.L. game.
Yet despite the delighted California-bashers who call this election a national embarrassment, the people who spurred the the recall effort say they believe it is essential to put California back on its fiscal feet. 
"The national media tend to focus on the eccentric and colorful personalities in the race, making fun of it," said State Senator Tom McClintock, a conservative Republican from Ventura who, yes, is also a candidate for governor. "It's obvious to me that unless you are living in California you don't understand just how serious this is."
Mary Carey, 26, a pornographic actress and erotic dancer whose professional name exploits her resemblance to the pop singer Mariah Carey, paused while putting on her frilly costume for a show at the Gold Club in Sacramento to say that, indeed, she was very aware of how serious this all was. That's why she decided to run for governor, for heaven's sake.
Some of her campaign platforms are for fun, like wiring every room in the governor's mansion with closed-circuit Internet cameras (so "Californians can see their government in action -- literally!"), but others are meant seriously. Ms. Carey just had another idea that morning, she said: As soon as a person signs up for unemployment relief they should be placed in a jury pool. Why should people have to take off work to serve on a jury when there are unemployed people who can do it? 
"It's been a lot of fun, and I've already learned a whole lot," she said.
Such as?
"Oh, I learned how an ordinary person can go about getting on the ballot," she said. "It's easy!"

The Logistics of Democracy
On Monday, most of the serious campaigns were still setting up their offices, hiring staff members and figuring out how to conduct such a crowded, truncated election. At the new Schwarzenegger headquarters on Main Street in Santa Monica, before a news media blackout restricted access at midweek, young fund-raisers and software engineers huddled over laptops discussing how to structure the campaign's Internet site to collect as much money from donors as possible through the Web. At Ms. Huffington's new offices, posters were already neatly stacked against the wall as desks and computers were being hastily assembled. 
"The campaign so far has been a circus," Parker Blackman, Ms. Huffington's press spokesman, said. "But our strategy will be to try to highlight how California's budget crisis is having a real-life impact on people."
Although the impression given by the nearly nonstop television coverage of the recall -- and the Schwarzenegger phenomenon -- was of frenzied activity, there was fairly little outright campaigning going on in the early days.
Governor Davis arrived at the Simon Wiesenthal Center in Los Angeles on Monday morning with a full phalanx of aides and armed guards. He smiled happily as he was greeted at the door by high school students brought in to meet the governor and provide uplifting background for the cameras.
Then he went upstairs to spend a few minutes with a sensitivity class for police officers, which was part of a program that he had initiated, and to take a tour of a new exhibition on families that he also helped get off the ground. Afterward, the cameras were assembled again and he announced from beneath his trademark helmet of gray hair that he would sign legislation offering tolerance training for teachers.
It was all part of the governor's plan to appear extragubernatorial these days. Monday was just the beginning. On Tuesday, he was backing more bills in Los Angeles, then did the same on Wednesday in San Francisco before coming back to Los Angeles to do even more of it. But everywhere he went, of course, the questions quickly turned to the recall -- and to Arnold.

What Voters Will See
The recall voting will have two parts. First, voters will be asked whether the governor should be removed from office. A simple majority gets that job done. Only then will voters be asked to choose from among the scores hoping to replace him, and in that race the candidate receiving the most votes wins.
Polls around the state in recent days have shown varied results, but have agreed on the main points: About three-fifths of the voters want Governor Davis out of office, a formidable number to overcome in such a short election. (A statewide Field Poll today, for instance, said 58 percent of voters wanted him out and 68 percent expected him to lose.)
And of the other candidates, Mr. Schwarzenegger, a moderate Republican, held a commanding early lead, followed by Lt. Gov. Cruz Bustamante, a Democrat who says he opposes the recall but entered the race to give anti-recall voters a haven for their second vote. Mr. McClintock and Mr. Simon, rivals for the conservative Republican vote, also received some support in the polls.
"There will be a lot of polls over the next few weeks," Governor Davis said as he was ending his visit to the Wiesenthal Center. "My focus is to do my job."
Sharon Davis, the governor's wife, made pretty much the same point as she visited the annual picnic of the Los Angeles County Federation of Labor under sagging white tents behind the musician union hall in Hollywood. 
"It's early days," Ms. Davis said. "Those poll numbers are going to turn around."
There were barbecued ribs and sausage on the folding tables, the potato salad was served with an ice-cream scoop and a rubber children's swimming pool was overflowing with cans of beer and bottles of water.
As a white-haired folk singer entertained the crowd ("I'm voting for the governor, Gray Davis/Stranger days than these I've never seen/But I'll save my protest vote for Howard Dean"), Miguel Contreras, executive secretary-treasurer of the federation, spelled out how the anti-recall effort would be structured.
"The first thing we're going to do is we're going to reach out to our members," he said. "We have 800,000 members, and 580,000 of them are registered voters. We're going to engage them at the work sites, we're going to send out mailings, and we have a phone bank of 250 computerized lines."
Then in the campaign's final three weeks, anti-recall volunteers will go door to door and organize carpools for election day. "It is our belief that the key is going to be voter turnout," he said. "The bigger the turnout, the better for us."
As Ms. Davis hit the stage, yellow-and-black "Vote NO on Recall" posters suddenly materialized in the crowd. 
"Yes, it seems as if there is a circus going on," Councilman Antonio Villaraigosa of Los Angeles said. "Because there are so many clowns on the ballot. But make no mistake, this is not a circus. This is a very serious situation."
He and Mr. Contreras led the union crowd, chanting "Three more years," a reference to the remainder of Governor Davis's second term, should he survive the recall.
There were only a handful of other campaign events in the early days, partly because, even while doing his impression of the invisible man, Mr. Schwarzenegger was able to command the spotlight. 
Most of the opening salvos took place on television and radio -- where the numerous all-news channels and round-the-clock punditry looked upon the recall in pretty much the same way that a wolf looks at a wounded rabbit.
"Because of the national media attention on the race, there are many more opportunities for radio and television appearances and those certainly trump your conventional campaign appearances that are limited to a single assembled audience," Mr. McClintock said. "My schedule today included two satellite broadcasts for Fox affiliates, a radio interview in San Francisco, another TV interview with a statewide news service, something with National Public Radio, an appearance on MSNBC and then a nationally syndicated radio show."
Mr. Simon, whose visit to the In-n-Out Burger in Stockton was part of a three-city swing up the state's agriculture-dominated Central Valley, seemed almost defensive when asked by a local television reporter why he was engaging voters one-on-one rather than doing television interviews like everybody else. 
"I do that, too," he insisted. "I was on two programs yesterday, and another the day before that, and I'm going to be on 'Meet the Press' this Sunday. But I also like to go out and meet the people."
Some of the more colorful fringe candidates were also getting as much airtime as they could handle. Ms. Carey visited, among others, Bill O'Reilly. "I'm sure he just wanted to have me on so he could make fun of me," she said. "But I don't care. I can hold my own."
Gary Coleman, the former sitcom star who has repeatedly said that he was unqualified for the job and would probably vote for Mr. Schwarzenegger, was on several channels, defending his presence in the race. Gallagher, the comedian, bashed a few melons. And Michael Wozniak, a former Oakland police officer, complained that the news media always focused on one item in his platform, the legalization of ferrets as house pets. "It's become a hot button issue for me," Mr. Wozniak said.
Several candidates with deep pockets, who might have an impact on the race, like Peter V. Ueberroth, former baseball commissioner, have been hanging back in the early going. Larry Flynt, the publisher of Hustler magazine, said he didn't want to waste his money.
"We're going to do some polling, and if the polling puts me in the double digits, I'm gonna spend some money and we're gonna go the distance," Mr. Flynt told CNN.
Others were struggling to come up with ways to maintain their moment in the limelight.
Georgy Russell, a 26-year-old from Mountain View, publicized her campaign with "Georgy for Governor" thong underwear. Now, however, she says she needs money to keep going. And since she has been surprised by the number of men who are suddenly trying to date her, she said, she is going to sell T-shirts saying: "I asked Georgy out and all I got was this lousy T-shirt."
Ms. Carey was publicizing her campaign during her striptease shows, but she also plans a rally for families on Saturday in Sacramento.
"I'm having fun, but I'm definitely serious, too," she said. "I know I'm probably not going to win. But maybe I can show people that you don't have to be the son of someone famous or married to a Kennedy to run for governor. In a way, I think I can be a role model for young girls, even though I am in the so-called adult industry, which some people frown on."

What About the Budget?
Ms. Huffington kicked off her campaign with a daylong swing through the Bay Area on Wednesday, meeting with community leaders and with the Green Party's Peter Miguel Camejo, who shares some of her views. On the sun-baked concrete esplanade outside Oakland Technical High School, she joined a rally by community activists urging the reinstatement of free bus passes for students.
For Ms. Huffington, it was a perfect opportunity to focus on the victims of the budget crisis, so she showed up with a handful of aides and a trunkful of "Arianna for Governor" posters. "In the middle of the circus atmosphere of the recall is a serious opportunity for change, and we've got to go at it," she said.
Only about a dozen voters showed up and were quickly swallowed up by the crowd of journalists and protesters who swarmed around Ms. Huffington.
Marian Baldwin of Oakland said she heard about the rally on television that morning and decided to wander over during her lunch hour. 
She said she was not particularly concerned about the circus atmosphere that has developed around the recall or the derision the state is receiving from elsewhere around the country.
"What with all the cults and the celebrities and what have you, I guess we've gotten pretty used to it here in California," Ms. Baldwin said.

HEADLINE: THE BLACKOUT: THE MIDWEST; 
Detroit Sweats While It Waits For Electricity

BYLINE:  By JODI WILGOREN and DANNY HAKIM

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 15 

 BODY:
As power was restored throughout most of the Northeast, this city sweated through its second day without lights, air conditioners and, in many cases, even drinking water. Officials estimated that parts of the electrical system here would remain down through the weekend.
 Gov. Jennifer M. Granholm of Michigan declared a state of emergency in five counties, and sent thousands of gallons of water and gasoline, along with state police officers and some National Guardsmen, to metropolitan Detroit from across the state. Detroit's police chief, Jerry Oliver, promised that the city would aggressively enforce an 11 p.m. curfew for anyone 16 or younger. 
 By 9 p.m., officials at DTE Energy, the main utility here, said that power had been restored to 1.5 million of its 2.1 million customers across 7,600 square miles in southeastern Michigan, five times the number that had electricity at noon today. All five of the city's water pumping plants were also back in use by late tonight, though officials warned residents to boil before drinking and said taking showers, washing cars and watering lawns should be limited. 
Anthony F. Earley, DTE's chief executive, would not predict when all the lights would be back on, but urged those with electricity not to overuse it, saying, "The customers hold the key to the speed of the restoration."
As dusk fell on the nation's 10th-largest city, bus service was suspended until 3:30 a.m. Saturday, tonight's Aerosmith concert at Comerica Park was canceled, the opening of the Michigan State Fair was postponed until Saturday, and Mayor Kwame M. Kilpatrick urged Detroit's one million residents to stay home.
"The party has to happen in your homes tonight," the mayor said at an afternoon news conference outside police headquarters in the eerily quiet and empty downtown. "Continue your family time. Love thy neighbor -- in your own home, your own neighborhood."
Thrilled that the number of arrests was at a typical level through the first 24 hours of the nation's worst blackout, Detroit officials said the weekend would serve as a referendum on Mayor Kilpatrick's leadership and on his efforts to rehabilitate Detroit's reputation, from that of a city decimated by violence and poverty to that of a cultural hub with a revitalized economy.
"Either the people of this city believe in this city's future and are going to rally around this mayor or they're not," said Michael Duggan, the county prosecutor, who stood with Mr. Kilpatrick and Mr. Oliver at the news conference. 
Although city officials said there had been virtually no violence or looting Thursday night or Friday, Mr. Duggan issued a stern warning to residents of a city still scarred from the riots of the 1960's. Noting that civil disobedience felonies carry a 10-year prison term, Mr. Duggan added, "Before you pick up a brick and throw it, before you tip over a car, before you take a TV, you better ask yourself, is this worth 10 years of my life?"
Elsewhere in the Midwest, Gov. Bob Taft of Ohio declared a state of emergency in Cuyahoga County, which includes Cleveland, where an order to boil the city's water was in effect through Sunday, though power had been restored by midafternoon to nearly all the 1.5 million area residents who had lost it and to the city's four water pumping stations. In Akron, power was restored in all but a four-block area by 11 a.m., and the mayor sent water and engineers to help Cleveland. Neighboring Cuyahoga Falls, population 50,000, never lost power.
"It was almost like when you land in Las Vegas and see all the lights," the mayor, Don Robart, said of driving home to Cuyahoga Falls from Akron, in a telephone call to National Public Radio. "It was nice to come home to."
In Melvindale, Mich., a Detroit suburb, 2,000 people were shut out of their homes until 1:35 p.m., after an explosion at an oil refinery on Thursday night caused by a buildup of pressure inside a boiler. It appeared unrelated to the blackout but compounded the misery.
Across the region the blackout caused all sorts of disruptions and inconvenience and prompted a variety of improvised remedies. 
At St. Joseph Mercy Hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich., Robert Moore, a courier, got stuck in traffic while trying to pick up platelets for a cancer patient. He borrowed a bicycle and a helmet and made the eight-mile trip. Meanwhile, Grace Elizabeth, the second child of Carrie Lint, a nurse practitioner at the hospital, would not wait for electricity to be restored before she entered the world.
"I ended up delivering my five-pound child in the dark and in the heat," Ms. Lint said. "It was back to the days of Laura Ingalls Wilder."
Also in Ann Arbor, 48 cars and trucks waited outside Malleks, the lone gas station functioning this morning, courtesy of a generator the owner had bought a few years ago, anticipating computer disasters at the start of 2000.
Three plumbers and pipe fitters in town for a training session were waiting to fill a rental car, while an Anglican priest in a sport utility vehicle sought gasoline for his generator to protect his son, who needed stable temperatures. "We have to have air conditioning for him, or he'll have multiple seizures," the priest, Doug Carson, said. The generator also saved 25 salmon in his freezer.
All along Interstate 94, gasoline stations and hotels were overrun, with dozens of cars and motor homes blocking offramps, as people fled the darkened areas. Nearly 150 miles from Detroit in Kalamazoo, which never lost power, the Amoco on Sprinkle Road received several calls from people heading to Chicago from Detroit asking whether they could stop there for gasoline. Eight crates of 99-cent gallons of water had sold out this morning at the station.
In Chelsea, Mich., a town of 4,300 about 50 miles west of Detroit, two of the three stations ran out of gasoline long before noon, and by lunchtime the third, an Amoco station, had sold 10,000 gallons more than its daily norm of 2,000. But three pumps had stopped working, and a fourth was acting up, too.
"We've got plenty of gas in the ground, I don't know what the problem is," said the manager, whose name tag read Barb. "The pumps are just worn out. They're tired."
At least they had power. Here in Detroit, residents were still stuck deep in emergency mode, scratching for a patch of shade as they gobbled the melting ice cream being given away at convenience stores.
Ford and General Motors closed 40 parts and assembly plants on Friday, giving some 100,000 workers the day off, though company officials said some factories might be running again as soon as this evening. The city's African cultural festival was canceled, but the Dream Cruise, an annual classic-car convention expected to draw two million people to a 16-mile stretch in the suburbs, was scheduled to go on Saturday, if slower than usual, because many traffic lights remained out along the route.
Mayor Kilpatrick said at the afternoon news conference that the city had 210,000 bottles of water, 53,000 gallons of gasoline and 83,000 gallons of diesel fuel, and that the sewage treatment plant was running again.
"Detroit, you can flush the toilet," he said. 
City workers had visited the 1,200 elderly people living in six public housing buildings, bearing water and helping them up stairs, he said.
Mr. Oliver, the police chief, described the mood on the city streets as "calm -- not serene, but calm." There were 118 arrests for felonies and seven for misdemeanors, but there was little looting, he said. Those arrested included 15 juveniles.
Throughout the quiet streets of downtown this afternoon, people sat wherever they could find a patch of shade, trying not to move much in the humidity. At the BP station at the corner of First and Fort Streets, one of few working gasoline stations in the area, police officers were on guard to keep people from cutting in line or stealing from the minimart. Perhaps 100 cars stretched around the corner, as people waited for more than three hours.
"You would think everyone would stick together after Sept. 11 stuff, everyone holding hands and hugging," said Martin Hale, 33, who lives on the East Side and waited two hours to fill his tank. "That's just right out the window. Everybody out for themselves." 
Throughout the afternoon, lights began to flicker on sporadically. The MGM Grand Casino's billboard flashed "Big Arm Challenge." Some traffic lights began to work normally, while others were still flashing red, requiring four-way stops. Mayor Kilpatrick said there were just 52 traffic accidents, far fewer than on a normal Friday, because most people stayed off the streets.
In Greektown, where the casino was shuttered for the first time since its opening in 1999, Gregory Alexander was surprised when the lights and air conditioning suddenly came on in his flower shop, in time to keep his roses from frying. He quickly ran a 100-foot extension cord across the street to try to save the freezer at the Yaka Cafe, and then kick-start the sump pump in the flooded basement of the New Parthenon restaurant, but there was not enough power.
"I have no idea why we have power," Mr. Alexander said. "We just got it. So I'm sharing it with my neighbors."
Though DTE Energy said this morning that it did not expect power to be back on until Sunday night, the grid returned, bit by bit, throughout the day. About 130,000 customers had lights when they woke up. By noon, the number was 330,000. By 5 p.m., 700,000; by 7 p.m., 1.2 million and by 9 p.m., 1.5 million.
In St. Clair Shores, a resort community about 20 miles northeast of here, that meant the Saturday evening wedding of Eric Herman and Lisa Tarsi was canceled, and then uncanceled.
"We've got so many candles at our wedding, the lighting was going to be fine," said Mr. Herman, who had scrambled to find generators for the food and music, all for naught after power returned this afternoon. Thursday's rehearsal dinner for 50, though, was scrapped.
"Instead we just bought pizza and subs and came back to our house," he said. "We just realized you have to make do with what you have."

GRAPHIC: Photos: People were lining up for gasoline at a station with a working pump in Detroit yesterday. The station limited purchases to $10. In the Detroit area, one driver received a little help in making it the last few yards into a gasoline station. (Photo by Julian H. Gonzalez/Detroit Free Press); (Photo by Reuters)(pg. B15)
