HEADLINE: MONEY & MEDICINE; 
Some Health Discounts May Be No Bargain

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE ANDREWS; Michelle Andrews is a freelance writer in Manhattan specializing in health care. Her column on its economics appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: moneymeds@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
WHEN Mary Crownover saw a flier for a program called MediSavers that advertised savings of up to 80 percent on medical care and prescription drugs, for a one-time broker fee of $29, she thought it was too good to pass up. It was late 2001 and Ms. Crownover was uninsured and more than a year away from qualifying for Medicare. Her MediSavers card sat in her wallet until one evening last April, when chest pains sent her to the hospital emergency room near her home in St. Charles, Mo. She presented her card and then spent the night undergoing tests at the hospital.
 Doctors ultimately gave Ms. Crownover a clean bill of health, but then came the bill, for $5,061.80. So what kind of savings did she get from her card? Just $278, around 5 percent of the invoice. "I was shocked," said Ms. Crownover, now 65. Every procedure she said she saw on the company Web site showed a savings of at least 56 percent. 
 Asked about Ms. Crownover's smaller-than-expected savings, Alvin Konigsberg, the president of MediSavers in New York, said: "There's very little savings in emergency room visits." It would have been difficult for her to know ahead of time what the savings would be, he said, because prices vary from place to place. Her savings would have been as high as 80 percent if she had gone for testing to a medical facility other than a hospital, he said. Savings by users of his plan can be up to 80 percent, and are generally 50 percent, Mr. Konigsberg said. 
Medical discount plans like the one Mrs. Crownover signed up for are spreading faster than a winter flu. As companies cut back health care coverage, more people are casting about for alternatives. But as many disgruntled people have learned, it's essential to read the fine print in a plan before signing on. To receive a discount, for example, some programs require patients to pay the entire amount due upfront by credit card, as MediSavers did with Ms. Crownover. Depending on your credit limit, such requirements can be a problem. Other programs make patients get the plan's approval before seeing a provider and to make appointments up to 30 days in advance. Some have back-end administrative fees that reduce discounts substantially.
Even if a plan seems solid, consumers may be able to do better on their own. "For an uninsured patient, we'd give better than a 25 percent discount," said Carol Plato Nicosia, director for patient financial service at Martin Memorial Medical Center in Stuart, Fla. "We might give them the Medicare rate -- as much as a 50 percent discount -- if they're near Medicare age."
Charles Martin, 61, of of Mobile, Ala., said he received a 20 percent discount from the hospital he visited for a knee problem after explaining that his $30-a-month discount-card program would shave only 12 percent off his $692 bill.
Sometimes the provider network in a discount program proves as elusive as the savings. Discount companies assemble their networks by buying or leasing lists of medical providers from preferred provider organizations. Some card companies take the additional step of contracting directly with the providers on the list, but problems often occur when this step isn't taken.
Cynthia Ketchum, 40, signed up for a medical discount plan with Family Care to supplement the high-deductible insurance policy she carries for herself and her 4-year-old son, Alberto. She said representatives from Family Care in Houston promised to send a list of participating doctors who were near her home in Arlington, Va., where she works as a client services manager for a law firm. But more than a month and several phone calls and e-mail messages later, she said, she still didn't have the information. Finally, Family Care gave her the name of a single doctor. But when she went to her scheduled appointment, the doctor said he had never heard of Family Care. "I was just furious," said Mrs. Ketchum, who was refunded her $99 enrollment fee and first month's payment of $69.
Jaren Current, vice president for marketing at Family Care, said, "Sometimes it's a little difficult for members to find a doctor in their area." He said that the company had added many more providers since Mrs. Ketchum's difficulties in April.
Some consumers may be led to believe through a plan's advertising that they are getting more protection than the cards provide. "It's certainly not the answer for catastrophic health care needs, or for people with chronic diseases," said Joseph Baker, health care bureau chief for the New York attorney general's office.
THAT office plans to release guidelines this fall for medical discount card companies. The guidelines are likely to include a requirement that companies state clearly that their product isn't insurance, disclose all fees and restrictions and provide a toll-free number for complaints and inquiries. A few states have adopted laws related to discount card company practices. But because the plans are not subject to state insurance laws, "they often fall through the regulatory cracks," said Jim Quiggle, a spokesman for the Coalition Against Insurance Fraud, an alliance of consumer groups, insurers and state regulators based in Washington.
Last year, in an effort to police its members and to educate consumers, the industry formed the Consumer Health Alliance. The group is completing a code of conduct that sets standards for discount companies. "We want to take the confusion out of all this," said Barbara L. Flood, president of the alliance and chief executive of Careington International, a discountcard company.
That's a laudable goal. For the millions who have joined or are considering a medical discount plan, it can't happen soon enough.

PERSON: Julian Gordon 

HEADLINE: Private Sector; 
A Silk Purse From a Safety Net

BYLINE:  By MELINDA LIGOS

 BODY:
IT was right there on the factory floor all the time, but Julian Gordon didn't notice.
 For many years, Mr. Gordon's privately held Boston company, Gordon Industries, a maker of metal doors and stairs that he founded in 1970, was a cash cow. At the height of the 1980's building boom, Gordon Industries had revenue of $3 million and was so profitable that Mr. Gordon could take weekend jaunts to Europe on the Concorde and build up his collection of vintage Mercedes-Benzes. What would be the point of innovating when tried-and-true worked so well? 
 But nothing gets the entrepreneurial juices flowing faster than desperation. In the early 1990's, the Bank of New England closed, brought down by the cumulative failure of many of the developers and speculators it had financed. "It all turned off in a 90-day period," said Mr. Gordon, 59, whose loans were called in by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. "We never missed a payment to the bank for 20 years, and all of a sudden I was threatened with liquidation."
As new construction ground to a halt, Gordon's sales plummeted by two-thirds, and Mr. Gordon spent the next two years worrying about meeting his payroll. With no bank backing, he poured his savings, as well as money borrowed from family and friends, into the business. He went without a salary for a year.
By 1993, the belt-tightening began to pay off as the construction market started to turn around. Mr. Gordon turned his attention to an old puzzle: how to create a steady stream of revenue in a business subject to the vagaries of the housing market. 
It was time, he decided, to branch out. He needed to create a useful product that nobody else had thought of, to patent it and to gain a niche market for himself. In other words, he needed to act more like an entrepreneur, even at the risk of failure.
Sure enough, his initial forays flopped. First, he created a martial-arts training device -- a sort of metal tree with pads that students could kick and punch -- and signed up a husband-and-wife team of trainers to market them. They sold a few hundred, but their marriage unraveled, and sales dried up. Then, his company came up with a steel security screen that shop owners could roll over display windows at night. His target market was New York City, but because the crime rate was falling there, interest in the product was negligible.
Then, in 1996, when his company fought its way back to about $1.75 million in sales, Mr. Gordon received a call from a man who had spotted the portable metal ramps that his company sold to construction sites for wheeling heavy material up to workers. Could he buy one for his aging mother so she could navigate her front steps in a wheelchair? It would be easier and cheaper to install, the man figured, than building a permanent concrete ramp.
At first, Mr. Gordon said no. Then the light bulb went off. "If this guy was so hungry to get one of these ramps, I wondered if maybe other consumers would be, too," he said.
Mr. Gordon, realizing he was onto something, spent the next two years doing market research, getting his patents in order and putting together a business plan.
Hospital stays, he figured, were becoming shorter, so more patients with temporary disabilities were being released while still confined to a wheelchair. The number of elderly homeowners was surging. And federal law was forcing business and government to make their buildings accessible to disabled Americans.
In 1998, Mr. Gordon patented his ramps and began renting them out for about $60 a week and selling them for $2,000. He also persuaded his son Jon to quit his advertising job in Arizona to help sell them. "At first I was skeptical,"' said Jon Gordon, whois now a vice president at the company. "I thought to myself: 'It's just a ramp. No big deal.' "
BUT consumers didn't agree. Sales of the ramp shot up 30 percent in 2000, 50 percent in 2001 and 50 percent in 2002, by which time they had accounted for nearly two-thirds of the company's total revenue of $4 million and had spawned a separate unit -- American Ramp Systems. Julian Gordon expects overall sales to rise to $6 million next year, with all the increase attributable to the ramp.
The elder Mr. Gordon has also sold 11 franchises for the product in Ohio and Pennsylvania and expects to expand that number to 100 nationally within five years.
Barbara Reeve, the mother of the actor Christopher Reeve, was one of the Gordons' first customers, renting out a ramp over Christmas of 1998. Others followed. Skiers with broken legs clamored for the device; other big buyers were churches and other organizations that needed ramps only at certain times. The City of New York ordered several.
Because many Americans confined to wheelchairs are on Medicaid or Medicare and cannot afford the ramps, Julian Gordon has taken steps to help them. Whenever a nonprofit group buys a ramp, he said, "we call the organization and ask what their mission is." He includes the names of likely donors in a "funding source kit" that he mails to low-income people who can contact them for financial help.
The elder Mr. Gordon also fusses over his franchisees, giving them training courses and feeding them leads. "I get e-mails from him at 4 o'clock in the morning," said Keith Rielag, co-owner with his wife, Louella, of a new Cincinnati franchise. "He's so available for me that it's almost ridiculous."
Julian Gordon says he feels that he is close to achieving immunity from the economic quirks that used to plague his business. But he isn't slowing down. He arrives at his office by 6:30 each morning and is the last to leave, Jon Gordon said.
The elder Mr. Gordon pleads guilty to workaholism. "It's not something that I'm proud of," he said, "but hard work seems to work better than wishing for lucky breaks."

HEADLINE: Business; 
Yes, Assembly Lines Can Mix Apples and Oranges

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD

DATELINE: EAST LIBERTY, Ohio 

 BODY:
SHOPPERS for new cars are often frustrated when they can't get the newest model exactly when they want it. Their fickle tastes will be much easier to satisfy, however, as plants like the Honda Motor Company's sprawling factory here become the norm in the industry. 
 In this factory 35 miles northwest of Columbus, the small Honda Civic and the big, boxy Element are being made not only in the same plant, but also on the same assembly line, a radical departure for the auto industry in the United States. Historically, the industry has had a method of one plant, one car. 
 As the cars roll down the miles of conveyor belts here, their differing sizes are made abundantly clear by two racks of roof liners -- soft fabric that stretches the length of a car, against the metal top -- which stand waiting to be installed inside the metal frame. 
The roof liner for the Element is 9 feet long, versus 6 feet for the Civic's; next to each other, they look like two garment bags -- one for a ball gown and one for a blazer. Depending on the vehicle that glides in front of them, workers take a roof liner off a rack and staple it into place.
The East Liberty plant is at the front of a trend that is spreading rapidly through the American automobile industry: flexible manufacturing. It allows automakers to satisfy the rapidly changing desires of consumers, and it provides new vehicles nearly as often as fashion designers turn out new clothes.
Every major company, from the Big Three automakers in Detroit to companies in Japan, Germany and Korea, is embracing the concept. In theory, flexible manufacturing will let them build any combination of vehicles in one factory, regardless of size, design or body style.
The concept lets auto companies meet customer demand quickly, without wasting time and money tearing up factories. Companies that can put new vehicles on the market first stand the best shot at earning the highest profits.
"None of us know four years from now what the right mix will be," said Dennis C. Cuneo, executive vice president of Toyota Motor Manufacturing North America. "That's why you have to be flexible."
Dennis K. Pawley, the former head of manufacturing at Chrysler who is now a consultant, said: "Products are coming faster than you can blink an eye. If you don't have flexibility now, you're dead."
There is already proof of the payoff. This year, in an industry where each tenth of a market-share point is fought over like gold, Honda has picked up an impressive 1.1 points primarily because of two new vehicles: the Element and the Honda Pilot, a large S.U.V. Both are built in flexible plants: the Element in East Liberty, and the Pilot in Alliston, Ontario.
The potential savings are enormous, too, wiping out the industry's long-held perception that flexible factories are too expensive to create and maintain. Three years ago, when General Motors started production of the latest version of the Chevrolet Impala, it spent $240 million to retool its assembly line to add the vehicle at its Oshawa, Ontario, plant. But, thanks to the flexible-manufacturing system that it is installing in its plants, G.M. is spending just $45 million now to add new vehicles at its factories. And it estimates that the cost will drop to $20 million by 2005.
"We will be prepared to move with the market," said Gerald L. Elson, G.M.'s vice president in charge of vehicle operations.
Traditionally, entire factories have been used exclusively for a single kind of vehicle, like the endless rows of Model T's that Henry Ford churned out a century ago. Even today, Ford Motor has six factories devoted solely to the F-series pickup, of which it sells more than 750,000 a year. 
And, until this spring, the Chrysler division of DaimlerChrysler had three factories in the United States and Europe that built only minivans, while its Jeep plant in Detroit operated 24 hours a day throughout the 1990's building only Jeep Grand Cherokees.
The single-vehicle plant was designed for economies of scale. "The only priority was to be the low-cost producer," Mr. Pawley said.
The big problem comes when those vehicles don't sell, and the factories have to be shut down. Labor contracts require Detroit auto companies to pay laid-off union members practically their entire wages and all their benefits when plants are not operating. This need to keep factories going also makes it costly for companies to introduce low-volume vehicles, because their limited sales cannot pay for keeping an entire plant running.
In installing flexible-manufacturing systems, the Big Three are aiming to race against Japanese auto companies. In a research report titled "The Joy of Flex," Michael Bruynesteyn, an industry analyst at Prudential Securities, wrote that Toyota and Honda were ahead of the Big Three automakers in adopting flexible-manufacturing concepts, in part because of the demands those companies face in Japan.
There, customers' tastes change even faster than those in the United States, meaning that automakers have to offer wide-ranging lineups with dozens of cars and constantly introduce new products. Many will be sold only in Japan, and for no more than a couple of years. 
Even a decade ago, Mazda was able to build up to 14 different vehicles at its plant in Hofu, Japan, and eight at its factory in Hiroshima. 
That expertise did not show up when Japanese companies first came to the United States. In earlier years, Japanese companies primarily produced high-volume cars, like the Toyota Camry and Honda Accord, taking time to figure out the American market, and to train their work forces. But as they have expanded their lineups and gained market share, the companies are flexing their plants with a vengeance.
One example is Nissan Motors, repeatedly ranked as the most efficient producer of vehicles by the Harbour Report, an annual manufacturing study.
Between its plant in Smyrna, Tenn., and its just-opened factory in Canton, Miss., Nissan can produce 10 different automobile nameplates. "People want a high degree of personalization in their cars, and flexibility is going to be the key to that," said Jed Connelly, Nissan's senior vice president for North American sales.
Likewise, flexible manufacturing is allowing Toyota to shuffle its vehicles between its North American plants, as if they were a deck of playing cards. This year, it switched the Toyota Sienna minivan from its factory in Georgetown, Ky., to one in Princeton, Ind., where it makes pickups and S.U.V.'s.
Caught off guard by the soaring popularity of the new version of the Sienna, which is sold out for up to 10 weeks at some showrooms, Toyota has increased Sienna production at the Princeton plant by about 18 percent, dialing back on the Tundra pickup and the Sequoia S.U.V. in order to do so.
Flexibility still poses tremendous challenges to auto companies. In making it work, an important role is played by the body shop -- the area where the different metal pieces of a car ortruck are welded together by robots, before the body moves off to be painted and the interiors installed. Imitating the humans that once performed those tasks, the robots were each programmed to do one task, again and again, on a fixed assembly line, with fixed conveyor belts.
Now, thanks to improved technology, manufacturers can program robots to handle many different welding tasks, at different places on a car body. And they are now using lighter body carriers, which hang from above the assembly line and gently support the vehicle rather than clamp onto it. This means that width and length aren't important as long as the vehicle can fit into the space provided on the assembly line and the robot knows where to weld.
THIS month, at G.M.'s factory in Lansing, Mich., the bodies of Cadillac CTS sedans and the new SRX crossover vehicle were gliding down the line next to one another, processed without a hiccup thanks to a system that G.M. calls C-Flex. In the fall, G.M. will merge in a third model, the STS luxury sedan.
The only part that the three vehicles have in common is a single metal piece that sits below the windshield, through which warm air from the engine compartment is expelled.
G.M.'s ability to pull this off starts at the beginning of the assembly process, where a worker slaps a sticker with a bar code on a rail that runs beneath the vehicle. Along the way, scanners read the information on the sticker and signal to robots down the line the type of automobile that is coming their way. As the body slides into place, the robots automatically align themselves to make the correct welds.
G.M. officials hope to have a flex system in all of its plants, in some form, by 2005. United Auto Workers officials declined to comment on what that might mean for its members, who now number 400,000, down from 1 million in 1978. 
Though local U.A.W. leaders cooperated with G.M. in building the Lansing plant, it employs half the numbers of workers of an old-style G.M. plant.
GARY CHAISON, professor of industrial relations at Clark University in Worcester, Mass., says some workers view the stampede toward flexible manufacturing as the industry's latest effort to eliminate their jobs.
"In the past, auto workers were the aristocrats of manufacturing," he said. "But flexible manufacturing not only makes the employer more profitable and workers more productive, it takes away power from the union. They're really worried about that."
Yet unions cannot ignore the increasing sales and growing market share of foreign manufacturers who use the system, Professor Chaison said.
Indeed, Toyota plans to include its flexible system in a new factory -- its seventh in North America -- under construction in San Antonio. There, it will build big pickups, planning to challenge the Detroit companies in a market that they have dominated for years.

HEADLINE: Betting the Ranch, a Really Big One 

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO

DATELINE: KINGSVILLE, Tex. 

 BODY:
AUGUST in South Texas, with temperatures soaring above 100 degrees and the humidity forming a dew that simmers on the mesquite brush, is not the easiest time for cowboys on the King Ranch. On such days, the tools of modern ranching, like air-conditioned pickups and helicopters used to shoo cattle, help only so much.
 "There's no good explanation for why we do this work," said Joey Salazar, 34, a leathery fifth-generation kineno, as the residents and employees born on the legendary 825,000-acre ranch call themselves. "I was born on this ranch, and I expect to die on it," Mr. Salazar, sweat-drenched and clad in chaps and boots with spurs, added in Spanish while taking a break from castrating a group of young calves. 
 Watching Mr. Salazar and other kinenos, one might think that little has changed since Richard King, a New York-born steamboat pilot, recruited vaqueros, as cowboys are still called in South Texas, and their families from northern Mexico 150 years ago to form the backbone of what is now about a $300 million-a-year business empire. Kinenos, in fact, translates as king's men. 
The King heirs branched out over time into racehorse breeding and oil and gas exploration and acquired large ranching interests overseas. The Kleberg family, descended from Richard King, held sway over the family's holdings from an austere whitewashed mansion on the ranch.
Were he alive today, Richard King would hardly recognize the enterprise. King Ranch Inc., the privately held company that controls the ranch, is run by a Harvard M.B.A. from outside the Kleberg clan who conducts business from a corporate suite in a Houston high-rise.
And now the King Ranch is betting its future on areas that have nothing to do with cattle, from leasing land to quail hunters to lending the ranch's name to a line of luxurious Ford pickup trucks.
The King Ranch, like some of the nation's other large ranching empires, is confronting a whirlwind of change. Some, like the Waggoner Ranch of North Texas, have been roiled by protracted family feuds. Others, like the Parker Ranch of Hawaii, with its own colorful cowboys called paniolos, have been buffeted by falling beef prices. Not surprisingly, rivals wonder whether King Ranch, too, will stumble.
CHIEF among the challenges, perhaps, is a lawsuit that threatens to tear asunder a chunk of land at the heart of the ranch. Another pressing issue is how to keep cattle relevant in an age of skepticism over the benefits of eating beef. 
Already, the legal assault by descendants of Maj. William W. Chapman has frayed the King Ranch's iconic status by raising questions about its legitimacy. William Chapman, a veteran of the Mexican War, was a business partner of Richard King when the ranch was formed in the 1850's. 
The lawsuit, which appellate decisions have upheld in favor of the Chapman descendants, is under review by the Texas Supreme Court. Reduced to its essentials, it contends that Robert Justus Kleberg, the lawyer who took over the King Ranch after marrying Richard King's favorite daughter in the 1880's, may have swindled William Chapman's widow of half of a roughly 15,000-acre holding at the ranch's core, known as the Rincon de Santa Gertrudis, after an old Spanish land grant. 
According to the Chapman descendants, Robert Kleberg had represented William Chapman's widow, Helen, while secretly working on retainer for Richard King, an accusation that the King Ranch contests. Thus, they argue, a conflict of interest clouded a settlement in the 1880's granting the King Ranch full control of the Rincon de Santa Gertrudis.
Edward Caleb Coker, a descendant of William Chapman and a lawyer and amateur historian in Charlotte, N.C., said he accidentally stumbled upon Robert Kleberg's dual role in the legal challenge while working on a book a decade ago about Helen Chapman, his great-great grandmother. 
Since then, Mr. Coker said, he and other family members have spent $300,000 in legal fees to advance their claim. The lawsuit has ensnarled not only the King Ranch but also Exxon Mobil, which has leased the mineral rights on the ranch since the early 1930's, when it was known as Humble Oil. 
Just half the original Santa Gertrudis land parcel is at stake, about 7,500 acres, or less than 1 percent of the King Ranch's total in South Texas. But losing that land could weaken the ranch, because it includes areas where the Kleberg family has collected payments for decades from Exxon Mobil for energy exploration leases; parts of downtown Kingsville, the Victorian-style town of 26,000 founded on the edge of the ranch a century ago; and the Kingsville Naval Air Station, a top center for pilot training.
It is unclear what damages the Chapman descendants could receive if they win or whether the lawsuit is even valid more than a century after the events in dispute. Mr. Coker said in an interview that he believed a statute of limitations did not apply to the lawsuit because statutes could relate to the time of the discovery of fraud, not the date of the event. 
If Mr. Coker and the other Chapman heirs prevail and the lawsuit is allowed to go to trial, the ruling could set an important precedent for questioning the legitimacy of land titles secured in Texas in the 19th century, especially for Hispanic families who contend that land grants dating to the Spanish empire were taken over by white settlers through fraudulent methods.
King Ranch executives bristle at the mention of the lawsuit. At different times in recent years, the ranch and other parties named in the suit, including Exxon Mobil, have had a combined team of more than 20 lawyers employed to defend their interests from the Chapman heirs' claim.
"We think their claim has no merit whatsoever," said Jack Hunt, the Harvard-trained chief executive of King Ranch Inc., who came to the company after running the large Tejon Ranch in Southern California. "This is a matter that the King Ranch settled more than 100 years ago."
Whatever the outcome of the legal battle, the King Ranch faces challenges on the business front as well, most notably the sluggish demand for beef.
Although per-capita consumption of American beef has recently flattened out, and perhaps even risen in the last year or two as some people switched to meat because of the popular Atkins diet, it remains more than 10 percent lower than it was in 1980.
ALTOGETHER, the King Ranch has a herd of more than 60,000 cattle, preserving its place among the nation's largest active cattle ranches. And some Texas-size superlatives still apply to the ranch, parts of which are near Corpus Christi: it is about the size of Rhode Island, and its fences, if put in a straight line, would stretch from New York City to Fargo, N.D.
In response to the changing business climate, the King Ranch has sold all its properties abroad -- from Australia to Venezuela -- to focus on domestic operations. 
Even as it shed these businesses, King Ranch bolstered its agricultural operations apart from livestock, seeking to lessen its dependency on the volatile and cyclical cattle industry. In doing so, it has become one of the nation's leading agricultural companies in some areas.
Through its control of Consolidated Citrus in Southern Florida, for example, King Ranch has emerged as the nation's top citrus producer. So today Mr. Hunt, a soft-spoken 58-year-old, is as likely to expound on competition from corporate orange producers in Sao Paulo as from Brazil's commercial cattle herd.
In Florida, King Ranch also has about 12,000 acres for growing sugar cane and 3,000 for sod, in addition to large parts of the ranch in South Texas for cotton. Agricultural operations excluding cattle are now responsible for more than half the company's revenue, according to people familiar with King Ranch's finances.
The company's decision to hire Paul Genho, 61, several years ago as vice president and general manager for livestock operations ended an internecine struggle over King Ranch's direction as a family-owned company. Ultimately, the board approved a coup that ousted Stephen J. Kleberg, the great-great grandson of Richard King and the last family member to manage the ranch directly, replacing him with Mr. Genho. To some, including Mr. Kleberg, who became a director at the time of his removal, the move ended an era.
"Sure, I'm nostalgic about the way it was, and I'm sure my grandfather or his father would also feel nostalgic if they were alive," Mr. Kleberg, known around the ranch as Tio, said. "There's always something passing in the ranching life, like the era of the cattle drives, which is just history now. We just need to look ahead to make sure we don't miss out on the changes that will keep us competitive."
The descendants who control the ranch still gather at least once a year in Kingsville to discuss King Ranch affairs. Richard Sugden, a Wyoming physician and Kleberg heir, said he was generally pleased with the direction the company had taken since nonfamily managers took charge.
"The other stuff makes more money, but I see cattle remaining part of the mix for both economic and traditional reasons," said Mr. Sugden, the largest individual shareholder in King Ranch, with more than 5 percent of its stock.
Navigating the desires of the 100 or so heirs who own King Ranch shares falls to Mr. Hunt and, to a degree, Mr. Genho, who has a Ph.D. in animal science from the University of Florida. Mr. Genho speaks passionately about the need to find a balance among cattle raising, hunting and ecotourism.
On the ranch itself, hunting accounts for a growing portion of revenue, about equal to cattle raising. Some pay handsomely to hunt everything from quail to javelinas, the wild pigs also known as peccaries. Large companies account for most of the hunting leases on the ranch.
"Nothing beats quail hunting for entertaining customers," said Bill Davis, a hunting manager for a Louisiana mining company with a lease to hunt on the King Ranch.
The ranch also employs an ornithologist to lead bird watchers on tours, though the ecotourism operations involving the ranch's wildlife still account for a small portion of overall revenue. Wild-animal enthusiasts can also pay for private tours to see, not shoot, bobcats, coyotes and mountain lions.
"I see a day when nonconsumptive wildlife ops outstrip consumptive ops, but it ain't happening yet," said Butch Thompson, King Ranch's director of security and wildlife.
As King Ranch veers into new directions, some elements of its culture are bound to come under pressure. Nowhere are the changes more apparent than among the kinenos.
THE patron system that allowed Richard King and the Klebergs to rule the ranch in an almost cradle-to-grave fashion is slowly being replaced by contemporary management practices. Gone, for instance, are the days when ranch employees were each given 60 pounds of beef and 10 gallons of milk a month as part of their salary.
Salaries remain relatively low, with cowboys earning as little as $20,000 a year, but nearly all the ranch's employees have health insurance and are enrolled in retirement plans. About 300 families continue to live on the ranch and receive free housing, though some employees prefer to live in Kingsville.
A few college-educated kinenos have also risen to management positions, overseeing areas like human resources and financial audits. That is different from the days a century ago when Hispanics were not allowed to become foremen in charge of cowboys and other employees. 
Some things will never change, however, as long as vaqueros are needed to work among the cattle herd under the South Texas sun. Robert J. Cavazos, a retired cowboy foreman and kineno who recently completed a book on the King Ranch, compared working on the ranch to "feeling like a superman."

Speakingof New Jobs . . .

BYLINE:  By JULIE FLAHERTY

 BODY:
It took months for Catalyst, a nonprofit research group that focuses on women in business, to find a successor to its president of 10 years, Sheila Wellington. Its choice is Ilene H. Lang, 59, the founding chief executive of AltaVista, the creator of the search engine. 
 Ms. Lang, who has also led several dot-coms, run her own consulting practice and been a partner of First Light Capital, a venture capital firm, has one qualm: trading her beloved Boston, where she has lived since 1961, for New York.  Glenview State Bank in Chicago is making less of a fuss over its departing president, who noted approvingly in a bank newsletter article that Hitler had "reduced unemployment in Germany three times as fast as America's Roosevelt." The Anti-Defamation League and others complained, the article was pulled, an apology was made, and David Raub, who is away on vacation, is now a senior executive vice president.

HEADLINE: Where to Turn When Rates Are Low 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "What Investors Should Do Now" (Aug. 10), which described possible investment alternatives in a period of low interest rates: 
 The Federal Reserve's relentless lowering of interest rates has bolstered consumer spending in the short run while clobbering senior savers. To older Americans struggling to live on Social Security and certificates of deposit, the Fed says it's the price that must be paid to stimulate the economy.
Longer-term consequences have been ignored. Because of low interest rates, homeowners have been enticed into buying much more expensive homes and have taken on huge amounts of both new and refinanced mortgage debt.
If the current housing bubble bursts and prices fall below mortgage levels, will the Fed tell stunned homeowners that the surge in foreclosures is the price we have to pay to stimulate the economy?

EDWIN P. BERLIN
San Diego, Aug. 10

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Flash Mobs; 
Guess Some People Don't Have Anything Better to Do

BYLINE:  By AMY HARMON

 BODY:
THE messages come by e-mail or cellphone, with instructions to meet at a specific place and time. Once there, participants in flash mobs, the compulsively deconstructed geek-chic game of the summer, briefly perform some collective activity, then flee.
 Since the first one in mid-June in New York, hundreds of strangers in more than a dozen cities have engaged in such gatherings. The mob in San Francisco's Golden Gate Park last weekend played duck-duck-goose. Last Wednesday, in Sao Paulo, Brazil, people took off their shoes and banged them on the street. In one of New York's six flash mobs, the crowddutifully followed instructions to mimic bird calls in Central Park for 20 seconds. 
 Inspired by dozens of media reports and many more Web log postings, enthusiasts in Portland, Ore., Tempe, Ariz., and Toledo, Ohio, are planning their own flash mobs.
But the flash mob juggernaut has now run into a flash mob backlash that may be spreading faster than the fad itself. The collision has ignited a decidedly Internet-style debate on the nature of social connection in the digital age. 
Anti-mobbers lump the flash mobs in the prank tradition of phone-booth stuffing, streaking, flagpole sitting and goldfish-swallowing. E-mail lists like "antimob" and "slashmob" have sprung up, as did a Web site warning that "flashmuggers" are bound to show up "wherever there's groups of young, naive, wealthy, bored fashionistas to be found." And a new definition was circulated last week on several Web sites: "flash mob, noun: An impromptu gathering, organized by means of electronic communication, of the unemployed."
Flash mobbers make no apologies for their lack of political mission, but stake a claim to significance nonetheless. They invoke Dada, the Yippies and "smart mobs," a term coined by the author Howard Rheingold, to describe the use of digital technology to mobilize people quickly for spontaneous creative gatherings.
The organizer of the first flash mob in New York, who will identify himself only as "Bill," argues that flash mobs exploit a desire to escape the virtual world of the Internet and join a real-world electronic underground.
"This isn't a movement, it's a pre-movement," said Bill, a New Yorker who says he works in the "culture industry." "People intuitively understand that it is a powerful thing to very quickly and surprisingly transform a physical space, and one reason they keep coming back to the mobs is there is this feeling that something is being created that can't be ignored."
Critics acknowledge the powerful combination of physical and electronic connection that the mobs thrive on, but many see them as disturbingly empty of purpose. If people are willing to abandon their computer screen only to open umbrellas en masse -- as they did in Austin, Tex., last Monday -- what is the point, critics wonder. 
"From our point of view it's a wasted opportunity," said Tom Sander, executive director of a project on civic engagement conducted by Harvard University's Kennedy School of Government. "It's great to have fun, but it would be a lot more interesting if the people organizing this tried to think of ways to utilize it to have people come together to build social networks." 
Some anti-mobbers say the phenomenon is an example of the herd mentality. "How is it possible that a technology with such potential to empower the individual has turned into an irritating clique-machine for the hipster sheep?" asks the Web log flashhack.blogspot.com. 
Others just find the events hopelessly contrived. (The organizers take pains to protect their identities, and instructions on the activity of the moment are typically handed out on pieces of paper to people who respond to the anonymous e-mail invitation.) 
FLASH mob organizers admit to being a bit taken aback at how quickly their game has been adopted. When "Jane," a San Francisco organizer, sent out anonymous invitations to her friends in June, they deleted the e-mail, she recalled. When she asked about it, they told her that they thought it was silly.
But after Wired News, an online publication, posted an article about flash mobs on its Web site, interest began to spiral upward. Now, Jane says, "I'm getting invited by my friends to my own mobs." About 350 people showed up for the flash mob in Golden Gate Park. 
Jane, 29, says the mobs answer a yearning for basic fun in a time of war, terrorism threats and recession. That it is a new kind of fun, not controlled by the usual entertainment conglomerates, adds to the appeal.
"We have protests in San Francisco all the time," she said. "The whole point of this is that there is no point." 
But that may not be for long. 
Paul Resnick, an associate professor at the University of Michigan's School of Information, says the flash mob is simply one of several early forays into building stronger ties between strangers by way of computer. Flash-mob organizing, Mr. Resnick argues, will inevitably be used in political campaigns and corporate marketing. 
Even some who have enjoyed participating in the mobs say the trend is winding down. Fears that the mob mechanism is already being taken over by corporate interests have surfaced on Web logs. A mob planned for Toronto was called off when it seemed that it could be overrun by the news media and the police.
"The flash mob seems to be finished," wrote Christina Ray, an artist in Brooklyn who attended two New York mobs, on her Web log last week. 
"I think people will remember it as a great social experiment with the technology we have right now," Ms. Ray said. "But it's beginning to get sort of goofy."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 24, 2003

 CORRECTION:
An article last Sunday about flash mobs, which gather briefly and then disperse, misstated the location of one such gathering in San Francisco. It was in Dolores Park, not Golden Gate Park.

HEADLINE: BULLETIN BOARD; 
At the Top, Pay and Performance Are Often Far Apart

BYLINE:  By HUBERT B. HERRING

 BODY:
Chief executives, be warned: Graef Crystal's calculator is humming again. And the latest statistical salvo from Mr. Crystal, that relentless tallier of corporate pay, could give them red faces to match their bulging wallets. 
 By Mr. Crystal's reckoning, the average chiefs total compensation is a staggering $12 million, with stock options accounting for 60 percent. Mr. Crystal, applying a complex formula to data provided by Equilar, figures that when pay is higher than average, fully 86 percent of the difference cannot be explained by the company's size or performance. 
 And of those executives, whose pay exceeds what he would have expected based on the company's revenue, Mr. Crystal just happens to have a list. HUBERT B. HERRING

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; 
Ah, Parisian Ambiance; Oh, Manhattan Regulations

BYLINE:  By DENNY LEE

 BODY:
Even on a sunny day, Al Roker won't be dining outdoors at Ferrier Restaurant this summer. 
 The French bistro, a favorite of the weatherman and other Upper East Side notables, was stripped of its cafe license this summer. The ensuing spat has become a cause celebre among restaurant owners, who say the harsh treatment points to the unfairness of cafe enforcement rules that went into effect this year. 
 For 14 years, Ferrier has operated a 12-table sidewalk cafe on East 65th Street near Madison Avenue. When the restaurant applied for a license renewal this year, Community Board 8 gave it unanimous approval, saying it had received no complaints about the place. 
 But the city's Department of Consumer Affairs rejected the application, anyway, saying no sidewalk cafes were allowed in the area, in the Madison Avenue Preservation District. Apparently, the city erred in giving Ferrier a sidewalk license in the past. 
 Thinking it was a bureaucratic oversight, the owners went ahead and set up a cafe, as they do each spring. They quickly received two violations. Invoking the new law, the second called for $2,000 in fines and padlocking the entire restaurant for 30 days. Ferrier is appealing the penalties and is fighting to reinstate the cafe license. 
 "It's so crazy," said Irving Sutton, an owner of Ferrier, who added that he planned to lay off 10 people because of lost income. "This really killed the business." 
 Elected officials have rallied to Ferrier's side. "I believe the Department of Consumer Affairs has picked the wrong restaurant as a target of its new enforcement powers," said Borough President C. Virginia Fields. "With our sluggish economy, I should think the city would be interested in resolving this issue, especially since jobs, tax revenue and a viable business are at stake."
 This is not the first time restaurant owners have criticized the new sidewalk rules. In March, the city agreed to scale back the fees for new licenses after restaurants complained of 600 percent increases. 
 But city officials say the new rules are addressing residents' complaints about noisy andillegal cafes. In the case of Ferrier, they argue, the city is simply enforcing the rules evenhandedly. 
 "We are hoping this will get the attention of restaurant owners," said Dina Improta, a Consumer Affairs spokeswoman. "Before this legislation was enacted, the only thing we could do is issue fine after fine. We would seize their furniture, and they would replace it the next day." DENNY LEE

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE; 
Economic Slump? Umbrella Sales Are Great

BYLINE:  By ERIN CHAN

 BODY:
It's nice to let a smile be your umbrella, but sometimes you need an umbrella to be your umbrella. Especially this summer.
 As the storm clouds roll endlessly across the city sky, there are those who actually delight in the deluge because they profit from the downpours. And chief among the precipitation profiteers is Burt Biderman, umbrella maker and wholesaler. 
 This summer, when carrying an umbrella seems as essential as wearing underwear, Mr. Biderman has watched sales at his Liberty Umbrella Company in Midtown soar 50 percent from last year, a statistic that almost makes this company president -- who wears gold wire-rimmed glasses and normally exudes seriousness -- want to, well, sing in the rain. 
 "We've been going crazy filling orders, but it's a good crazy," Mr. Biderman said. "No rain makes you feel old, oh my God. I feel bad for resort people, but economically, I'm very happy." 
 From the beginning of June until last Wednesday, New York received 19.48 inches of rain, already making it the seventh wettest for those three months since Central Park started measuring precipitation in 1869, according to Peter Wichrowski, a meteorologist with the National Weather Service.
 If the skies squeeze out three more inches of rain by the end of this month, the record for the wettest June, July and August -- set in 1975 when 22.4 inches of rain fell on the city -- will be broken, said Stephen S. Fybish, a local weather historian. The average for those three months is 12.68 inches.
 For Mr. Biderman, there is no question that the rain has driven up sales, but his company also holds the license that allows it to turn the prints of the London designer Lulu Guinness into patterns for umbrellas. These handbag-turned-umbrella prints do not mirror the mundane black of those $3 street umbrellas but rather radiate in bright red with Scottie dogs, in Paris street scenes with blue Vespa-like scooters and in almost everything else that would make one forget about the rain.
 Those umbrellas were especially popular at Liberty's booth last week at the New York International Gift Fair at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center. "Oh, my god, yesterday, we were so busy," said Bonni Orloff, a company vice president who lives in Midtown. Rain aside, it did not hurt that the Guinness designs had been seen on HBO's "Sex and the City." 
 Corinna Vere Nicoll, also working at the Liberty booth, did not act quite as charitable toward the rain.
 "It's very irritating," said Ms. Vere Nicoll, who lives on the Upper East Side but comes from London. "You just don't know what to wear. If you wear jeans, your pants will get wet, but if you wear a skirt, your shoes will get wet. It's depressing for summer, especially since it's my first summer in New York. Americans think London is the city that always rains, but since I've been here, this is more rain than I've ever seen in London." 
 By the way, Ms. Vere Nicoll attended the fair as the sales assistant for Lulu Guinness handbags -- not for the umbrellas. And even the most ardent purse lover knows that plopping a handbag over your head in the rain will do about as much good in keeping dry as smiling will. ERIN CHAN

SECTION: Section 14; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk; Pg. 4

HEADLINE: BRONX UP CLOSE; 
Retail Chains Arrive, but With Weak Links

BYLINE:  By SETH KUGEL

 BODY:
WHEN Starbucks opened its first Bronx store at 314 East Fordham Road in 1999, it added an upscale touch to a bustling commercial strip and was heralded as another sign of economic revival. Fernando Ferrer, the borough president then, brewed a ceremonial first espresso. 
 Four years later, the lines of customers at 314 East Fordham Road are longer than Starbucks' marketers could have dreamed. But it is no longer a Starbucks. The coffeehouse declined to renew its lease and slipped out quietly in May 2002 and was replaced by a T-Mobile store. 
 Interviewed last week, a Starbucks spokesman cited "competitive reasons" for the closing, but refused to give details. Prevailing wisdom on the streets of the Bronx, however, goes something like this: rushed families looking for bargains on clothes were unwilling to slow down and squander those savings on Frappuccinos. The T-Mobile store offers a more popular service: a place to pay cellphone bills in cash. 
 The experiences of Starbucks and T-Mobile underscore just how tricky the Bronx has been for national chains. There has been a lot of success in a borough once ignored by big retail names. Two Home Depots have opened since 1997. Kmart came to Bruckner Plaza in 1999; Barnes & Noble opened in Bay Plaza the same year, with nary a locally owned bookstore for miles around to complain. (The only neighbor to put up a fight was Nobody Beats the Wiz, worried about CD sales.) A Target is under construction near Marble Hill; BJ's signed a lease in the southeast Bronx. And even Starbucks was successful on its second try, with a booming store in diverse, middle-class Parkchester.
 Rafael Salaberrios, president of the Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation, which advises the borough president, said retailers abandoned the inner city so completely that they finally realized they had gone too far. "Now they're seeing an immense underserved population," he said. His organization conducted a study that found that from 1996 to 2001, retail employment in the Bronx rose 12.5 percent. The corporation is producing a CD-ROM to attract businesses to the Bronx.
 But the market is complex, and the borough still battles an outdated -- or at least greatly exaggerated -- reputation for urban decay. Ikea passed over the Bronx after plans for a nearby store in New Rochelle fell through. Local groups have had a tough time getting Marriott to look seriously at a South Bronx hotel. And after a decade of stumbles, the New Horizons Retail Shopping Center, with Pathmark, GNC and Radio Shack, is supposed to open in Crotona Park East in November. But so many other projected dates have come and gone, it is hard to say what will happen.
 Gary Axelbank, host of the BronxTalk cable television shows, said the failures are in part attributable to local politics. "You need good urban planning, and that falls to the community boards and City Council people to be well organized and not do things in a haphazard way," he said. "We haven't always had that in every neighborhood in the Bronx."
 Retail, of course, is not an economic cure-all. Unemployment in the Bronx is still the highest in the state, and efforts to attract company headquarters or back-office operations in the Bronx have not yet born much fruit. The lack of bigger firms is a sensitive issue. When it was suggested that McDonald's, with 2,250 employees, might be the Bronx's biggest for-profit employer, Mr. Salaberrios said he doubted it, but could not cite a bigger one.
 The borough president, Adolfo Carrion Jr., said retail is not a priority -- he would like to see medical laboratories move in to serve the borough's mammoth hospitals and art-handling companies take over empty warehouse space. But Mr. Carrion, an urban planner by trade, said bringing in retail chains boosts the Bronx's image. "There's a ripple effect to this that defies the stereotypes and image of the Bronx," he said.
 Mr. Carrion's definition of success underscores just how far the Bronx has to go. Earlier this year, even the opening of a Mail Boxes Etc. merited a presidential news release and a ribbon cutting.
 One contributing factor may be the lack of an active chamber of commerce in the Bronx. There was no chamber for years, and even though a new chamber started in March, five months later it is virtually impossible for an outsider to get in touch with it: it has no Web site and no listed phone number, and an e-mail address found on several Bronx Web sites is inactive. 
 That leaves the work to politicians and nonprofits. Assemblyman Carl E. Heastie, who represents the northeast Bronx, procured financing for the North Bronx Business Outreach Center, which he hopes will lure a better mix of businesses and a big retail name to the not-so-bustling northern reaches of White Plains Road. "We have three hair salons on the same block," he lamented.
 The arrival of Barnes & Noble is at least in part attributable to Assemblyman Stephen B. Kaufman. In 1998, he publicly and vociferously denounced Barnes & Noble for ignoring the Bronx. The company's chairman, Leonard Riggio, shot a nasty letter to him. "Do you have some sort of misplaced crusader complex which needs fixing?" he wrote. But 21 months later, Barnes & Noble opened its store to rave reviews. 
 Although local merchants often fear the competition of big-box stores, and residents fear traffic and construction, community leaders and academics generally say a mix of big and small businesses is the key. 
 "From where we stand it's an absolute necessity," said Neil Parriser, senior vice president of the South Bronx Overall Development Corporation, or SoBro. "To not have large names is a big mistake. It relegates you to a whole different psychology and you lose out on the market, because people want to come to the Kmarts, they want to come to the Staples." Staples, in fact, plans a store in the long-troubled Hub shopping district, in an unused three-block stretch that has long been marked by SoBro for development.
 And even though chains siphon profits to headquarters elsewhere, they do bring jobs. "The reason big retail chains are good," said Mitchell Moss, director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University, "is that they employ lots of people and lots of youth. Retailing is a gateway job."
 What kind of retail, of course, also matters. While McDonald's flourishes, the Bronx has the lowest Starbucks per capita ratio in the city. Even affluent Riverdale, where many residents refuse to use the word "Bronx" in their mailing address, has not attracted one. The result: in Manhattan, there is a Starbucks for every 11,000 people; in Staten Island, one for every 150,000, in Queens, one for every 185,000 and in Brooklyn one for every 500,000. In the Bronx, the lone Parkchester location theoretically serves 1.3 million.
 Yet a recent visit revealed a scene strikingly similar to any other Starbucks. On a lazy summer weekday afternoon, the store was busy. A family stopped by after shopping, teenagers gossiped, an opera singer relaxed with coffee, a teacher took notes.
 The teacher, Anthony Lett, who had made the long trip from his home halfway across the Bronx, near Yankee Stadium, said the borough could support just about any retail operation. The singer, Johnny Maldonado, agreed. "I understand the stereotype, but it's really a misconception," he said, nestled into a chair by the window. "You have all kinds of people living in the Bronx. Our money is just as green as anyone else's."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Starbucks currently has one outlet in the Bronx, in diverse, middle-class Parkchester. The borough has two Home Depots, top left, and one Barnes & Noble, below. And Target is on the way, above, right off the Major Deegan. (Photos by left and above, Don Hogan Charles/The New York Times;far left and below, G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times)
